¶ De modo cauterizandi in fluxu sanguins ex arteria in uulnere.	Regarding the cautery of a vein in a wound
Caput LVIII.	Chapter 58
Multotiens accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, quae incisa est apud uulnus, quod accidit extrinsecus, aut apud incisionem apostematis, aut cauterium membri, et similia eis: et fit difficile abscindere eum.	Many times there happens the flow of blood from a vein that has been cut in a wound, which happens outside, or at the incision of the skin, or by cautery of a limb, and the like: and this makes it difficult to close it off
Cum ergo accidit alicui illud, tunc propera cum manu tua ad orificium arteriae, et pone super ipsum digitum tuum indicem: et stringe eum multum, donec obsessus sit sanguis sub digito tuo, et non egrediatur ex eo aliquid.	When this happens to anyone, then do so with your hand at the opening of the vein, and place above it your index finger: and press it firmly, until the blood is held under your finger, and does not come out of it again
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	Then put on the fire a small olive twig, and a great number more: and blow over them, until they are ignited somewhat
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then take from the wound one, or a few, or many, according to the wound and the place, in which the vein has been broken, and place the cautery on the vein itself: and as soon as you have moved your finger away, hold the cautery in place, until the blood is closed off
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	And if it comes out when you remove your finger from the opening of the vein, and extinguish the cautery, then take another cautery quickly, from those which are prepared in the fire.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Do not cease to do this until the blood is severed.
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	Beware lest you burn the nerve in that place and increase the pain of the ailment
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	You know that when blood flows from an artery, it is not possible to sever it: especially when the artery is large, except with four fingers.
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	Or with the cautery, as we have said before
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	Or by extracting it, when it is not extracted
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	For when it is extracted, its extremities are contracted, and the blood is severed.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	Or it is bound with strong ligature.
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	Or a medicine is placed upon it that has the property of severing blood, and it is bound with a tight constriction
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	Whoever performs an incision with ligature and tightening with cloth, or with the application of burnings and the like, does not confer on it sufficient pain, except rarely.
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	If, however, this happens to anyone and there is no physician present, neither medicine: then one should start by placing the index finger over the opening of the vein, as we have said before, and constrict it tightly, until the blood is choked from the upper part of the wound, and over the artery
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	And the finger should not be moved, but should be held down with cold water or ice always, until the blood solidifies, and increases, and is severed
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	And meanwhile consider what is needed from the cautery, or from medicine
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	End of First Section.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	Book of Surgery by Albucasis, Part II.
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	On Incision, Perforation, and Phlebotomy in Wounds, and Similar Procedures.
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	We have spoken in the first chapter concerning all ailments which are amenable to the cautery of fire and burning medicines, and the occasions when these are necessary, their causes, and their instruments, and the forms of cautery.
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	And following we shall treat of the chapters from the head down to the foot
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	I proceed in this chapter in the same manner: so as to satisfy the seeker of knowledge concerning this matter
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	Before I begin, it is necessary to tell you what is omitted from this chapter which is found in the first chapter concerning cautery.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	Therefore it is necessary to exercise great caution in this procedure, because in this chapter there is great bloodshed with blood vessels, with the result that there is great danger of swelling of the limb, or of wound, or of bursting of an abscess, or of bursting of an artery, or of fracture of a bone, or of similar occurrences, which are all accompanied by tremors, fear, and great loss of blood
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	I warn you, do not be afraid of this which is contained in hesitation, for indeed it is done in the art of man as in the art of healing the sick.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	For such is the man who is enraged with his ailment: he is light in his blood: because of the greatness of his ailment and the length of his suffering
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	And because of the fear which signifies death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	And because he gives himself up to you, and tells you that he hopes for health, knowing that his ailment is pernicious
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	It is not proper that you consent to those who come to you from outside, whose manner is like this.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	Take care, however, lest your eagerness surpass your prudence and your ferocity.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	Do not presume anything beyond what is known by science, except that which experience confirms in you the success of your praiseworthy actions.
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	Make use of the care of all your patients, the prognostication and the indication of that which is convenient for their health.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	For in this lies for you the aid to the acquisition of fame and glory, and the memory and praise
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	May God inspire you, his son, your intellect, and do not take away from you direction and inspiration: for this is in his hand.</start_of_turn>
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	And I, too, order this Chapter to be distinguished by chapters, according as it follows in the Chapter of Cautery, from the groin to the feet: that all your inquiries concerning what is best and what is needful may be alleviated from you.</start_of_turn>
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	Of the care of water which accumulates in the heads of children.</start_of_turn>
Caput I.	Chapter I.</start_of_turn>
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	Know that this illness often happens to children at birth: or when the midwife tightens the head of the child without gentleness.</start_of_turn
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	And sometimes it happens also from an occult cause which is not known.</start_of_turn
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	And I have not seen this illness in anyone except children: and concerning all those whom I have seen suffer from it, I have deemed it appropriate to send them away from surgery for this.</start_of_turn
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	And indeed I saw from among the young ones whose heads were filled with water, and their heads grew great every day, until they could no longer sit upon themselves because of the size of their heads: and their moisture increased until they died.
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	Or else such moisture accumulates between the skin and bone: or accumulates under the bone upon the flesh.
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	And the operation in such a case, if there is moisture between the skin and bone, and the swelling is small, then it is necessary to make a single fissure in the middle of the head, equal in length to two knots, until the moisture is cured
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	This is the form of the sponge.
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	If therefore the moisture is greatly increased, and the swelling is great, then make two incisions, according to this form
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	If the moisture is under the bone, and its sign is that the edges of the head are open from every side: and the water is squeezed out when you press your hand inwards, and it is not hidden by that: then it is necessary to make three incisions in the middle of the head, according to this method.
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	And after the incision extract all the moisture
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	Then bind the incisions with strips and threads.
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	Then keep that clean with wine and oil until the fifth day.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	Then loosen the ligament, and care for the wound with tension and care.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	And do not bind the head with equality
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	And feed the sick man with little food of little moisture until the limb is healed, and recovered
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	And another method of incision is that you consider where the swelling appears and the collection of water is great
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	Wherever the head is more, either in the back or front, or on the right or left.
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	Go up therefore with the incision where you see the swelling and the discharge of water: and cut that according to what is possible for you.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	Observe, that you do not cut an artery, and that there is an increase in the flow of blood, and that the patient dies from that flow with the evacuation of moisture.
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	Concerning the incision of the arteries which are behind the ears
Caput II.	Chapter 2
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	When something falls into the eyes or chest, and it becomes old, and no remedy is of use: then the last remedy is the incision of those two arteries
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	It is necessary therefore when you wish to cut them, that you give the patient a sign that he should move his head.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	Then scrape the place with rough cloth, so that the arteries appear
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	Then bind the patient's neck with anything you have.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	Then consider where the pulse is beating
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	And the places where both are located are those which are behind the ears depressed: and they are rarely hidden, except in some people
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	Then sign with a scar above each: and cut each with a spatula as sharp as possible, cutting through to the bone: and do that through the width of the head
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	And if you wish, introduce the spatula under the artery, and cut upwards with the incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	And let the length of the incision be like two joined fingers.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	For when the artery is cut, blood flows out with the pulsation, which jumps inside with frequent jumps
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	If the artery does not appear to the sense, then it is necessary that measures be taken from the thumb to quantify the amount of space of three fingers.
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	Then signs with the thumb inwards, and find until the bone.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	And that which must be emitted from the blood is six ounces, and perhaps more or less is emitted from it.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	All of this is according to the quantity which appears to you from the patient and the refilling of the artery of him.
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	Then consider concerning the pulse.
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	Then if anything remains to the bone from the soft part, then cut that, so that there be no cold swelling: then bind the pulse with strips of linen cloth
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it with unguents, until it is healed
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	Concerning the extraction of arteries, which are in time.
Caput III.	Chapter 3.
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	When it happens to a man an ancient headache, or an acute catarrh due to acrid humilities and heat in the lacerations of the times, or an old soda, or bile, or similar things: and it is not to be remedied by the methods of the medical art, then we are experts in these diseases of the arteries of the times, or their cauterization, as we have said
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	And the manner of the operation in the extraction of these is that the sick man grasps the hair which are in the times, and brings them to the apparent artery in the time.
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	And itself is often seen by you from your pulse, and rarely hides itself except in a few men, or the coldness of the air.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	And if it hides itself from you, then the sick man binds his head with anything he has: then he will rub the place with rough cloth
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	Until the vapor has reached the place of the warm water, it will manifest itself visibly.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	Then grasp the sponge, which is already wet before its shape becomes visible.</start_of_turn>
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	Then cleanse the skin with it, and with the help of this [sponge] reach the artery.</start_of_turn>
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	Then throw in the cautery, and draw out the cautery upwards, until you have withdrawn it from the skin, and made it recede from the tunics beneath it on all sides.</start_of_turn
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	If the artery is small: then grasp the cautery with the extremity of the hook.</start_of_turn
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Then cut from that side as much as the length of its extremities, and tighten, so that the blood flow is not increased.</start_of_turn
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	For if neither of these things is done, the blood will not ascend entirely.</start_of_turn
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	Then drain from the blood about six ounces, until three remain.</start_of_turn
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	If the artery is large: then it is necessary to bind the cautery in two places with a strong thread of silk: or with an silken cord, so that it does not burst before the wound has consolidated, and that the blood flow is increased.</start_of_turn
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	Then cut away the excess, which is between the two ligatures.</start_of_turn
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	Do this in an hour, or after an hour.</start_of_turn>
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	And if necessary, cauterize the cautery right up to the bone, with the cautery of a knife: until its extremities are cut through, and it remains in the same place as before the work.</start_of_turn
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	It is better work if the patient has a fever, or their complexion is flushed.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	For indeed, the cautery is of the things which hasten the completion of humours.
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	Therefore is better to cauterize.
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	And it is necessary after the extraction of arteries, that the cautery be applied to the ancient place: and that a little ball of wool be placed over the top of the cautery.
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	And after the application of the cautery, care must be taken with dry physicians, which make meat appear to be born, and with cloths, until the wound is healed.</start_of_turn>
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If during the work blood flows from the artery, then it is proper to stop the bleeding with the cautery, or to place something over the place with pressure: and clench your hand until the bleeding stops.</start_of_turn
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	If nothing of these things is present to you, then put over the place your finger, until the bleeding stops.</start_of_turn
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	And bind up the place with cold water, until the pain subsides, and bandage according as is necessary.</start_of_turn
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	And from this it is easier and more convenient to extract the artery, namely that you cauterize the vein with this cautery which has two blades: and that the sharpness of the two blades be like that of an almond.</start_of_turn
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	But indeed are they of much less sharpness than two blades.</start_of_turn
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	For if they are acute, like two blades, they are liable to cause both heat and burn the flesh: and they do not pass through the flesh with speed.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	For in these things there is somewhat of the size of the work, for the hold of the fire is kept in the work, and the flesh is quickly cut through: with this therefore the work is better in every work, and more gentle, and easier.</start_of_turn
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	And let there be space between the two knives equal to the length of a finger, after you have marked two points with the cautery: and remove both of them ignited upwards, until they reach the bone, and penetrate each other in two places: so that the distance between their extremities is elongated.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	For indeed they do not solidify with this inward cautery.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	This is the form of the cautery.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	Take care that the acute tears do not flow from the eyes excessively
Caput IIII.	Chapter III
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	When the tears are thick and flow excessively from the eyes, which are above the external part of the head, and do not cease from the eyes, and cause the face of the patient to be red, and he feels a walking sensation in front of him, like the walking of ants: and his eyes are wide, wet, because they are corroded by the tears: and the palpebrae are inflamed from the intensity of the tears: then the ancients disapproved of their treatment of these and named this treatment "Ense.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	And it is necessary to shave the hair in front of the patient's face
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	Then make three incisions on the forehead, equidistant from each other according to the length of the forehead: and let the length of the incision be like two fingers, and let one incision be equidistant from the length of the nose in the middle of the forehead, and the second according to the length of the lobes of the ears, and the third from the other side: and cauterize from the arteries which are in the two sides. And extend your hand from the continuation of the two mandibles, and let there be space between the incisions equal to the width of three joined fingers. And let there be prepared a sponge or dry cloth with which to soak up the blood
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	Then introduce the sponge-bag of two acute extremities, whose form follows.
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	From the incision from the temporal part up to the second incision: and scrape away the whole skin between the two incisions, with the sponge-bag containing the fat, which is above the bone.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	Then do the same from the middle incision up to the second incision.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	Then remove the sponge-bag and introduce another instrument, which is called the acute knife, through the first incision from one blunt side, not from the acute side
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form.
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	And fix its sharp edge towards the fleshy substance with the attached skin, and its blunt side towards the bone: and press it in until it reaches the middle incision; and cut through everything that descends from the head to the eyes: except that which appears on the skin
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	Then do the same in the middle incision up to the other incision
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	And when the bleeding has ceased, express from the clots the quantity of blood which has collected.
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	Then put on all the incisions a bandage of coarse cotton, and put over them soaked sponges in wine, and wax or vinegar.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	And take care that no swelling should arise.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	And on the third day loosen the ligament and give a large infusion with warm water.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	Then care for the wound from the basic ointment, and leave the rest of the wounds to heal: until they are healed
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	Regarding the care of acute tears and catarrh of the eyes from the inside of the head.
Caput V.	Chapter V.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	When acute carbuncles or abscesses occur on someone, and the eyes are swollen, small, and the face is pale: and the eyelashes are ulcerated, and hair falls out from the body, and there is sharp pain in the depth of the head, causing pain and sneezing: then take from these signs that the matter and carbuncles do not come from one source, except from many wounds.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	And the best treatment in this case is this.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	It is to scrape off the front of the head of the patient.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	Then make a single incision in the middle of the forehead, or on the other side along the breadth, and begin the incision from the left temple to the right temple: and extend the incision until you reach the bone: and pull your hand away from the edges of the wound, which move with chewing: until the bone is exposed: and you will drain all the blood with a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	Then separate between the two lips of the incision with pieces of cotton wool, or with strips of linen.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	Then tie up above with threads: and soak the threads with wine and oil, so that no swelling will occur.
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	And when you have finished this, and the swelling of the carbuncle has begun to subside: then it is necessary to massage the bone, until new flesh begins to form in it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	And then care for the patient with regular application of poultices which makes new flesh grow: such as if you take from wheat flour two parts, and from colophony four parts: and make from these an ointment, and apply it to the wounds
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	And concerning the care of the wound in the Golden Age.
Caput VI.	Chapter VI.
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	Every substance in gold descends, is of four kinds: either a mineral lapis, or like stone, such as iron; or is from a plant, such as cicer and beans; or is a flowing substance, such as water and vinegar, and like these. Or it is an animal.
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	When any substance descends into gold, either a lapis that does not coexist in the gold or that does not grow in it, it exposes the gold to the air: if the lapis is removed, something is distilled out of the gold that was previously dissolved or mixed with it
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	Then perform the extraction, and make it adhere firmly with conditions, and seal up the nostrils near the insertion of the plug, after you have placed around the circumference of the ear a barrier of cotton wool, or wool, and extended the gold upwards
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	Many things depart with such care.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	If they do not depart, then perform the extraction with vinegar, that is, subtile pins. Which are of this shape
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	If they depart with vinegar, it is good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	And if they do not depart, then perform the extraction with a blunt needle of small size.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	If they do not depart by that, then make a hole in the air, and insert the end of the tube into the ear many times, and seal up what is around the tube with wax mixed with oil, so that there is no air except the tube: then draw out with your hand with great force.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	Many things depart with that which we have said
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	If they do not depart in this way: take from barley or from vinegar, that is, prepared gluten, with which birds are caught, and put it in the extremity of the radius after you have enveloped over it the middle part well positioned: then insert it into the ear with ease, after you have dried the gold from moisture
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	If, therefore, it does not depart with all that we have said, then it is proper to split [the wound] before the callous swelling or spasm occurs.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	The method of splitting is as follows: like a phlebotomist I first prick the head of the patient, and from the blood I extract according to the measure of his virtue.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	Then I make the patient sit between my hands, and I support his head above, and I find the proper split at the root of the ear at the hollow place of the ear: and let the split be in the shape of a crescent, until you reach the stone: then remove it with the instrument.
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then withdraw the split with your hand at the time, and take care of the wound, until it heals.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	If anything falling from the ear is from a seed that grows and swells: then I direct the extraction of it
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	If it does not obey your order to come out, then grasp a small sponge, fine and subtle, according to this shape.
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	And manage with it the excision of that kind from the seeds that fall into the ear, and do not make it bleed when you think that it is already softened by the vapor of the ear, until you place the sponge firmly: then remove it with hooks or with fine graspers, or with suction, as we said, for its extraction alleviates it
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	When water enters the ear, the patient must sneeze at the beginning: and I put the ear to the bottom of some cotton wool: and it is lying over the ear in which the water is.
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	If it comes out through this, that is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	And if not: then grasp many stones, according to the length of a finger, tight, fine, and warm them with fire next to it, and let the patient put one of his ears into the ear: and I will sprinkle one foot of his with salt from this side, and I will strike with the other stone on the stone which is in the ear.
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	Until all the water has drained out, do not cease to do that with stone and stone.
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	When the water has drained out, take some charcoal or alum and insert one extremity into the fire: and bring the other extremity close to the fire until most of it is consumed by the flame.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	Then repeat the process with another piece of alum, and do this many times until all the water has drained out: and extract it with a needle as prescribed in the stone
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	In the extraction of an animal that is within the stone, such as a flea or anything like it, care for it as I have said in the explanation.
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	But if it is a large body that appears to the sense: then manage its extraction with the hands and needles: and it will be easier for all who hold it in the fire.
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	When the worms are generated in the fire, when you have cared for them as we have said in the explanation of distillation, and in the treatise on distillations, and your care has not availed: then it is necessary to uncover the fire.
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	If anything appears there from the worms: then extract it with the hands or with fine needles.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	If nothing appears there: take a needle whose shape is like this, narrow below and wide above: and insert the lower extremity into the fire according to the capacity of the sick person: then draw it out with that strong suction.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	Do this many times until all the worms have drained out.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	If they do not obey you to come out, then encircle the needle with lead, as I have said in the stone
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	If they do not depart with it as we have said: then perform distillations which the ancients are experts in in the handling of worms: and you will find this in the treatise on distillations.
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	And let your effusion be such as when you pour oil and medicines into the ear with this instrument whose form is depicted here
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	Like water, make it from silver or lead, lower it tightly, in which there is a small hole, wide above.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	Let the driving force which is in the curve of the tube be made of air centred
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	And if you wish, take a sphere, and put it at the end of the tube with a cover of cotton: then pour oil, or gum, or whatever you wish of these medicines into the tube: and let it be in the ear: then introduce the sphere with the cotton above, and press it with your hand cautiously, until the oil is driven into the curve of the ear, and the patient feels it inside: and whatever is poured into the ear will be warmed with fire immediately: and beware that nothing which is distilled is in the ear when it is cold: for medicines do not tolerate this.
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	Of the care of the accident of the ear.
Caput VII.	Chapter VII.</start_of_turn>
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	Whenever some children come out of the mothers' wombs unpierced.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	And sometimes it happens to some people that their ear is operated on in meat by a wound, or is born with a cleft in it
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	And this operation is sometimes done in the deep cavity of the ear, which does not follow custom: and sometimes it happens outside the cavity of the ear a little, and follows custom.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	Whatever happens in the depth of the ear, which the sight does not grasp, is difficult to heal in many arrangements.
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	It is necessary that you put the ear of the patient in the sun and gaze into it: then, if you see the apparent removal of hair, open the ear with a fine spatula, whose form is this which follows, so that its extremity is in that part which has a small breadth, and that some part of it is acute: and the rest of the spatula should be soft on both sides, so that it does not harm the ear
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	If, therefore, the hair is of the nature of that which grows in the flesh of the ear: then hold the ear with a fine hook, and cut through it with ease until the whole flesh is removed.</start_of_turn>
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	If the hair is in the depth of the ear: then grasp a thin, soft stick, and warm it with fire: then insert it into the ear.</start_of_turn>
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	If you sense hair with this, which the patient has with great suffering of hearing, try to open it with ease: and be careful, lest you injure the nerves of the ear.</start_of_turn>
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	Then put in the ear a plaster according to the quantity of the breadth of the hole which you have made in the unguent of Egypt: do this for a few days, until you are secure of the consolidation of the wound.</start_of_turn>
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	Or take plaster, and mix it with rose water, and sprinkle upon it powdered gypsum, and use it.</start_of_turn
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	If you see the ear already blackened: then you must extract the plaster, and allow it to be covered with another plaster, which you mix with powdered gypsum, which is made with rose water, until the swelling has subsided: then care for it until it is healed.</start_of_turn
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	If blood flow increases: then immerse a sponge, or pack the area with cold water, and place above it a bandage: and employ the remaining treatment which separates the blood flow as described in the treatise on distillation.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	On the care of the eyelids.
Caput VIII.	Chapter VIII.
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	These Altheli which happen in the eyelids are either wet or dry
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	It is necessary therefore to keep the edges moist with tears or with an ointment: or with a single [ointment] and remove them with a sponge from their roots
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	Then place over the place a soft cheese
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	If blood flows from the eye, then cauterize the blood vessel with a fine lancet.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	And the cauterization is better after the incision
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	Many of them return when something remains from their roots
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	And when cauterized with fire, those roots are burnt and do not return
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	On the care of the great eyelid of the eye
Caput IX.	Chapter IX
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	Many things happen in the eyelids something which assimilates the Crandinum in its hardness and its toughness, and because of this it is called the Great one: and it is an accumulation of thick moisture in the upper and lower eyelids
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	The operation therefore is as follows: if there is a Great one proceeding from the eye, which appears from the eyelid and moves to every part, and its resolution is easy
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	Find therefore above the edge a fissure for the width.
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	Then cleanse the wound from all sides with ease, until it is satisfied.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	Then suspend the wound with one thread, and cut it off.</start_of_turn>
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	If indeed it is not prepared for cutting, except after you have pierced the lid with a small incision, then it will harm the patient in some way.</start_of_turn>
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	If the wound is large: then gather it together with sutures: and care for it until it heals.</start_of_turn
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	And if it is small, it will not cause you any harm.</start_of_turn
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	The ointment will restore it and make the wound flexible.</start_of_turn
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	And if it is great and extends downwards towards the inner parts of the ear towards the surface inwards: then pierce the lid and suspend the large blood vessel with one thread: except that you will not need an incision, and press the wound from all sides.</start_of_turn
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	And if the lid is elongated by the incision, it will not cause any harm.</start_of_turn
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	Then wash the eye from the incision of the great vessel with salt water: and care for the place with it that is flexible, until the patient is healed.</start_of_turn
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	On the care of the eyelashes.</start_of_turn
Caput X.	Chapter X.</start_of_turn>
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	The eyelash is a gland that is generated in the upper eyelid: and mostly it happens to children: and it weighs down their eyes, and causes them to shed tears in the mornings, and they cannot see the sunlight because of this, because the tears run down their faces always, and over their eyes while they sleep, and their eyelashes are always wet under their eyebrows because of the swelling: and the prominence of the eyelash is seen in the eye, and when you touch the place with your fingers, you feel the eyelash between your fingers.</start_of_turn
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And thus is the manner of his operation, that he place the patient's head in your lap.
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	Then grasp a towel, and prepare it in such a way that you make from it a circle according to the quantity that contains Axirnath from all sides
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	Then place him upon the [incision], and press with your fingers from all sides, so that Axirnath is gathered in the middle of the circle
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	Then find in the middle thereof moisture with a sponge, and do not make a wound wider than that which is made in phlebotomy in depth.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	Or it is necessary that you find the whole skin, until you reach Axirnath in many positions, because Axirnath comes out of the wound according to the shape of the white pith of barley.
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	Extract therefore the said towel which you have infiltrated between your fingers outwards: and you will move your hand to the right and left, until it is scattered: and take care, lest you add to the wound, that you do not reach the eye with the sponge, and stain it
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	But if indeed Axirnath does not appear at the beginning of the wound, you will add a little to the wound with ease, until Axirnath comes out.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	Then extract the said towel, as we have said.
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	Then soak the towel in vinegar and water, and place it over the place, and bind it with wool threads.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	And from men there are some who anoint salt, and place it in the hollow of the wound, so that the remainder of the moisture may liquefy.
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	But if there arises in the place of the after-boil a thick pus, then care for it with soothing poultices, until it heals.
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	Regarding the methods of treating the eye when the eyelids are softened, so that the eye does not bulge excessively.
Caput XI.	Regarding the methods of treating the eye when the eyelids are softened, so that the eye does not bulge excessively.
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	When additional hairs grow in the eyelids surrounding the eye, and when they are excessive: then they harm the eye, and cause the methods of treatment to fail, such as excessive tears, softening of the eyelids, and inflammation, until such time as the cause of the eye's destruction is eliminated.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	And Ataxmir of the eye is cured according to four methods.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	Or by cautery with fire.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	Or with acute medicine, as is mentioned previously in the chapter on cautery
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	Or by incision and suture
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	Or by cautery, as I shall say
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	It is necessary to place the head of the patient on your knee
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	Then grasp the lower eyelid of the eye with your left hand
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	If it turns easily, that is good.
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	And if not: insert the needle through the fold of the lower eyelid, where the hair is, and pass the needle with the thread close to the base of the hair, and draw the thread up to the upper eyelid with the eyelid, and join the needle to the surrounding tissue.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	Then find inside the eyelid under the added hair a space corresponding to the greater and lesser tears
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	Then draw out the thread and put under the eyelid a small piece of cotton or gauze: then sign over the eye with cautery, so that it looks like the figure of a myrtle leaf
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	The wound must be properly closed, so that it forms a figure according to the quantity and elevation of the eyelid: for it is altered in different people.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	The wound must be properly closed, so that it forms a figure according to the quantity of the eyelid and the elevation of the border: for it is altered in different people.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	When the suture has been found over two lines which you have marked, and you have commenced from the greater lacrimal gland up to the lesser, and there is one opening near the natural hair, as is the thickness of a radius.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	Then introduce the needle through one of the two angles of the skin.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	Then remove the whole.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	Then gather together with the suture two lips, with a needle and a thin thread: and stop the bleeding, and make fast that which is superabundant from the threads over two superciliums, with some useful substance, if you wish to do so: or if not, do not worry about it.
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	Then remove the suture and the thread for three days, or four: afterwards care for it.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	And if you wish, remove the wound without suture, and care for it, which will dry up and contract
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	For the eyelid is elevated at the sealing of the wound and the gathering of its parts: but the future is better.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	This is the way which the old men of Atarax taught to cure it.
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	There is great solicitude over the sick man, and it comes from a good operation, and there is no fear in it.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	And another way is in Atarax: and it is that the sign on the eyelid should be like the figure of a myrtle leaf, as we have said.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	Then lift the eyelid with three separate hooks, or aggregated, according to the form which follows, and then cut away what is superfluous with small scissors, according to the same form, with equal incision.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	If, however, it is not possible to hold the hook, and it does not equal: then grasp the point where the thread lies and introduce it into the middle of the figure: and introduce another thread near the greater lacrimal, and another near the smaller lacrimal: and gather together the threads between your fingers with equality
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	Then lift your hand for elevation equally: and lift the skin above that which is signed with the mark of the limb, as we have said.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then gather together the two lips of the wound with suture: and care for it until it is healed.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	If, however, swelling should arise at the incision or wound: stop that swelling with powder, and with similar things, from the sponges which are sitting.
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	And when the eyelids are also swollen, as their hair is converted.
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	It is necessary therefore that you use what we said concerning the incision: but the suture of both is artificial
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	Concerning the care of Ataxmir with dogs.
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	And it is, that you cover the eyelid, and split the wound which is inside, according to what I have said.
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	Then make two incisions, or two small sticks underneath: whose length is according to the length of the eyelid, and the width of them is less than the width of the pupil: and I put in the stitches at the extremities from both parts where you have the thread
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	Then gather together both things with slightness over that which is superfluous from the eyeball, and string two threads from both parts tightly, and let go of them every few days
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	The skin, when tightly closed, will die, darken, and putrefy until it falls away by itself.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	If delayed, then cut it open with scissors.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.</start_of_turn>
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	When it has consolidated, elevate the eyelid: and do not pierce the hair.</start_of_turn
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	And this is the form of two incisions which you make according to this figure and their quantity in length and breadth.</start_of_turn
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	Regarding the elevation of hairy punctures in the eye with a needle.</start_of_turn
Caput XII.	Chapter XII.</start_of_turn>
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	The operation in this case is to take a fine needle and introduce it under the silk thread, which is soft.</start_of_turn
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	Then join the ends together, and make knots at each end with a fine loop: and let the length of the thread be equal to one palm.</start_of_turn
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	Then make another fine loop of thread under this one in a short space, and knot the ends if you wish.</start_of_turn
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	Then put the patient's head on your lap, and let it be near the heel so that the operation is visible: because it is a slight operation, or even a minute.</start_of_turn
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	Then insert the needle with the loop at the root of the eyelid, and make it penetrate the eyelid quickly, until you have pulled out the natural hair.</start_of_turn
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	Then pull out the hair until above the loop: and insert into the loop the tip of the hair: if there is one, or two, or three, not more.</start_of_turn
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	Then draw your hand with that which is towards the elbow, until the hair escapes with its root adhering to the eyelashes with the natural hair.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	Then draw your hand with that which is towards the elbow, until the hair escapes with its root adhering to the eyelashes with the natural hair.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	If the hair is short, then either associate it with a long hair from the natural hair and elevate it with that: or dismiss it and let it grow out again, and then elevate it.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	Concerning the care of the eyelash which occurs in the upper eyelid.
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII.
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	When this happens to the eye, it is called a Leporina.
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	This eyelash is either natural or accidental
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	Accidental, therefore, is from the consolidation of a wound, or section, or cautery, and things like these
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	And the method of operation in this is that you find the consolidation and separate its lips, and put between them a bit of lint from linen, and bind it, until it is healed
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	And do not use in the treatment anything which excites and contracts: for if you do, the eyelash will deteriorate more than before: rather use those things which soften, such as barley flour: and embroil with water, in which be dissolved aloes, poppy seeds: and oil of almond, which is liquefied with some oil: and mix with this lint, and care with this.
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	Your store of remedies is, that you may be prepared with every ingenuity, that it may not be shaken, following the form which was in the first place.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	This operation, as we have said, is not without some rectification of the Alxatrati, that it may not return to its former shape altogether
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	Regarding the care of the Alxatrati which is in the lower eyelid, and is a swelling or contraction above to the right and left.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter 123.
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	This swelling of the Alxatrati which is in the lower eyelid, is what is truly called the Alxatrati.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	And it is natural, and is accidental.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	And it is accidental from a wound, or a tear, or a burn, and such like things.
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	And the way of operating in this is that you take a needle, in which there is a doubled thread, and you pass it under the meat, and make it penetrate from the left lacrimal gland up to the right lacrimal gland, until the thread reaches the two extremities of the meat.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	Then stretch the meat upwards with the needle, and cut the vein with a wide blade
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	If, therefore, the figure of the eyelid returns to its former state as it should be, that is good
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	And if not, grasp the edge, and put it into the wound, and close it with it: and find two incisions on the inner side of the eyelid, and let the extremities of the two incisions go from two angles of the incision, until they meet and form an angle: until when they meet they form the figure of the two letters together, which is the Greek letter lambda
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	And then remove that piece of meat by as much as the width of its acute lower end, from that which follows the eyelid
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	Then gather the separated parts: such as with a thread of wool.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	Then care for them as we have said, with soothing medications, and ointments, until they are healed.</start_of_turn>
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	And if the Alexatrati occurs from a wound, and the suture, or cautery: then it is necessary that you find the wound flat under the eyelashes, even as before.</start_of_turn
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	Then separate between two lips with ointment, as we have said.</start_of_turn
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	And the sum of the sermon about the care of the Alexatrati, when it is above, or below, is that you should care for it in that operation, according to the form of the Alexatrati.</start_of_turn>
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	For itself, there are many variations in form: and the prudent artist prepares the ingenuity in any way that is possible for it, until it returns to its natural form, or almost so, and the patient himself, according to what suits him from the operation and the instruments in many arrangements.</start_of_turn>
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	About the adhesion of the eyelashes to the conjunctiva, or the cornea.</start_of_turn
Caput XV.	Chapter XV.</start_of_turn
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	When this consolidation happens to many people, it is like the upper eyelid to stick to the white of the eye, and to prevent it from doing its natural operations.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	Therefore you must introduce the edge of the radius under the eyelid, and raise it upwards: or extend it with a needle: then cut the adhesion with a fine sponge, which is not with the sharpness of the knife, but rather blunt, so that it does not irritate the patient during the operation, and that it does not move the eye from its natural position: and that the incision be like that which you would make to scratch that adhesion with ease, until when the eyelid returns to its natural form, and the adhesion is completely healed.</start_of_turn
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	Pour water into the eye, while the water washes it out: or distill it into it from a vessel made of lead, from vinegar dissolved in water.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	Then separate between the eyelid and the eye with a strip of linen: and place above the eye wool infused with alum or gypsum: and after three days use the vessel, and with the solidarities, until the eye is healed.
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	Regarding the incision of the nail and the prominence of the carnis lachrymarum.
Caput XVI.	Chapter XVI.
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	You know that the nail exists in two ways.
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	It is nervous: and is similar to hard sand, thin.
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	Or it is not nervous, similar to frozen white moisture: which when it touches iron, or you try to grasp it with a hook, it breaks, and does not remain in the nail
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	Both of these species do not begin, except for the greater lacrimal gland, until it has gone slowly, until it covers the whole area, and hinders the light, and the movement of the eye
