Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	If you do not understand how to proceed, repeat the medicine: and after cauterization, remove the surrounding parts of the vein with the thumb and bathe in butter, and mix with that which is in the vicinity of the medicine: and bind with cold water.
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	And care for the outside with bandages, and for the inside with gargles, until the patient is healed.
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	Thus is this kind of treatment better than an incision and is longer lasting in fear of infection.
Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	And when the vein is healed even with the gentler methods than cautery and incision: it is healed by fumigation, according to this manner.
Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	Take calamine, and hyssop, and origanum, and rue, and sassafras, and chamomile, and angelica, and similar herbs: and mix these all together, or some of them in a pot, and immerse with vinegar, and let them boil: and the pot should be covered with a lid: and there should be a hole in the middle of the pot, above which the instrument is composed according to this manner.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	Let air or silver issue forth; and let the extremity be introduced into that which contains the pomegranate, until the vapor ascends to the upper opening of the cannula, until the opening becomes much obscured.
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	Then repeat over the surface many times, until it boils over.
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	Take heed, do not perform this treatment at the beginning of an attack of inflammation.
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	Let there be added some plaster in the inflammation: and it is not permitted to do this except when the inflammation has subsided
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	If therefore this instrument is not present, then take a tube and fill its extremity with cork or pith: so that the bone of the sick does not burn: for the pith of cork hinders the vapor from burning the bone: and this is an excellent treatment with health.
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	Of the extraction of thorns, and bones from the gullet.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter XXXVIII.
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	Many thorns of fish bones or other things adhere to the gut
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	It is necessary therefore to extract what is apparent on the surface of that which has fallen down, after having passed the tongue with the instrument at the root, and it is declared to be in the gut
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	And what is not apparent to you and is hidden in the gut, you must make the sick person vomit before the food is digested in the stomach
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	Perhaps therefore the thing which is annexed will come out with the vomit.
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	Or the sick person may swallow down a piece of dates, or the root of lettuce, or swallow down a dry breadcrumb: or take up a dry sponge of sea-moss: and bind it up in a thread, then swallow it down
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	When the limb approaches the place where spines or bones are extracted, it is then withdrawn.
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	If it does not withdraw when pulled as we have said: then use a lead instrument according to this shape.
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	Let it be thicker than a radius small, and have a curvature at its extremity, which intrudes into its gut with ease: and let it have its head elevated above itself.
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	Beware of its touch of its epiglottis, that it does not cause it to cough, and drive with it bone, spine, or let the physician himself introduce it with his hand
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	Truly that the patient intrudes it is better: because of his science of the place of the annexed thing: and drives downwards, or pulls his hand with the instrument upwards, the whole of this according to the quantity that is prepared for it, until it comes out
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	Of the extraction of bloodletting
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter XXXIX.
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When bloodletting is medicated with what I have said in the treatise on curing with the physicians, and it does not help, then consider in the belly of the patient before the sole, or behind the tongue after having moved the tongue with the instrument which I mentioned.
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If your hand should slip from the bloodletting, extract it with a small hook, or with fine fingers from the middle.
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	If this is not possible with these: then take a curved needle, and introduce it into the belly of the patient up to the gut: then introduce the burning iron into the curve of the needle.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Do this several times: and let the patient abstain from all water throughout the day
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then he shall take a full measure of cold water and open the mouth of the [patient] over it: and he shall gather his jaw with it, and shall not swallow anything from it: and he shall drink the water an hour after the other with his hand.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	The blood-sucker will feel the water falling from his lip.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	If, however, he does not depart from this as we have said, then he must suffocate the patient with sponges or with a tube as with the cannula of the nose or the ear
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do this often, for it is falling from him.
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	And the mode of operation in suffocation is that you take all the urine which is in the bladder with fire: and the vessels be covered with a covering, in the middle of which is a hole: and make an incision in that hole the extremity of the instrument
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then he will expel the suffocation, and place the patient's jaw in the extremity of the cannula, and clamp his jaw, so that it does not depart from the suffocation, until you know that the suffocation has passed to the blood-sucker
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For the blood-sucker is immediately falling from him.
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	If it does not fall, do the suffocation often again
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And the patient will tolerate sitting, and will eat garlic and onions, and will not drink water.
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	It is necessary therefore that he depart from this regimen.
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	And this is the form of the instrument with which the blood-sucker is extracted from the gut when it falls upon the urine.
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It is like tweezers, like urine: except that it has that curvature which enters the gut
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And its extremity is like that of an owl's wing which is called the ciconia, in which there is harshness of the lime: when it grasps something, it does not relinquish it entirely.
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	And concerning the opening of abscesses, their section, and their care in general.
Caput XL.	Chapter 40.
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	There are many kinds of abscesses, of various degrees, according as the nature of the pain remembered: for some there is one cause, for others two in this book. They are diverse in their perforation and their sections are of two kinds.
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	One of them is the kind of abscess which arises from moisture.
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	The other is due to the place where it occurs in the body
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	Because an abscess occurring in the head is different from one occurring in the foot: and an abscess occurring in a fleshy part is different from one occurring in a joint. And each one of them has its own judgement according to its operation
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	And there are abscesses which do not require perforation, except after the ripening of health in the flesh, and the completion of its action: and there are those which require perforation while they are raw and have not ripened according to their completion.
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	Like abscesses which are close to joints.
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	For an abscess which occurs near a joint and which persists, until it putrefies, that is to say, when the surrounding parts are perhaps corrupted, the ligaments or nerves of that joint may be ruptured. And this is the cause of the closer contraction of that limb
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	Or an abscess near a main limb: for if you delay its perforation until it ripens, the bone may break or become deformed, or the limb itself will be spoiled
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	If it is close to a bone, perforate it immediately: it does not matter if the abscess is incomplete, except that it be close to the bone, lest it putrefy deeply and reach the intestines, and form a fistula, or remain unhealed at its end.
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	It is necessary that you know the time of perforation of the abscess, which is according to the maturity of the lesion: and it is among the relaxation of pain, recession of fever, decrease of redness, pulse, and severity of the headache of the abscess: and the other signs.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	It is necessary that you make the perforation in the lower part of the abscess, and immediately above the apex: and let the perforation be wide in the length of the body, if the abscesses are in the parts of the hands and feet, and in the places of lacerations, and strings, and nerves, and arteries, and finally in all the places equally, where there is no reflection
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	In these, however, which reflect, act with the perforation according to that limb.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	When indeed the abscess is in the parts of carnis: then it is better that you delay the perforation of it, until its digestion is confirmed, as we said according to the maturity of the lesion.
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	Because if you perforate it before that, you prolong the course of the infection, and there is much pus and dirt, and perhaps the edges of the wound will adhere to each other, and its depth.
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	And some abscesses are perforated throughout the body according to necessity: or according to that which is necessary for the limb.
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	And it is necessary that you administer in small abscesses a moderate perforation, and in large abscesses a wide perforation: or multiple sections according to the similarity of the size of the abscesses.
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	There are also from the apostemata, in which it is necessary that the skin should be concaved: and it happens when it has been made like a cloth, and has been made at the end, when it is dead: as it happens with many things, as with a dubelet and a bubon.
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And there are also those which are cut with a section having three angles.
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	And there are also those which are cut like the figure of a myrtle leaf
Sicut apostema inguinum.	Like the inguinal apostema.
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And there are also those in which a round section and a lunar section are administered: and similar things from sections
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	This, however, which has no head, like the superficial leninous apostemata, must be perforated through a superficial perforation, or only with a plane cutting tool
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	And it must be performed when the apostema is thick, and when it has collected much blood, and you must perforate it so that you do not tear and extract all the pus at once: rather extract from it part of it
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then anoint the apostema until another day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then extract some of the pus again.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Do this many times according to the degree, until it has gone: especially if the patient is feeble in spirit, or a woman in childbirth, or a young child, or an old man decrepit: for the spirit of the animal is dissolved from the animal with the evacuation of the blood: and perhaps the patient dies, and you do not perceive it
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Therefore take heed of this chapter, for it contains great caution
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	And after you have perforated the apostema, which you must perforate, you must remove the clot: and consider carefully
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	If there is a small abscess of the apostematis, either perform a plane section or administer a dose of laudanum or coto from an old container.
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	If the abscess is large and there are many holes in the perforation, it is necessary to introduce medicine into every hole until the bleeding stops
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	If you have excised a piece of skin from the abscess, or if you have cauterized the circumference: then you must apply an old coto, or as when a cloth is taken away, or sprinkle with lint without moisture: and bind it tightly until the third day.
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then remove it, and care for it with oil until it is healed
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	If, however, blood flow occurs in your operation at the hour, then administer cold water and vinegar, after they have been drunk on a piece of cloth: and put it over the place of the blood flow many times over
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	If the bleeding persists, then you must administer regimen, care, and powders, which I have mentioned in many places of this book, and from experience.
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	If it is in the winter, and the place of the abscess is of many nerves: then you must infuse sponges with wine and warm oil: and put them on the place.
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	If it is in the summer, and the place is fleshy: then you must put sponges soaked in water, or oil, or both with wine and oil, and keep it cold.
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	Until then, as we have said, on the third day you must drain the abscess, evacuate it, and administer treatment that suits it, until it is healed.
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This is what is necessary for the knowledge of the treatment of abscesses in general
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	According to the sequence of positions, concerning the difference, as I have already said concerning all apostamata, how it is possible to treat it singly.
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	Concerning the section of the apostomas that occur in the head
Caput XLI.	Concerning the section of the apostomas that occur in the head
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	The small apostomas that occur in the head are of the kind of nodules, which contain sacs, like the houses of hens.
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	And their kind is many.
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	Some are fat: and some contain moisture like slime: and some contain moisture like blood clots: and some are like stones
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And in the section of all of them, and in their extraction, there is no fear, as long as it does not touch the artery during the section
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	And the operation in the section of these is, as you will experience with the instrument which comes after this, which is called the Intromissum, until you know what it contains
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	For if it contains moisture, then dry it out with the superficial section: in this form.
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	Begin with the incision from point b to point g. When the moisture has been evacuated, remove the sac which contains it, and do not leave anything behind
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	There is much risk of infection if anything is left behind
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then immerse the wound in Egyptian unguent, if it is there: and if not, in water and salt: and apply with oil, and remove it on the next day.
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	The oil will dissolve what remains of the sac
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then repeat over the said heel with the second and third fingers, and if you find it still painful, do not trust that it will not recover from the swelling, then take oil and unguent, until it is healed.
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	If the swelling contains a knot of fat: then dry it again in this fashion, by cutting it through in the shape of a cross: and project the nails between the two lobes of the cut, and scour it from every part: and try your skill in extracting the membrane which contains it
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	If, however, it opposes you, the artery: then do that which I shall tell you afterwards.
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	And similarly do in a swelling which is bony, by cutting through and curing in the same way as we have said before.
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	And the cutting through of a bony swelling is easier: because there is little blood and moisture.
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And whenever there are some hours of swelling which are in the head in some men, when there is no moisture in them.
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	Because I have seen over swelling in a woman's head, and I found the swelling like a solid stone, hard, rough, white, which could not be broken: and if it was pierced with anything, it would burst open
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	In other swellings which happen in the head, except for those which happen in the heads of children, and near the roots of the ears, the cutting should be superficial.
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	Or make the perforation always from below upwards, so as to preserve the course of the healing towards the lower parts.
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then care for it with that which is suitable for it
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	(The provided text does not include any information regarding the section of the thyroid in the neck, so I cannot translate that portion of the sentence.)
Caput XLII.	Head Chapter 42.
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	Many wounds occur in the jaw, under the armpits, and in the groin: and sometimes in other parts of the body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And above all that occurs from these wounds in the jaw are one, and many: and they are generated from the inside: and every swelling from these wounds is within its own sheath, as in the nodes and the head wounds which we have mentioned
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	There are many kinds of swellings
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	And from these things are fatty swellings: and those which contain humors: and malignant swellings which do not obey treatment
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	When, therefore, a good humoral liquid appears in the touch, which is evidenced by its proximity to the color of the skin, and which moves to every part and is not connected with the nerves of the jaw, nor with the veins, nor with the arteries, nor is it deep: it must be excised by a superficial incision from the upper part to the lower part of the body from the line A to the line G, and the surrounding skin should be stripped away from all sides: and two lips of skin should be spread out with one or with several sutures, if necessary, as we have said in the head wounds, and the contents should be gradually extracted
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	It is important to take care not to injure the bone or the nerve.
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	And let the incision not be acute, but rather wide: so that it does not bring your hand near the incision, or cause the patient pain, and you will cut only what is necessary.
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	If, however, you cut the bone, or the artery, or if you are forbidden from the operation, then put in the wound some sponge which absorbs blood, or some powder which sheds blood, and tie the wound and leave it until the swelling subsides: or begin to putrefy it
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	The blood is severed by the ligature and hangs ready for the operation until you complete it.
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then inquire with your finger as to whether anything remains of the small trophlets: if so, cut them off and wash them away.</start_of_turn>
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	If there is in the root of the trophlet a large vessel: then it is necessary that you do not cut off the latter from its root: but rather that you ligate it with a strong doubled thread, and let it go until it falls off of itself without any nourishment.</start_of_turn>
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then make a hole in the heel of the thigh, which you have immersed in Egyptian unguent.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum.	Then take care of yourself.</start_of_turn
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	If the whole trophlet is cut, then it is necessary that you gather the two lips of the wound: and hold them fast, after which you must wash because there remains no excess.</start_of_turn
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	If however you wash and find that there remains excess because of the size of the trophlet, then it is necessary that you bring an incision to the root of the latter and extract it: and administer the suture as we have said.</start_of_turn
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And whatever remains of the trophlets should be perforated with a superficial perforation: so that you may see the seat of its maturity: and put the perforation below that which follows from the lower part of the body as we have said.</start_of_turn
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then administer after the perforation some lint with unguent, and like that, so that it consumes what remains of the corruption, until when you wash the wound is seen to be healed: then take care of yourself with the unguent of generation of flesh until it is healed.</start_of_turn
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	As for the excision of the epiglottis from the epiglottis to the gut: this happens by chance.</start_of_turn
Caput XLIII.	Head Chapter XLIII.
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	They say that the ancients did this section in the epiglottis, and they did not know of anyone on our land who had done it: and this is the writing of their words.
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	But in the case of haemophilus, the surgeon must perform a section of the epiglottis: for if it is not done, there will be no remedy for it: because all the veins and the lung are weakened
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	In those who have a callous swelling in the mouth, or the gullet, or the two tonsils, when there is no inflammation in the canal, the surgeon must perform a section of the epiglottis in order to escape the destruction that comes from their prolapse.
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	It must therefore be performed when we wish to do so, that we cut the epiglottis under three circles of the epiglottis, or four, with a small section through the width, in the place where there is between two circles the quantity which is the section of the cartilage, not in the cartilage itself: and this is the convenient place for the section, because it is bare of flesh, and the blood vessels from it are long.
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	If the surgeon is timid, then it must be extended with the tongue
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then find the skin until it reaches the canal: there will be blood vessels if there is anything there.
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then cut the cartilage as we have said: and it is signified above the section of the canal by the phlegm that comes out of it, with that which is broken, and the cutting of the vessel.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And withdraw the wound open at some time
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	When the time has passed in which the prolapse takes place, gather together the two lips of the wound with the skin only, without the cartilage
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then administer the medicines which make the flesh grow until healing is complete.
Inquit Albucasis.	Albucasis wrote: Then administer the medicines which make the flesh grow until healing is complete.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	The sum of this sermon which we have narrated is this: an exposed wound cannot be closed until the inflammation has subsided; for when the wound is closed while the inflammation still persists, the patient will die. Therefore it is necessary to leave the wound open until the inflammation has vanished, which is about three days. Then the wound can be closed.</start_of_turn>
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And this which I have heard from myself is that a maidservant once took a knife and put it into her own gut, and it pierced a part of the windpipe.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	I was called to care for her, and I found her already dead, just like a corpse.</start_of_turn>
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	I saw that the wound had been opened, and blood had flowed out of it from the little finger.</start_of_turn
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	I am confident that she would not have died if she had not been abandoned: neither did she guide herself. The wind was coming out of the wound.</start_of_turn
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	I treated her, and closed the wound, and cared for her until she was healed: and the maidservant did nothing else but groan in the water. She recovered after a few days.</start_of_turn
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	Therefore it is clear that there is no fear in the section of the epiglottis.</start_of_turn>
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	About the section of the hernia of the gut.</start_of_turn>
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter XLIV.</start_of_turn>
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This hernia of the gutturis is named after the hernia of the gutturis, and is a great hernia, according to the colour of the body: and it is much in women.
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	It is according to two modes: or it is natural: or it is accidental
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	In the natural mode there is no ingenuity
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	Accidental it is according to two modes: one of which is like a swelling of fat.
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	The other mode is like a hernia which arises from a knot of an artery
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And in this there is fear, and it does not behoove that presumption should be made towards it with the hand, except in the case where it is small: and you must prove it, and investigate it with the intestines.
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	If therefore you find it like a swelling of fat, and it is not suspected with any other swelling: then dry it up like swellings are dried up: and extract it with the thing which contains it from the bag, if it is in a bag: and if not, then investigate all of it
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the place with it which should be cured until it is healed
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	Of the cutting above the species of swellings.
Caput XLV.	Chapter XLV.</start_of_turn>
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many species of swellings, and I have mentioned all the species of them in their order: and it is necessary that I tell you the difference between the Node and the Extrude: in case of doubt
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	I say therefore, that when the Extrude is cold, and without fever, and without pain which excites, until the ebullition of the superfluous has ceased, and the putrefaction is completed: then indeed the fever and heat cease
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	When the Node however is not cold, neither feverish, neither painful, and contains its own bag, which is its own sac, and is according to the colour of the body: and is like a cicer, and makes like a batter, and is greater and less.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	There are two kinds: either fat [tissue] or containing moisture.
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	The colours of moisture are many, as I have said in the previous discourse
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	It is necessary therefore, when you are dealing with the Node, to experiment with it and inquire about its character at the outset using the instrument called the Intromissum, as its form will be shown in the following chapter.
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	The way to inquire about the posterior parts and the Nodes in general is to take hold of this instrument and introduce it into the moist place which you find in the posterior region: then gradually withdraw your fingers until you know that the instrument has penetrated the skin
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then lastly touch the hand according to the measure of the size of the posterior region
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Then withdraw the Intromissum and consider what comes out of its wound
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If therefore moisture runs out, whatever its colour may be: then dry it out with a superficial section, as I have said in the other chapters concerning the posterior region.
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	If it does not run out, then you know that it is fat: dry it out therefore with a section having the shape of a cross, as it has been shown to you: and suspend it with sutures, and scrape the skin from all sides with ease: and hold the tissue firm if necessary, until you have extracted the Node safely.</start_of_turn>
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	If, however, the bag is burst during the operation, and it is not possible to extract the Node whole, much the same happens in this case: then extract the latter with forceps, until nothing remains of it.
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	For if anything remains of it, little or much, the Node returns most frequently.</start_of_turn>
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	If it swells and remains so slightly: then let you insert a thorn into the completion of your work, with some corrosive powders of sharp points: and bind the thorn, and place above it that which sits upon the cold heel, and care for it along with the rest of the treatment, until it is healed.
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	If there is a large node, then split its two lips and care for it with that which is contained within it
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	If, however, there is a contrary swelling which is not pulsating, or which is pulsating: then clean the area thoroughly, and insert a splinter of wood into the place of the bite, and keep it tight for two or three days, until the thorn has rotted and the boiling of the blood has ceased: and then return to the incision which remains of the node.
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	Of the instruments outside which are for incision and perforation
Caput XLVI.	Chapter 46.
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	From these are the forms of the instruments which are introduced, and there are three sorts of them.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	From these again are the great, the medium, and the small
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	Let them be of iron, square at the extremities and hollow in the middle, that they may hasten the entrance into the heel
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	And these are the forms of the instruments of experience, and no, that is, perforating: and one of them is called a beris, that is, a piercer, and there are three sorts of them
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	From these again are the great, the medium, and the small
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	They join, that they may be investigated through the heel, and the exit, and the fistula, and the bubble from that which is between the bones
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	And others are round, triangular, blunt, like a great needle which has under it nails, of citrine, or of brass, or of iron, or of silver.
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	And the better things are those that come from the citron.
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	And experience is also obtained from black lead, which joins with these [instruments] so that through them one may experience fistulas, whose cavities reflect like lenity itself with those reflections.
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	There are three things that are of three kinds
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	For indeed from these three things are things long, things medium, and things short, according to the quantity of the breadth of the fistula and the stricture of it
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	The form of the needles, and there are many kinds of them
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	For indeed from these three things are things simple, namely those which have a single curve: and there are three kinds of them like liquids, great, medium, and small.
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	And from these three things are blind neighbours: and there are three kinds of them
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	And from these three things are needles having two curves, and there are three kinds of them: and from these three things are needles having three curves, and there are three kinds of them: and all of these are necessary in their place
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	And these are the forms of scalpels, which cut and scrape nodes and excoriate: and there are three kinds of them: for indeed from these three things are great, medium, and small.
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	Their extremities which make the cut are acute, and the other extremities are not acute: and they are not placed thus, except when there is a deliberate intention for excision of nodes near the fear of the cutting edge of the vein, or the nerve: and in order that the patient may recover more easily from the pain than from the excision of the abscess
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	These are magdas, and there are three kinds of them
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	The air is their origin, and they are like radium, as with which wine is made: and at their wide end is a hidden Spatumilis point: and within it runs inwards and outwards as desired, like liquids.
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	The Spatumili form which go between the fingers at the perforation of the apostematum: they are not perceived by the patient: and there are three kinds, great, medium, and small
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	The bubbles of the wind when they break up the flow of blood: and there are three kinds, great, medium, and small.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	They are from the air, or from citron, round, to a short length, like liquids: and they are solid.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And it is necessary that these kinds of bubbles should be great and small among you: so that you can break up blood quickly when necessary, and then when there is no physician present
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	But do not use these substances to break up blood in any part of the body, and do not use them except in carbuncles: such as wounds of the thigh, hip, wounds of the forearm and breasts, and of the belly, groin, and similar carbuncles, humors
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	And sometimes they are formed from other small things like fragments of sponges, resembling cork: which break up the blood when it flows out from the place of phlebotomy, or at the incision of the vein, or artery: and sometimes they are formed from round things in this form.
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	As for the care of the breasts of women who are breastfeeding.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter XLVII.
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	When the breasts of some men swell because of sleep (that is, when they begin to become soiled during sleep) until they resemble the breasts of women: and they remain with post-apoplectic swelling.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	Whoever dislikes that [thing], it is necessary that he cut across the breast [area] with a lunar section, according to this shape from the line, b. to the line, g. Then he should remove the whole fat.
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Then he should apply a sponge soaked in medicine to the wound
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then he should bring together two lips of the wound with sutures, and care for it until it is healed
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	If, however, the breast leans downwards and is softened by its size, as is the case with women: then it is necessary that two similar lunar sections be made in the two upper sides of the breast, each one containing the other at the ends as far as the greater line contains the smaller, according to this shape from the line, b. to the line, g. Then he should remove the skin which is between the two lips, and remove the fat, and administer what has been said concerning the sutures and powders, which is necessary for the cure, until it is healed
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	If, however, he does not wish to make the incision which is necessary, because of the patient’s anxiety or because of the flow of blood: then it is necessary that he apply a sponge soaked in corrosive unguent under the coat, and let it go, until that which remains of the fat has been corroded.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it is healed
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	As for the perforation of the apostem, which occurs under the nipple
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter XLVIII.
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These apostemas which occur under the nipple are of the kind of hard Stropharia, which contain vesicles, and from which are exuded humors.
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	These are exuded from the humors which contain the moisture, it is necessary that they be cut with a lunar section, according to this shape from the line b. to the line g. when all that is in the apostema is evacuated from the flesh, then apply a sponge to the surrounding area and let it go until the next day
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then the foot is lifted up, and is cared for with an unguent suitable for it, until it is healed.
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	If the swelling were from a kind of knot of the Strophulas, then it is to be cut above it, as we said in the section on the Strophulas which are equal
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	But if a swelling occurs in this way as to discharge pus, then in this case apply cautery to it, as we said before
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	As for the cutting of the swelling that occurs from the Artery and Vein.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter 49.</start_of_turn>
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When the Artery is ruptured, and the skin above it is consolidated, then much swelling immediately occurs from the swelling: and in the same way swelling also occurs in the Vein, as it does in the swelling and the inflation.</start_of_turn>
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	And the signs by which it is known that the swelling and inflation are from the Artery and Vein are: for when the swelling is from the Artery, it is long, aggregated in the depth of the body: and when the swelling of the hand is made by pressing upon the digits, you feel as if there is a constriction there.</start_of_turn
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And that which is from the Vein is rounded in the open part of the body.</start_of_turn>
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	And the cutting above this swelling is dangerous, and especially when it is under the armpits, and in the groin, and the throat, and in many other parts of the body: and it is a great danger.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	Therefore it is necessary to take care of it with fire, and that from iron also is in the extremities, or in the head, it is necessary to take care of it.</start_of_turn
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	Because of that which is from the iron is from the swelling of the orifice of the Artery, find in the cutting of the skin in the length.</start_of_turn
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the part with hooks, afterwards the Artery: and release the gut from the tunics, until it is severed.
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then insert the hook under it and make the gut penetrate until the other side, and ligate the Artery with two threads in two places, as you were taught in the extraction of two Arteries which are in the abdomen
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then bite the place which is between two ligatures with a sponge, until the blood which is in it comes out, and it is dissolved after the swelling has gone down.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then give treatment which causes pus to form, until the ligatures fall away: afterwards care for it with suitable unguents until it is healed.
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	If there should be swelling on account of the cutting of a Vein, then it is necessary to put in your hand what is possible from the swelling with the skin.
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then insert the hook under the place where you held your hand, and make the gut penetrate: and there put in two threads, until you draw it out from the other side.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then ligate with the gut itself the ligature with good thread: according to what I told you concerning the ligature of the vein, from two parts with two extremities of thread
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	If you fear that the thread will be pulled out, then insert another hook with another thread under the whole swelling at the incision of the needle: first, and ligate your thread in four places.
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then dry the swelling in the middle of it, until when it comes out what is in it: then cut off the excess of the skin, and discharge what is ligated from it.
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then put upon it a little puff which you submerged in wine, and oil.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then give treatment which is done with poultices and unguents, until it is healed
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	Of the swelling that arises from the twisting of nerves.
Caput L.	Of the swelling that arises from the twisting of nerves.
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	Just as swelling arises in arteries and veins, in the same way swelling arises in nerves: that which arises from percussion in the body, or from excessive labor, or in a similar way: and it is most frequent in the armpits, or at the ankle, and in every place where there is a joint movement: and it is a serious swelling.
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	It is similar in color to the rest of the body, and is in various positions without pain: and when it is compressed with pressure, a pain similar to that of drunkenness is felt in it
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	It is not a deep swelling of the body, but rather under the skin, and it moves to all parts, and does not go forward or backward or to the back
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	Which is why it is in the joints, it does not need to be grasped with iron.
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	Perhaps also there will be a contraction.
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	But in that which is in the head, or in the face, find the skin with a spatula.
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	If it is a small swelling, then hold it with forceps, and cut it off from its root
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if it is large, then suspend it with a thread, and scrape it off: then remove it, and join it together with a suture: and care for it until it heals.</start_of_turn>
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	Of the excision of the swelling which is in the belly.</start_of_turn>
Caput LI.	Of the excision of the swelling which is in the belly.</start_of_turn
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	These occur in many people in the bellies, and in the rest of their bodies, those which are called Fungalia, because of their resemblance to fungi
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	Whose root is slender, and their head is bulky, and their lips are joined together.
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	And they are of the small intestines: and they are of the small intestines which grow large upwards
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	And indeed I saw a man, and in his belly there were two tumours, which were greater than the rest like mushrooms: there was no difference between them, white or dark, root or top: they joined together and moisture ran out of them always.
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	I cut them off, and I found in the weight of one almost twenty-eight ounces and in the other about six ounces. And the operation in their incision is, as you consider, if the patient is humid, and the colour of the tumours is white, humid, slender root: then cut through with a wide spatula, and there will be in your presence their caeca in the fire.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	Much blood is expelled at the cutting of it: take care therefore if you are splashed by blood, then cauterize it.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	If you see a sick man weak and timid from the incision with the iron, then take a leaden thread from the middle and string it with it: whose method is as we have said, and let him go in two days.
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add lead in stricture.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	Do not cease to string the lead until it is broken, and it falls down without toil
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	If however the tumours be large of the root, then in their incision there is something fearful and painful: especially because of that which is in the belly
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	But indeed it is possible to cut through the middle of them.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize it, that it does not return
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then care for yourself until you are healed of the wound.
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	Then care for yourself until you are healed of the wound.
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	Then care for yourself until you are healed of the wound.
Caput LII.	Then care for yourself until you are healed of the wound
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	Then care for yourself until you are healed of the wound
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	Then care for yourself until you are healed of the wound
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Then care for yourself until you are healed of the wound
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Then care for yourself until you are healed of the wound
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	Then care for yourself until you are healed of the wound
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	Then care for yourself until you are healed of the wound
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	Then care for yourself until you are healed of the wound
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	Then care for yourself until you are healed of the wound
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	Then care for yourself until you are healed of the wound
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	Then care for yourself until you are healed of the wound
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	Then care for yourself until you are healed of the wound
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	Then care for yourself until you are healed of the wound
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	For in this case there is fear and dread, as I taught thee in the chapter where I spoke of the posset due to the artery and the vein.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	If the swelling of the belly is from the intestine or the bladder: then it is necessary to make the patient spit out whatever he is swallowing, as long as he continues to swallow, and to keep him standing extended
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then signs with encasement all around the belly.
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Then command him to lie down between your hands on his back
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Then surround with a wide sponge around the belly in the place which you indicated with encasement.
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Then extend the middle of the incision upwards with a large hook.
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Then bind it firmly around with strong thread, or with silk cord: and let the knot of the ligation be firm.
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Then open the middle of the incision which has been extended above the ligation.
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	If therefore you find that the thing which is captured by the ligation: then extract the encasement and introduce the finger into it, and push the intestine into the belly: and if you find the bladder, then grasp it with the hook, and cut off its excess
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	But if it is the artery or the vein: then surround it a great deal.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then return to your work.
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	And take two needles, and introduce them into the two corners of the wound: and introduce two needles around the circumference which you made around the incision in the form of a cross, which you make penetrate.
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then tighten the wound in four places on the needles: and if you wish, take out the needles and leave the wound open until the extended flesh has decayed: and it will fall away by itself: or cut it away when it becomes thin and has decayed
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for yourself with what is necessary from unguents until you are healed.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	If there is swelling of the belly from the flesh or from moisture: then it is necessary to make an incision above the navel, as we have said.</start_of_turn>
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	And drain blood, or moisture, as you find in it.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	Then care for yourself with what is necessary from unguents until you are healed.</start_of_turn>
¶ De cura CANCRI.	About the care of cancer.</start_of_turn
Caput LIII.	Chapter 53.</start_of_turn>
Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	We have already said in the discourse concerning the kinds of cancer, and how it is useful to care for it with physicians: and we must be cautious with it when caring for it with iron, so that we do not ulcerate it: and we have said that cancer is generated in the matrix, and we must be cautious of its care.</start_of_turn
Et dixerunt antiqui, quod quandoque Cancer est in loco, ubi possibilis est eius eradicatio: sicut Cancer qui est in mammillis, aut in coxa, et eis similibus, ex membris locatis ad extrahendum totum eius: praecipue quando est incipiens paruus.	And the ancients have said that sometimes when cancer is in a place where its eradication is possible: such as cancer that is in the breast, or in the thigh, and those that are like these, from the members located to be extracted throughout: especially when it is in its beginning and small.</start_of_turn
Quando uero antiquatur, et est magnus, non oportet ut appropinques ei.	When it is old and great, it is not necessary to approach it.</start_of_turn
Ego enim non potui sanare ex eo aliquem: neque uidi alium ante me qui peruenerit ad illud.	I cannot cure anyone from it: nor do I know of anyone who has ever cured it.</start_of_turn
Et operatio in eo, quando est locatus sicut diximus, est, ut praecedas, et soluas infirmum ex cholera nigra aliquotiens.	And the operation in it, when it is located as we have said, is to precede and extract the diseased part from black bile several times.</start_of_turn
Deinde phlebotoma ipsum si inuenis cum repletione manifesta.	Then make a phlebotomy if you find it with a visible swelling.</start_of_turn
Deinde praepara infirmum praeparatione, in qua locetur cum operatione.	Then prepare the patient before the operation, when he is located with the operation.
Deinde proiice in Cancrum uncinos qui conueniunt ei.	Then place him on the table which is suitable for him.
Postea concaua ipsum ab omni parte cum cute, secundum perscrutationem, donec non remaneat aliquid ex radicibus eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere, et non abscindas ipsum uelociter, imo exprime loca, et absterge sanguinem grossum totum manu tua, aut cum quo possibile est ibi ex instrumentis.	Then draw out all the nails from every part with the skin, according to the prescription, until nothing remains of his roots: and let the blood flow freely, and do not cut him too quickly, but rather express the place, and drain the thick blood as much as possible with your hands, or with whatever instruments are available
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi fluxus sanguinis grossi ex incisione arteriae, aut uenae: tunc cauteriza uenam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If, however, there is excessive flow of thick blood from an artery or vein: then cauterize the vein, until the bleeding stops
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for him with the rest of the treatment, until he is healed
¶ De cura Hydropisis.	(Text continues with another section of the translation
Caput LIIII.	(End of translation
