Deinde accipe acum, in qua sit filum grossum, factum licinium ex decem filis: et intromitte ipsam apud postremum sifach, id est, tunicae, quod est sub cute testiculorum quae sequitur sectionem: deinde incide extremitates quae eminent ex filo, donec sint quatuor fila.	Then grasp the needle, in which there is a thick thread, made of ten threads: and introduce it through the back of the white patch, that is, the tunica which follows the section: and cut off the extremities which protrude from the thread, until there remain four threads.
Deinde compone quaedam eorum super quaedam cum figura quae sit in modo crucis: et liga cum eis alsifach, de quo diximus, quia est sub cute testiculorum ligamento uehementi, donec non possit aliquod ex uasis, quae nutriunt eos mittere ad eos aliquid: ut non accidat inde apostema calidum.	Then make a loop with each over each other in the shape of a cross: and ligate with two threads, of which we have spoken, because it is under the skin of the testicles a ligament which unites them, until it cannot any longer contain any of the things which nourish them: so that it does not happen that after the operation there remains a cold abscess
Et pone iterum ligamentum secundum extra ligamentum primum, longinquum ab eo minus duobus digitis.	And put in again a ligament outside the first ligament, long enough to be less than two fingers.
Et post ista duo ligamenta dimitte ex sifach, quod est sub cute testiculorum, quantitatem magnitudinis digiti: et incide reliquum totum secundum rotunditatem, et aufer ex eo ouum.	And after these two ligatures draw out from the white patch, which is under the skin of the testicles, as much as the quantity of the magnitude of a finger: and cut off the rest entirely according to the roundness, and take out from it one.
Deinde seca in inferiori parte cutis testiculorum sectione, ex qua currit sanguis, et sanies: sicut narrauimus in eo quod praemissum est.	Then dry the lower part of the skin of the testicles of the section from which blood runs, and heal: as we have narrated before.
Deinde administra lanam submersam in oleo, et pone in uulnus: et administra ligamentum quod narrauimus.	Then apply soaked wool under the bandage in oil, and put in: and administer the ligament which we have narrated.
Et quandoque cauterizatur sifach album quod diximus, post incisionem eius timendo de fluxu sanguinis.	And when the white pith has been cauterized, after its incision be watchful of the flow of blood.
Multotiens enim accidit illud.	Blood flow is prone to occur in this case.
Et dimitte ligamentum, donec cadat per se.	And let go the ligament until it falls away by itself.
Si autem tardatur casus eius, tunc embrocetur cum aqua calida: et pone super ipsum illud quod diximus, donec cadat.	If, however, its case is delayed, then it will be bound with warm water: and place above that which we mentioned, until it falls away
Deinde cura uulnus cum reliqua curatione uulnerum, donec curetur.	Then care for the wound with the rest of the care for wounds, until it heals
¶ De Ramice uentosa.	Of a Suppurated Limb.
Caput LXVI.	Chapter LXVI.</start_of_turn>
IN Hac Ramice non uidi aliquem qui ausus fuerit super curationem eius cum ferro.	In a Suppurated Limb let no one presume to treat it with iron
Et primi quidem dixerunt, quod fit sicut narrauimus in Ramice quae est cum Vite.	And first they say that it is like that which we have narrated in the Ramus which is with the Bone-Splint.
Quod est, ut liges uasa post sectionem super ea cum facilitate inferius: deinde seca in medio, et cura postremo cum eo quod aperit ipsum, donec cadant uasa: et cura uulnus, secundum quod diximus, donec sanetur.	That is, as the bone-splint is applied after the section above that with ease: then dry in the middle, and care afterwards with that which opens it up, until the splints fall away: and care for the wound, as we have mentioned, until it heals
¶ De disruptione quae fit in inguinibus.	Of the disruption which occurs in the Groins
Caput LXVII.	Chapter LXVII.</start_of_turn
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, sicut diximus, et eminet locus, et non descendit ad testiculos aliquid ex intestinis: et si descendit, est illud parum, et redit in omnibus horis: uerum si prolongatur cum ea tempus, additur fissura in sifach, donec descendunt intestina in sifach.	When a Rupture occurs in the Groins, as we have mentioned, and the place is evident, and the intestines do not descend to the testicles for anything: and if they descend, it is little, and returns in every hour: indeed if prolonged for a long time, a fissure is added in the pith, until the intestines descend into the pith
Et accidit illud ex extensione sifach, quod est in inguinibus, sicut diximus.	And this occurs from the extension of the pith, which is in the Groins, as we have mentioned
Quod est, quia extenditur sifach: deinde mollificatur, et apostematur locus, et eminet.	When the swelling has been extended, it is softened, and the place is raised up, and it emits.
Et cura eius est cum cauterio, sicut praecessit eius narratio.	Its care is like that with cautery, as it has been said before.
Et quandoque curatur cum ferro, secundum hunc modum: et est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum inter manus tuas.	When it is cured with iron, it is done in this way: the patient lies upon his back between your hands.
Deinde seca locum Rupturae apostematum et eminentem, sectione per latitudinem, secundum quantitatem trium digitorum.	Then dry the place of the rupture, raise it up and emit it by cutting across its breadth, according to the quantity of three fingers
Deinde stringe alsifak et, quae sunt sub cute, donec quando detegitur sifach album, quod est sub cute quae sequitur ipsum.	Then bind up the swelling and those which are under the skin, until the white swelling, which is under the skin following the said, is detected.
Tunc accipe radium, et pone ipsum super locum eminentem ex sifach, et preme ipsum ad profundum uentris.	Then take the radium and place it upon the place where the swelling has emitted from the swelling, and press it deep into the belly
Deinde sue duo loca eminentia super extremitatem radii ex sifach, et annecte cum sutura unum eorum cum altero: deinde extrahe extremitatem radii.	Then take two points from the edge of the swelling from the swelling, and join them with a suture: then draw out the edge of the swelling
Et non incidas alsifach omnino, neque tendas ouum, neque aliud, sicut feci te scire in curatione ramicis intestinalis.	And do not cut through the swelling at all, neither pull out hair or anything else, like I have told you in the treatment of intestinal branches.
Deinde cura illud curatione uulnerum.	Then care for the wound.
Cum ergo incidis fila, mundifica illud, et restaura uulnus, donec consolidetur.	When you have finished cutting the suture, moisten it, and restore the wound, until it is consolidated
Sisach enim contrahitur, et non additur eminentia Rupturae.	Let the swelling relax, and do not add to the emission of the rupture.
Et cauterium est melius in hoc loco: quoniam est propinquius ad salutem.	And cautery is better in this place: because it is closer to the membrane.
¶ De mollificatione cutis testiculorum.	About the softening of the skin of the testicles.
Caput LXVIII.	Chapter LXVIII.
Multotiens mollificatur cutis testiculorum in quibusdam hominibus, propter quod mollificantur carnes quae sunt inter ea, et foedatur aspectus eius.	The skin of the testicles is softened in many people, because the meats which are between them are softened, and the aspect of it is made worse.
Ergo necesse est ei qui rogatur in curatione eius, ut faciat iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et incidat totam cutem quae mollificata est super cutem naturalem.	Therefore it is necessary for him who is asking for treatment to make the patient lie upon his back, and to cut through the whole skin which has been softened over the natural skin.
Deinde aggreget duo labia cum sutura: et si uis, sue in primis superfluitatem cutis mollificatae tribus suturis, aut quatuor, et firma suturam.	Then two lips are to be brought together with sutures: and if desired, the excess of softened skin is to be excised with three or four sutures, and to tighten the suture
Deinde incide inter sututuras.	And then to cut through between the sutures.
Deinde cura curatione reliquorum uulnerum, usquequo sanetur, et cadant fila.	And then to care for the remaining wounds until they are healed, and the stitches are to be removed
¶ De Castratione.	(The text following this point is not included in the request and is not translated.)
Caput LXIX.	Chapter LXIX
Scias, quod Castratio in lege nostra excommunicata est: et propter illud liceret mihi, ut non rememorarer eius in libro meo isto: et non est necessaria rememoratio eius, nisi propter duos modos.	You know that castration is forbidden in our law: and because of this it is permitted for me not to remind it in this book: and it is not necessary to remind it, except for two cases.
Quorum unus est, ut sit illud in scientia medici quando interrogatur de ea: et ut sciat curationem eius cui accidit.	Of which one is that it is in the science of medicine when it is inquired about: and to know its treatment when it has happened.
Et modus alter est, quod nos multotiens indigemus castratione quorundam animalium, propter iuuamenta nostra per illud, sicut arietum, hyrcorum, et gattorum, et similium ex animalibus.	And the other is that we are much in need of castration for some animals, because of our enjoyment of them, such as horses, gazelles, and cats, and similar animals.
Dico ergo, quod Castratio fit secundum duos modos.	I say therefore that castration is done in two ways.
Aut per attritionem.	Or by cutting off.
Aut per fissuram, et sectionem.	Or by incision, and section
In illa autem quae fit per attritionem, uia operationis est: quod nos faciamus sedere animal in aqua calida, donec mollificentur testiculi eius, et leniantur, et pendeant: deinde attere eos manu tua, donec resoluantur et non appareant sub tactu.	In which way, however, which is done by attrition, the operation is: that we make the animal sit in warm water, until the testicles soften and relax, and hang down: then cut off their hands, until they are dissolved and do not appear to the touch
In castratione autem per fissuram et sectionem, oportet ut teneas animal, et premas cutem testiculorum eius cum manu sinistra.	In castratione autem per fissuram et sectionem, oportet ut teneas animal, et premas cutem testiculorum eius cum manu sinistra.
Deinde liga suspensorium, et seca super omne ouum sectione una, donec quando procedunt duo oua: tunc incide ea postquam excoriaueris utrumque, et non dimittas super ea ex sifaket aliquid praeter sifac subtile, quod est super uasa.	In castration, however, through incision and section, it is necessary to ligate the animal and grasp the skin of the testicles with the left hand.
Et iste modus castrationis est melior eo qui fit per attritonem: quoniam attritio fortasse relinquit aliquid ex testiculis, quare desiderat animal coitum.	And thus is the better method of castration by attrition: for perhaps attrition will leave something behind from the testicles, which the animal desires in coitus.
Deinde cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	Then care for the wound until it has healed.
¶ De cura Hermafroditae duorum modorum.	Of the care of hermaphrodites, two methods exist
Caput LXX.	(The text continues with further medical instructions.)
Hermafrodita ex uiris est secundum duos modos.	A hermaphrodite is born from two mothers
Vnus eorum est, quia apparet in eo quod sequitur spacium, aut in cute testiculorum, in eo quod est inter duos testiculos, figura quasi uulua mulieris, in qua sunt pili: et quandoque currit urina ex eo quod est in cute testiculorum.	One of them appears because it follows the space, or in the skin of the testicles, or between two testicles, a figure like a female vulva, in which there are hairs: and sometimes urine comes out from that which is in the skin of the testicles
In mulieribus autem est species una, et est uulua mulieris super pectinem sicut testiculi uiri parui omnino, eminentes ad exteriora: quorum unus est sicut priapus uiri, et duo sicut duo testiculi.	But in women there is only one kind, which is the female vulva which is placed over the belly like small testicles and extends outwards: of which one is like the penis of a man, and two like two testicles
Et curatio trium specierum, duarum ex uiris, et speciei unius ex mulieribus, est: quia oportet ut incidas carnes additas, donec effugiat impressio earum.	And the care of the three kinds, two of which are born from two mothers, and the one from a woman, is: because it is necessary to cut away the added flesh until the impression of them is fled.
Deinde cura eas curatione reliquorum uulnerum.	Then care for the rest of the wounds
In specie autem secunda uirorum, ex qua egreditur urina, quae est in cute testiculorum, non est operatio, neque est eius curatio omnino.	But as for the second kind of hermaphroditism from which urine comes from the skin of the testicles, there is no operation, nor is there any care for it whatsoever.
¶ De incisione Tentiginis, et carnis eminentis in uuluis mulierum.	On the incision of the Tentiginis, and the protruding flesh in the vulvas of women.
Caput LXXI.	On the incision of the Tentiginis, and the protruding flesh in the vulvas of women.
Tentigo fortasse additur super rem naturalem, donec foedatur et turpis fit aspectus eius: et quandoque magnificatur in quibusdam mulieribus adeo, donec expanditur sicut in uiris, et peruenit usque ad coitum.	The Tentiginis sometimes adds something beyond its natural size, until it becomes deformed and unsightly: and sometimes it swells in certain women to such an extent that it expands as far as the hips, and persists until coitus.
Oportet ergo ut teneas superfluitatem Tentiginis manu, aut cum uncino, et incidas: et non ultimes in incisione, praecipue in profundo radicis: ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	It is necessary therefore to remove the superfluous flesh of the Tentiginis, either with one cut or two: and do not hesitate in the incision, especially in the depth of the root: lest there should be a flow of blood
Deinde cura ipsam curatione uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the healing of the wound, until it is healed
Caro autem orta, est caro quae nascitur in orificio matricis, donec impleat ipsum: et fortasse egreditur ad exteriora secundum similitudinem caudae: et propter illud quidam primi nominant aegritudinem caudatam.	But the flesh which is born in the opening of the womb, until it is expelled: and perhaps it goes out to the exterior like the tail: and because of this some call it caudal fistula.
Oportet ergo ut incidamus eam sicut incidimus Tentiginem, et curemus eam, donec sanetur.	It is necessary therefore to incisions as we did the Tentiginis, and to take care of it, until it is healed
¶ De cura Alratica, quae est uulua mulieris non perforata.	On the care of the Alratica, which is the vulva of a woman which is not perforated.
Caput LXXII.	On the care of the Alratica, which is the vulva of a woman which is not perforated
Alratica est, ut sit uulua mulieris non perforata, aut sit foramen paruum.	The Alratica is, when it is neither perforated nor has a small opening.
Et est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	It is either natural or accidental
Accidentalis est ex aegritudine quae praecessit: et ipsa quidem fit aut ex carne nata addita, aut sifach subtili, aut spisso: et fit aut in profundo matricis, aut in lateribus eius, aut in superiore ipsius, aut inferiori eius: et prohibet a coitu et impregnatione, et partu, et fortasse prohibet menstrua.	It is accidental from an ailment which preceded it: and sometimes it is formed from the native flesh added, or from fine blood vessels, or from fat: and it occurs either in the depth of the womb, or in the flanks, or in the upper part of it, or in the lower part of it: and it prevents coitus and impregnation, and childbirth, and perhaps prevents menstruation
Et cognitio illius fit per aspectum obstetricis, si opilatio est apparens propinqua.	Knowledge of the condition is acquired from the aspect of obstetrics, when the opening appears close at hand.
Si autem non est apparens, tunc quaere eam digitis tuis, aut cum radio.	If it is not apparent, then seek with your fingers, or with the aid of an instrument.</start_of_turn>
Si autem opilatio est ex sifach subtili, et est propinqua duobus labiis: tunc propera, et disrumpe ipsam.	If the opening is from a thin membrane, and is close to the bones, then grasp firmly, and break it.</start_of_turn>
Et est, ut ponas super duo labia puluillos.	And it is necessary to place over two lips two cushions.</start_of_turn>
Deinde pone indices tuos duarum manuum simul, et mulier sit super dorsum suum expansis cruribus suis.	Then place your two fingers of both hands together, and the woman should sit with her buttocks spread wide.</start_of_turn
Deinde extende duo labia cum fortitudine, donec disrumpatur sifach subtile, et aperiatur opilatio.	Then stretch out the two lips with force, until the thin membrane is broken and the opening is created.</start_of_turn
Deinde accipe lanam, et imbibe eam in oleo, et pone ipsam super locum: et coeat mulier omni die, ut non consolidetur locus uice alia.	Then grasp wool, and soak it in oil, and place it on the place: and the woman should abstain from all food until the place has healed.</start_of_turn
Si autem sifach est grossum, spissum: tunc oportet ut seces ipsum cum spatumili lato simili folio myrti.	If the membrane is thick and tough: then it is necessary to cut it with a knife like the edge of a myrtle leaf.</start_of_turn
Si autem opilatio est ex carne nata, tunc suspende eam cum uncinis, et incide eam: et sint tecum medicinae quae fluxum sedant sanguinis absque mordicatione, sicut acacia, et sanguis draconis, et thus aggregatum cum albugine oui.	If the opening is from natural flesh: then suspend it with hooks, and cut it through: and be with physicians who will cause the flow of blood without causing damage, such as acacia, and dragon's blood, and thus it will be aggregated with albumin or urine.</start_of_turn>
Deinde administra cannulam ex plumbo amplam, ut non consolidetur uulnus uelociter, teneat eam diebus aliquot: et administra licinium ex lino sicco, deinde curetur reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then administer a wide lead cannula, so that it does not cause the wound to heal too quickly, keep it for a few days: and administer vinegar from dry wine, then care for the rest of the treatment until it heals.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque nasciur in matrice natiuitas carnium aliarum: oportet ergo ut incidantur secundum hunc modum: dum non est apostema cancerosum apostemati enim canceroso quod est in matrice, non fiat contrarietas cum ferro omnino.	And when there is birth in the matrix of other meats: it is necessary to do this in this way: while there is no cancerous tumor in the matrix, do not use iron in any way.</start_of_turn
¶ De cura hemorroidarum, Athehelil, et Bothor rubeae in uuluis mulierum.	Concerning the care of hemorrhoids, Athehelil, and Bothor of the red in the veins of women.
Caput LXXIII.	Concerning the care of hemorrhoids, Athehelil, and Bothor of the red in the veins of women.
Hemorroides quidem sunt apertio orificiorum uenarum, donec currit ex eis sanguis multus assidue.	Hemorrhoids are indeed the opening of the veins of the rectum, from which blood flows out in large quantities due to excess.
Cum ergo antiquantur hemorroides, fiunt thelil: et iam dixi in diuisione species earum, et signa ipsarum: et dicam hic quae ex eis recipiunt curationem, et quae non.	When the hemorrhoids have become large, they cause pain: and as I have already mentioned in the discussion of their kinds, and their signs: here I will tell you what is to be received for their treatment, and what is not
Dico ergo, quod hemorroides quae sunt in orificio matricis, et non apparent sensui: tunc non est ei curatio cum ferro.	I say, therefore, that hemorrhoids which are in the belly and not visible to the eye: then there is no treatment for them with iron.
Quae autem ex eis sunt in orificio matricis super quas cadit sensus, sunt quae curantur.	Those which are in the belly and over which sense falls are those which are cured.
Oportet ergo ut intromittas mulierem in domum frigidam.	It is necessary therefore that the woman be put into a cold house
Deinde extende athehelil cum forficibus, aut cum panno aspero, et incide eas ex radicibus suis.	Then stretch out Athehelil with forceps, or with rough cloth, and cut away the roots from them
Deinde pulueriza super eas apud fluxum sanguinis ex uno puluerum incisiuorum absque mordificatione: sicut acacia, et sanguis draconis, et thus, et similia eis.	Then powder over the roots with one of the powders mentioned above, without causing any damage: like acacia, and dragon's blood, and thus, and similar things.
Deinde impellat pedes eius ad parietem hora una.	Then press her feet against the wall for an hour.
Postea depone eam in aquam frigidam.	Then put her down in cold water.
Quod si perseuerat fluxus sanguinis: tunc fac eam sedere in decoctione sumach, et corticum granatorum, et gallarum, et similium.	If the bleeding persists: then make her sit in a decoction of rue, and nutmeg seeds, and barley, and similar things.
Deinde accipe farinam hordei, et confice eam cum melle et aceto, et fac emplastrum cum eo super dorsum eius.	Then take barley flour, and mix it with honey and vinegar, and make a plaster with it on her back
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis cum eo, bonum est: et si non, fac adhaerere dorso uentosas, et mammillis, absque scarificatione.	If the bleeding stops with this: good. And if not, make the edges of the wound adhere to each other, and give her milk, without causing any damage
Deinde accipe lanam, et submerge in succo tarathit, aut succo arnoglossae, aut succo ramorum alaulat, id est, aglanter, uino pontico, et fac adhaerere loeo.	Then take wool and soak it in grease of poppy seeds, or in almond oil, or in fat of asses, that is, beeswax, wine of Ponticus, and make it adhere to the wound.
Cum ergo quiescit apostema, tunc cura locum cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	When the swelling has subsided, then care for the place with unguents until it has healed.</start_of_turn>
Albarth uero rubeum est simile capitibus alhaasse, et est asperi aspectus.	However, it is red like a head of garlic, and has a rough appearance.</start_of_turn>
Oportet ergo ut incidas quod apparet ex eo, secundum quod dixi in thelil aequaliter: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	It is necessary therefore that you cut away what appears from it, as I said a little while ago: and care for it until it has healed.</start_of_turn>
¶ De perforatione Exiturae quae accidit in matrice.	Of the perforation of the Exitura which happens in the matrix.</start_of_turn>
Caput LXXIIII.	The head is seventy-four.</start_of_turn
Accidunt in matrice species multae apostematum, sicut cancer, et apostema lapideum, et ulcera, et adubelati, et alekilati, id est, herpes, aestiomemus, et fistulae, et hemorroides, et ragadiae, et thelil, et apostema calidum.	Many kinds of swellings happen in the matrix, such as cancer, and stone abscess, and ulcer, and tumor, and carbuncle, and herpes, and aestioma, and fistula, and hemorrhoids, and carbuncles, and gangrene.</start_of_turn
Et ego quidem iam dixi omnes has aegritudines et species earum, et signa ipsarum, et earum curationes in diuisione: necesse est ut dicam in hoc tractatu apostema calidum quod accidit in matrice, quando est ex apostematibus quae colligunt saniem, et uis scire qualiter fit eius apertio cum ferro.	And I will say also that I mentioned all these diseases and their signs and their cures in detail: it is necessary to say in this treatise the carbuncle which happens in the matrix, when it is from swellings which join health, and to know how to open it with a knife.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	You must consider this.</start_of_turn
Tunc si dolor apostematis in incaeptione sua est acutus cum percussione sua, et flamma, et febre: et uides ipsum rubere: si cadit super ipsum sensus, tunc non properes cum perforatione eius: et cura ipsum cum eo eo quod iuuat super maturationem, donec quando quiescat acuitas accidentium.	When the pain of the swelling is acute with percussion, flame and fever: and you see it turning red: if it falls over your senses, do not attempt to perforate it: care for it with something that will promote maturation, until the acute pain of the accident has subsided.</start_of_turn
Tunc oportet ut facias sedere mulierem super sedem quae labeat duo sedilia, et reclinetur, uel appodietur super dorsum suum, et aggreget pedes suos ad partem inferiorem uentris: et sint coxae eius expansae, et ponat brachia sua sub genibus suis, et liget utraque ligamento conueniente ad illud.	Then it is necessary that you make her sit upon a seat which beats two seats beneath her, and that she recline or is supported upon her back, and that she gather her feet to the lower part of her belly: and that her knees be spread wide, and that she place her arms under her knees, and that she tie each ligament conveniently to that.
Deinde sedeat obstetrix a latere dextro, et administra instrumentum quo aperitur orificium matricis.	Then let the midwife sit to the right, and manage the instrument with which the opening of the birth passage is made.
Cuius forma uenit in eis quae sunt post.	Whose shape comes in the shape of an egg which is behind
Et oportet quando uis administrare hoc instrumentum, ut figas cum Radio profundum matricis mulieris: ut non sit illud quod ingreditur ex instrumento plus, quam profundum matricis, et laedat infirmam.	And it is necessary that when you administer this instrument that the liver is placed with the ribs at the depth of the woman's belly: so that it does not go in deeper than the belly, and does not damage the lower part
Si autem fuerit instrumentum magis quam profundum, tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos super tecturam profundi matricis: ut prohibeatur introitus instrumenti totius in profundum matricis: et oportet ut ponat uertiginem, quae currit in instrumento, ex latere superiore: et ut teneat instrumentum, et ut reuoluat minister uertiginem, donec aperiatur profundum matricis.	If however the instrument is greater than the depth of the belly, then you must place sponges upon the covering of the depth of the belly: so that the entrance of the whole instrument into the belly is prohibited: and you must place a bandage which runs in the instrument from the upper side: and that you hold the instrument and that you rotate the minister of the bandage until the depth of the belly is opened.
Cum ergo apparet Exitura, et tangitur manu, et est lenis et mollis: tunc oportet ut seces ipsam apud caput suum cum spatumili lato.	When therefore the opening appears, and the hand touches it, and it is soft and gentle: then it is necessary that you cut her near her head with a broad spatula.
Cum ergo euacuatur sanies, tunc oportet ut ponas in uulnus licinium submersum in oleo rosaceo: aut oleo uiridi, in quo sit quaedam stipticitas: et pone licinium, et extrahe sectionem in profundo matricis.	When therefore the blood is evacuated, then it is necessary that you put on a compress soaked in warm rose-water: or in green oil, in which there is some astringency: and put on the compress, and draw out the section from the depth of the belly
Et pone exterius super matricem, et super pectinem lanam mundam submersam in aqua, in qua bullitae sunt maluae.	And put externally on the belly, and on the flanks a warm wool blanket soaked in water in which there are bubbles.
Deinde curetur post duos dies cum unguento quod conuenit ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then he cares for two days with the unguent that agrees with it, until it is healed.
Et quandoque abluitur matrix et uulnus, ita quod clisterizatur cum aqua et melle: deinde cum aqua in qua bullita est radix lilii, aut aristolochia longa: deinde redeat ad unguentum.	When the matrix and the vulnus have been bathed, it is to be plastered with water and honey: then with water in which the root of lily or long aristolochia has been boiled: then return to the unguent.
Quod si uulnus absconditum fuerit interius in matrice, tunc oportet ut prohibearis ex curatione eius cum ferro, imo cura ipsum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione.	If the vulnus has been hidden inside the matrix, then it is necessary to keep it away from its cure with iron, or to care for it in the way we have mentioned in the previous instruction
¶ Doctrinae Obstetricum, qualiter medicentur embriones uiui, secundum figuram non naturalem egressi.	Concerning the obstetrics of women, how to treat the embryos of the womb, according to the unnatural figure of their emergence.
Caput Lxxu.	Chapter 72.
Necesse est Obstetrici, ut cognoscat in primis figuram partus naturalis.	It is necessary for the Obstetrician to first learn the natural figure of delivery.
Ex signis ergo eius est, quod quando uides mulierem comprimi ad inferiora, et desiderat odorare aerem, et alleuiatur super eam quod super ipsam est de partu, et festinat exitus embrionis: tunc scias quod iste partus est secundum figuram naturalem, et est exitus eius super caput suum, et secundina cum eo: aut suspensa, uel pendens ex umbilico.	When women are squeezed in childbirth and desire to smell the air, and groan over what is above them during delivery, and hasten the birth of the embryo: then you know that this delivery is natural, and that the head comes out first, and the second with it, or that it is suspended or hanging from the navel
Cum ergo uides haec signa, tunc oportet ut comprimatur uenter eius, ut descendat embrio uelociter.	When you see these signs, then it is necessary to compress the womb, so that the embryo comes down more quickly.
Nam quando descendit super caput suum, descendit secundina cum eo, et mundatur ex illis superfluitatibus mundificatione bona.	For when it descends over the head, it descends with the second part and comes out with them together with the good delivery
Qui autem est praeter hunc partum, est innaturalis, illaudabilis.	Whoever is beyond this delivery is unnatural and harmful
Quoniam quandoque egreditur foetus super pedes suos, et egreditur corpus eius ante caput ipsius, et pedes eius, et manus eius una, aut pes eius unus: aut egreditur caput eius et manus eius: aut egreditur uentrinus: et fortasse conuertitur super collum suum, et similia ex figuris illaudabilibus.	For when the fetus comes out over its feet, and its body comes out before the head, and the feet and hands together, or one foot alone: or the head and the hand: or the belly: and perhaps it turns over on its neck, and similar things from the unnatural figures.
Necesse est ergo Obstetrici, ut sit prudens, subtilis in istis rebus omnibus, et caueat sibi ab errore et decaeptione: et ego sum ostendens omnem figuram ex eis, et qualiter est ingenium in ea, et significetur per illud, et stetur super ipsum.	It is necessary for the Obstetrician to be prudent, discreet in all these matters, and to beware of error and neglect: for I shall demonstrate every figure from these [instruments], and how each is designed, and it will be understood thereby, and I shall stand above it.
Quando egreditur foetus super caput suum egressione sua naturali, et uehemens fit illud super mulierem, et difficilis fit ei partus, et uides uirtutem eius iam debilitatam: tunc fac eam sedere super sedem, aut mulieres teneant eam: et uapora uuluam eius cum foenugraeco decocto, et cum oleis humidis.	When the fetus emerges over its head during its natural expulsion, and the latter is difficult for the woman, and its virtue is impaired: then let her sit down, or let the women hold her: and let steam rise from her moisture with vinegar and decocted henbane, and with oily substances.
Deinde intromittat Obstetrix inter digitos suos Spatumile paruum, et findat cum eo secundinam, et secet eam ungue suo, donec currat quod est in ea ex humiditate: et preme uentrem mulieris, donec descendat foetus.	Then the Obstetrician inserts his fingers between the [vaginal] lips of the Sponge, and finds the second one, and severs it with his nail, until it runs out from the moisture: and he grasps the woman's belly, until the fetus descends
Si autem non descendit, tunc oportet ut clisterizetur mulier ex mucillagine foenugraeci, cum oleo sisamino.	If it does not descend, then it is necessary to instill the woman with [a solution of] vinegar from henbane, with slippery elm.
Deinde praecipe ei post clistere, ut comprimatur: et fac eam sternutare cum condisi, et tene os eius et nasum ipsius hora una.	Then command her to lie down after instilling, so as to compress: and let her breathe steadily for an hour.
Foetus enim egredietur statim.	The fetus will immediately come out.
Quod si egrediantur duae manus foetus in primis, iunc oportet ut reducas eas cum facilitate paulatim.	If two hands of the fetus emerge at once, it is necessary to reduce them gradually with ease
Si autem non obedit in introitu, tunc pone mulierem super sedem, et eleua pedes eius sursum: deinde concute sedem super terram: et mulier teneatur, ut non cadat apud concussionem.	If it does not obey in the delivery, then let the woman sit down and elevate her feet above the ground: then press the seat down to the earth: and the woman should be held so that she does not fall from the concussion
Si ergo non egrediuntur manus, et moritur foetus: tunc incide eas, et extrahe residuum foetus: et liga manum eius cum panno, et extrahe ipsum cum aequalitate: nam ipse egredietur.	If the hands do not come out, and the fetus dies: then cut through the ease and extract the fetus: and tie up the hand with a cloth, and extract it with evenness: for it will come out itself.
¶ Exitus embrionis super pedes suo.	The fetus has emerged from its feet.
Quando egreditur foetus super pedes suos, tunc oportet ut impellat eos sursum: deinde conuertat foetum paulatim: postea aequet ipsum.	When the fetus emerges from its feet, then it is necessary to urge it upwards: afterwards, gradually convert the fetus: finally, equalize it itself.
Deinde accipiat unum pedum eius, et extendat eum paulatim.	Then grasp one of its feet and extend it gradually.
Cum ergo egrediuntur usque ad coxas, tunc praecipe ei, ut comprimatur, et fac eam sternutare cum condisi: egredietur enim, si Deus uoluerit.	When it has emerged as far as the thighs, then command it to lie down, so that it will compress and rest: it will then go out, God willing.
Et si non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc reduc foetum paulatim, donec ponas eum secundum figuram naturalem.	If it does not come out as we have described, then gradually reduce the fetus until you have set it according to its natural shape
Nam ipse egredietur tunc egressu facili.	For indeed it will go out of itself then
Quod si prohibeatur cum eo toto quod narrauimus: tunc accipe ex mucillagine alteae, et oleo sisamino, et gummi soluto: et percute totum in mortario percussione bona: deinde line cum eo uuluam mulieris, et inferius uentris eius.	If it is obstructed as we have described: then take from the high slime, and blood clots, and gum dissolved in water: and pierce all through in the belly with a good blow: then join with the woman's urine and the lower part of her belly.
Deinde fac eam sedere in aqua tepida, donec consequatur hypocundria.	Then make her sit in warm water, until the afterbirth follows naturally.
Cum ergo uides quod iam calefacta sunt inferiora eius, tunc fac ei sief de myrrha: et suppone ipsum.	When the lower parts are softened by the heat, then give her a sieve of myrrh: and support her
Quando ergo tenet sief hora una, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem.	When she has held the sieve for an hour, then make her sit on a seat
Deinde fac eam sternutare: et stringe ipsius os et nasum: et preme inferiorem partem uentris compressione facili.	Then command her to sneeze: and strain her jaw and nose: and compress the lower part of her belly gently
Nam foeus egredietur statim.	For the fetus will go out immediately.
¶ Exitus foetus super genua et manus.	The fetus has emerged from its knees and hands
Quando egreditur secundum hanc formam, tunc ingeniet in intromittendo manus suas paulatim.	When it appears in this form, then it will gradually withdraw its hands inwards.
Deinde resupinetur mulier super collum suum, et pendeant pedes eius ad inferiora: et ipsa sit iacens super lectum, et complicet manus suas.	Then the woman lies upon her shoulder, and her feet hang down below: she lies upon the bed, and she covers her hands.
Deinde preme supra uentrem eius paulatim.	Then she slowly raises her belly upwards
Deinde extrahe quod est sub pedibus eius ex puluinaribus, donec sit praeparata in inferiori parte.	Then pull out what is under her feet from the shoes, until it is prepared in the lower part.
Quod si non egreditur foetus, tunc accipe pedes eius, et moue eos motu uehementi.	If the fetus does not come out, then grasp her feet and move them up and down
Deinde preme quod est supra hypocundria paulatim, donec ascendat foetus ad superiora.	Then slowly press what is above the navel upwards, until the fetus ascends to the upper parts
Deinde intromittat manus suas, et aequet foetum paulatim: et praecipe mulieri, ut comprimatur, donec egrediatur foetus.	Then put in your hands, and gently support the fetus: and command the woman to press, until the fetus comes out.
¶ Exitus foetus latitudinaliter pendens ex manibus.	The fetus comes out hanging laterally from the hands
Ingenietur in reductione manus eius.	It is completed in the reduction of her hand
Si autem non potest reducere eam, tunc eleua mulierem, et fac eam ambulare.	But if it is not possible to reduce the hand, then raise up the woman, and make her walk.
Si uero ambulare non potest, tunc fac eam iacere super lectum: et concute crura eius concussione uehementi.	If she is unable to walk, then make her lie on the bed: and strike her thighs with a blow which is enough to cause her to groan
Deinde administra linimentum quod praeparasti ex mucillaginibus.	Then apply the liniment which you prepared from mucilages.
Quod si accipit eam partus, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem.	If she gives birth, then make her sit on a seat
Deinde stude in reductione manus, et aequa foetum secundum figuram naturalem: et fac sternutare mulierem, et praecipe ei, ut comprimat se, donec egrediatur.	Then watch in the reduction of the hand, and equal the fetus according to its natural figure: and command the woman to breathe steadily, and tell her to press, until it comes out
¶ Exitus foetus super collum suum, expansis manibus, et est facies eius ad dorsum matris suae.	The fetus comes out on her shoulder, with her hands spread out, and her face is towards the mother's back
Oportet ut teneat Obstetrix manum foetus, deinde reuoluat eum paulatim, et aequet eum cum facilitate.	The obstetrix must hold the hand of the fetus firmly, then gradually release it, and equalize it with ease.
Cum ergo aequatur, tunc pone super uuluam eius quod narrauimus ex oleo et mucillaginibus.	When it is equal, then place above its belly what we have mentioned from wax and mucus
Deinde praecipe ei, ut moueatur paulatim.	Then command it to move gradually.
Cum ergo feceris illud, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem, et praecipe ei ut inclinetur ad latus dextrum.	When you have done this, then make it sit on its seat, and command it to incline to the right side.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut comprimatur: et fac eam sternutare cum condisi.	Then command it to press: and make it exhale with a cough.
¶ Exitus foetus praeparati super latus.	The fetus is prepared for birth on the right side.
Quando descendit ad orificium matricis secundum hunc modum cum secundina, tunc scinde secundinam cum ungue tuo, donec euacuetur ex humiditate.	When it descends to the opening of the womb in this manner with the second [finger], then tear the second [finger] with your thumb, until it is evacuated from the moisture
Si ergo suspenditur super faciem foetus, et collum eius, tunc incide eam ex umbilico: ut non retineatur, et moriatur.	If it is suspended on the face of the fetus, and its neck, then cut it from the navel: so that it does not remain and does not die
Deinde impelle foetum ad interiora, donec ponas eam secundum quod oportet: et praecipe mulieri, ut comprimat se aliquotiens: ipse enim egredietur exitu leui.	Then push the fetus inwards, until you have placed it according to what is required: and command the woman to press slightly: for it will go out through the easy birth opening itself.
¶ Exitus Geminorum, aut foetuum multorum.	Birth of twins, or many fetuses.
Scias, quod Gemini multotiens nascuntur: et quandoque nascuntur tres, et quatuor.	You know that twins are often born together: and sometimes three or four are born together.
Verumtamen illud extraneum est, et raro contingit.	However, this is an unusual thing, and is rarely found.
Quinque uero est res extra naturam, et non uiuunt penitus: et continet eos, quamuis multiplicentur, secundina una: et separantur per sifach, distinguens inter eos ligatum in umbilico cuiusque eorum.	Five or more is beyond nature, and does not endure: and continues with them, although multiplied, the second one being joined to one: and they are separated by the navel of each of them
Et quandoque egrediuntur sicut egreditur foetus unus exitu naturali, facili: et egrediuntur exitu illaudabili, sicut narrauimus.	And sometimes they come out like a single fetus through the natural birth opening, easily: and sometimes they come out through an unnatural opening, as we have narrated.
Quod si difficiles fuerint quidam eorum apud partum, et perueniunt ad illud quod diximus ex figuris innaturalibus, tunc cura eos sicut narrauimus: et sit ob stetrix subtilis, et faciat quod facit cum facilitate et tarditate, et ingenietur secundum omnem figuram cum eo quod praeparatur ei ex ingenio ducente ad salutem.	If some things are difficult at the part, and they reach that which we mentioned from unnatural figures, then care for them as we have said: and let the obstretrix be slight, and let her do what she does with ease and tardiness, and she shall adapt herself to every figure as she is prepared from the ingenuity leading to safety.
¶ Rememoratio eius quod formatur in matrice ex embrionibus, et abortiuntur.	Remember that which is formed in the womb from embryos, and which abort.
Quandoque formatur in matrice unus, et duo, et tres, et quatuor, et quinque, et sex, et septem, et plures decem: et iam uerificatum est apud me, quod mulier abortiendo emisit septem, et alia quindecim, omnes formatos.	When one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, or more than ten are formed in the womb: and I have seen it verified that a woman has aborted seven, and another fifteen, all of whom were formed.
Quod factum est mensuratione gloriosi sapientis.	That which is done by the measurement of the glorious sage.
Hoc ergo totum oportet ut sit in scientia Obstetricis.	Therefore all this pertains to the science of Obstetrics
Fortasse enim perueniet ad eam simile illius: opponat ergo ei cum illo quod oportet	Perhaps therefore it will reach that which is like this: oppose to it what pertains to it
¶ De extractione foetus mortui.	Of the extraction of a dead fetus.
Caput LXXVI.	Chapter LXXVI.
Quando curas foetum mortuum cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex medicatione, et non egreditur, et cogeris uti operatione cum manu, tunc oportet ut consideres.	When you care for a dead fetus with that which I said in the discourse from the medicine, and it does not go out, and you must do what you will with your hands, then you must consider it
Si ergo mulier est sanae uirtutis, et non est cum aliquo ex accidentibus, ex quibus timetur super eam perditio: tunc oportet ut resupinetur mulier super lectum, super dorsum suum, et sit caput eius inclinatum inferius, et crura eius eleuata: et ministra teneat eam a duabus partibus, aut ligetur ad lectum, ut non extrahatur corpus eius apud extractionem foetus.	If a woman is of sound virtue and is not with any of the things from which she is afraid to lose her life during childbirth: then it must be that she rests on her seat, on her back, and let her head be inclined downwards, and her legs be elevated: and the minister shall keep hold of her from two parts, or she shall be bound to the bed, so that her body is not pulled out during the extraction of the fetus
Deinde humecta os matricis ex oleis humidis cum mucillagine alteae, et foenugraeci, et seminis lini.	Then moisten the os matrice with oils which are humid with mucilage of high rank, and fennel, and linseed seed.
Deinde inungat Obstetrix manum suam cum istis oleis et mucillaginibus: deinde intromittat eam in matricem cum facilitate.	Then let the Obstetrix put his hand into the matrix with ease after having moistened it with these oils and mucilages.
Deinde quaerat cum ea locum in quo figat uncinos ex foetu, et loca conuenientia ad illud.	Then he seeks the place where the ribs are joined to the fetus, and the convenient place for it
Considera ergo tunc, si foetus est praeparatus ut descendat super caput suum: tunc fige uncinos in oculos eius, aut in collo eius, aut in ore eius, aut in palato ipsius, aut sub barba eius, aut in furcula ipsius, aut in locis propinquis costis, et sub hypocundriis.	Consider now therefore, if the fetus is ready to descend upon his head: then fix the ribs to his eyes, or to his neck, or to his mouth, or to his palate, or under his beard, or under his armpits, or in the adjacent parts of the ribs, and under the hypopomus
Si autem descensus est super pedes eius, tunc in pectine, et costis eius mediis.	If, however, the descent is upon his feet, then in the loin, and in the middle ribs.
Et oportet, ut teneat uncinum cum manu dextra: et ponat curuitatem eius in eo quod est inter digitos sinistrae manus: et intromittat cum manu cum facilitate, et figat uncinum in aliquo illorum locorum quae diximus, donec perueniat ad rem uacuam.	And it is necessary that he grasp the rib with his right hand: and let his curvature rest in that which is between the left thumb and the little finger: and he introduces it with the hand with ease, and fixes the rib in one of those places which we mentioned until it comes to a halt
Deinde figat in oppositione eius uncinum alium, aut tertium, si indiges: ut sit contractio aequalis, et non declinet ad partem.	Then he fixes the other rib, or the third if necessary: so that there is an equal tension, and it does not incline to one side
Deinde extendatur extensione aequali, et non sit extensio secundum rectitudinem tantum, imo moueatur ad omnem partem, ut alleuietur exitus eius: sicut fit cum dente apud eradicationem eius.	Then extend with an equal extension, and do not be extended only in a straight line, but move towards all parts, so as to alleviate its exit: as it is done with a tooth when it is extracted.
Et oportet in eo quod est inter illud, ut mollificetur extensio.	And it is necessary between these to soften the extension.
Quod si retineatur ex eo pars, tunc oportet ut inungat Obstetrix quosdam digitos cum oleo, et intromittat eos ex parte, ut reuoluat cum eis quod retinetur.	Which if it is retained from this side, then let the Obstetrix grasp any digit with oil, and introduce it from the side, so as to rotate with it what is retained
Si ergo egreditur pars foetus, tunc permutentur uncini ad locum alium qui sit altior: fac hoc donec egrediatur foetus totus.	If therefore the limb of the fetus comes out, then change the nails to another place which is higher: do this until the fetus comes out entirely
Si ergo egreditur manus ante alia, et non est possibile reducere eam, propter coartationem eius: tunc oportet, ut inuoluatur super eam pannus.	If the hand has gone beyond another, and it is not possible to restore it, because of its compression: then it is necessary to cover over the wound.
Deinde extrahe eam donec quando egreditur tota, incide eam aut in iunctura plantae, aut in cubito: et ita oportet ut facias in manu altera, et in duobus pedibus.	Then withdraw the hand until it has gone beyond all the way, cut the palm of the hand or at the base of the plant, or at the elbow: and thus it is necessary that you make in the hand the other way around, and in two feet.
Si autem caput foetus est magnum, aut accidit ei coartatio in exitu, aut est in capite eius aqua aggregata: tunc oportet ut intromittat inter digitos Spatumile spinosum, et findat cum eo caput, et extrahat aquam: aut disrumpat ipsum cum instrumento quod nominatur Almisdac: cuius forma uenit cum formis reliquorum instrumentorum in capitulo quod est post hoc.	If however the head of the fetus is large, or if there is compression for him in the birth, or there is water in his head: then it is necessary that he introduce between the fingers the Spatumile spinosum, and find it with the head, and extract the water: or break it with the instrument which is called Almisdac: whose form comes with the forms of the other instruments in the chapter which follows.
Similiter faciat si foetus est magni capitis natura, tunc oportet ut seces algengematu: aut extrahas ipsum cum misdach, sicut diximus.	Likewise do as concerning a fetus of great head-size; then it is necessary that you cut through the membrane. Or extract him with the hook, as we have said.
Deinde attrahas ossa cum forcipibus.	Then draw out the bones with forceps.
Quod si egrediatur caput, et coartetur apud furculam: tunc findatur, donec effundatur humiditas quae est in pectore.	When the head has gone out, and is compressed at the rib: then it is found, until the moisture which is in the chest is drained out
Si autem non complicatur, neque obedit ad exitum: tunc incide caput frustatim, secundum quod possibile est tibi.	When however it does not complicate, neither does it obey the going out: then cut off the head roughly, as much as is possible for you
Quod si inferius uentris est apostematum, aut est in eo hydropisis: tunc oportet ut perfores ipsum, donec currat humiditas ex eo.	When however the lower belly is apostematized, or there is water in it: then it is necessary that you perforate it, until the moisture is run out of it.
Si uero foetus est super pedes suos, tunc attractio eius est facilis, et directio eius ad os matricis est leuis.	When however the fetus is above his feet: then the traction of him is easy, and the direction of him towards the maternal bone is gentle
Si autem coartatur apud uentrem, aut pectus: tunc oportet ut extrahas ipsum cum panno quem inuoluisti super manum tuam: et findat uentrem, aut pectus, donec currat quod est in eis.	When however it is compressed at the belly, or the chest: then it is necessary that you extract it with the cloth which you have covered over your hand: and find the belly, or the chest, until it is run out of it.
Si autem auferuntur reliqua membra, et redit caput: tunc intromittat Obstetrix manum sinistram.	If, however, the other limbs are removed and the head remains: then the Obstetrix inserts his left hand into the head.
Si ergo os matricis est apertum, tunc intromittat manum in profundum matricis, et quaerat cum ea caput, et attrahat ipsum cum digitis usque ad os matricis: deinde intromittat in eo uncinum unum, aut uncinos duos, et attrahat ipsum cum eo.	If the mouth of the uterus is open: then he inserts his hand into the depth of the uterus, and grasps the head, and pulls it towards the os of the uterus: then he inserts into it one or two fingers and pulls them with it.</start_of_turn>
Quod si os matricis coartatur, propter apostema calidum quod accidit ei: tunc non oportet ut laboretur super ipsum, imo oportet tunc administrare effusionem rerum humidarum, pinguium: et administra emplastra: et sedeat in aquis quae mollificant et humectant.	If the os of the uterus is closed, because of a thick clot which has occurred to it: then it is not necessary to work above it, indeed it is necessary at that time to administer an effusion of liquid things, fats: and administer plasters: and sit in water which softens and moistens.</start_of_turn>
Quod si foetus est super latus suum, tunc possibile est ut aequetur: tunc administretur quod diximus in foetu uiuo.	If the fetus is above its side: then it is possible to equalize it: then is administered what we said concerning the fetus above.</start_of_turn>
Quod si non est possibile illud, tunc incidatur frustatim, et extrahatur.	If that is not possible, then it is done hastily, and it is extracted.</start_of_turn>
Et oportet ut non dimittas aliquid ex secundina intus omnino.	And it is necessary that you do not let anything fall out of the second part entirely.</start_of_turn>
Cum ergo compleueris operationem tuam, tunc administra quod diximus in apostematibus calidis quae accidunt in matricibus.	When you have completed your operation, then administer what we said concerning the clots which occur in the uterus.</start_of_turn
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc descendat in aquis stipticis, et administra reliquam curationem.	If blood flows: then descends into styptic waters, and administer the rest of the treatment.</start_of_turn
Et ego quidem iam uidi mulierem, in cuius uentre mortuus erat foetus: deinde impregnata est super ipsum uice alia, postea mortuus est foetus alius etiam.	And I myself have seen a woman in whose womb a fetus was dead: then she was impregnated above her with another, afterwards another fetus was also dead.</start_of_turn
Accidit ergo ei post tempus longum apostema in umbilico suo, et inflatum est, donec apertum est: et coepit emittere pus.	It happened to her afterwards a long time, a clot in her navel, which was inflated, until it opened: and it began to emit pus.</start_of_turn
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius, et medicatus sum ei tempore longo: et non consolidatum est uulnus.	I am called to his care, and I have treated him for a long time: and the wound is not consolidated.
Posui ergo super ipsum ex quibusdam emplastris fortis attractionis: et exiuit ex loco os.	I place above it some strong adhesive plaster: and it has come out of its place.</start_of_turn>
Deinde praeterierunt ei dies aliquot, et exiuit os aliud.	Then some days passed by, and it came out of its place again.</start_of_turn
Miratus sum ergo inde, cum in uentre non sit os.	I am sore there, because there is no bone in it.</start_of_turn>
Cogitaui ergo, quia erant ex ossibus foetus mortui.	I think therefore that there were dead bones of a fetus.</start_of_turn>
Inquisiui ergo uulnus, et extraxi ossa multa, muliere existente in melioribus dispositionibus suis: et iam uixit taliter tempore longo, et mittit ex loco pus parum.	I asked about the wound, and I extracted many bones, the woman being in better conditions: and I have treated it thus for a long time, and it is now leaving pus a little.</start_of_turn
Et ego non firmaui hic hoc extraneum, nisi quoniam in eo est scientia, et adiutorium ad illud, quod administrat medicus artifex cum manu ex curatione.	And I did not consolidate this foreign body, except that there is science in it, and an aid to that which the artificer doctor administers with his hand in treatment.</start_of_turn>
¶ De formis Instrumentorum necessariorum in extractione foetus.	Regarding the forms of the necessary instruments for extracting a fetus.</start_of_turn
Caput LXXVII.	Chapter 77.</start_of_turn>
Hic inferius est forma Strictorii, quo aequantur libri, cui aequaliter sunt duae uertigines in duabus extremitatibus duorum lignorum.	Here below is the form of the Strictor, with which books are equalised, having two rings in two extremities of two sticks.</start_of_turn
Verumtamen haec Vertigo oportet ut sit subtilior strictorio: et ut fiat, aut ex ebano, aut ex ligno bussi.	But it must be known that this hook should be finer than the strictor: and that it should be made either of ebony or of seasoned wood.</start_of_turn
Et sit latitudo omnis ligni quasi duo digiti: et margo cuiusque amborum est quasi digitus unus, et longitudo cuiusque eorum est palmus et medietas: et in medio duorum lignorum sunt duo additamenta ex genere eiusdem ligni, quae iam firmata sunt in utrisque, quorum longitudo est medietas palmi et plus parum: et latitudo utriusque est quasi duo digiti, aut plus parum.	And the width of every stick is like two fingers: and the margin of each of them is like one finger, and the length of each of them is palm and a half: and in the middle of the two sticks are two additaments of the same kind of wood, which are firm in both, of whose length is half a palm and a little, and the width of each is like two fingers, or less.</start_of_turn
Et ista duo additamenta intromittuntur in os matricis, ut aperiatur cum eis quando tu reuoluis duas Vertigines.	Two additional things are introduced into the matrix of the bone, so that it opens when you rotate two Vertigines.
Forma Vertiginis qua aperitur matrix.	The form of the Vertigines which opens the matrix.
Forma alia ad simile illius, subtilior, et leuior.	Another form like that, finer and lighter.
Fiat ex ligno ebani, aut bussi, secundum similitudinem forcipum.	It is made from the wood of the bone, or from ivory, according to the shape of pincers.
Verumtamen in extremitate eius sint duo additamenta, sicut uides hic supra: et longitudo omnis additamenti ex eis est quasi palmus: et latitudo utriusque est, duo digiti.	Indeed, at its extremity these two things are introduced, as mentioned above: and the length of each of these things from the tip is like a palm, and the breadth of each is like two fingers
Cum ergo uis aperire matricem cum eo, tunc fac sedere mulierem super lectum, pendentibus pedibus eius, aperto quod est inter crura eius.	When you wish to open the matrix with these, then make her sit on a chair, with her feet hanging over the edge, and open what is between her buttocks
Deinde intromitte ista duo additamenta coniuncta in matricem: et tu es tenens extremitatem instrumenti inferius inter coxas eius.	Then introduce these two things together into the matrix: and you hold the lower extremity of the instrument between her thighs
Deinde aperi manum tuam cum instrumento, sicut facis cum forficibus, aequaliter secundum quantitatem quam uis ex apertione oris matricis, donec faciat Obstetrix quod uult.	Then open your hand with the instrument, like you do with pincers, equally according to the quantity that you wish to open the mouth of the matrix, until the Obstetrician wishes to stop
Forma Vertiginis alterius quam dixerunt antiqui Forma Impellentis quo impellitur foetus.	The other form of the Vertigines which they said was like the Impelling Force which drives out the fetus.
Forma Almisdac, qua conteritur caput magnum: et assimilatur forcipi, cui sunt dentes in extremitate, sicut uides.	The form of the Almidach, which counteracts the large head: and it is assimilated to the forceps, which have teeth at the extremity, like these two things.
Et quandoque fit oblungum, sicut forcipes secundum hanc formam, sicut uides, cui sunt dentes sicut dentes serrae, quo inciditur et conteritur.	And when it is hooked, like the forceps following this form, like these two things, which have teeth like saw-teeth, with which it incides and counteracts
Forma Almisdac quo conteritur caput paruum.	The form of the Almidach which counteracts the small head
Forma Vncini habentis spinam unam.	The shape of the neighbour who has one spine.
Forma Vncini habentis spinas duas.	The form of the neighbor having spines two.
Forma forcipis cui sunt dentes serrae, cum quo conteritur caput foetus.	The form of the forceps which has teeth serrated, with which the head of the fetus is held.
Forma Spatumilis habentis duas extremitates ad abscindendum caput.	The form of the spatula having two extremities to bind the head
Forma duorum Spatumilium etiam latorum.	The form of two spatulas also of the hands
Ista instrumenta omnia exercentur, et quanto plus multiplicantur species eorum, et praeparata sunt apud artificem, est uelocior ad operationem suam, et altior apud homines, propter quantitatem suam.	These instruments are all used, and the more numerous their species, and the more they are prepared by the artificer, the more rapid is the operation and the greater is the benefit to men, on account of their quantity.
Non ergo despicies ex eis instrumentum, quin sit apud te praeparatum.	It does not behove you to despise any of these instruments, because they are prepared for you
Inexcusabilis est enim necessitas eorum.	Necessity compels them indeed
¶ De extractione Secundinae.	About the extraction of the second one
Caput LXXVIII.	Head seventy-eighth
Quando retinetur Secundina apud partum, tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmae, ut retineat anhelitum suum.	When the second one is retained at birth, then it is necessary to remove the lower ones, so that it may retain its breath.
Deinde fac eam sternutare cum condisi: et stringe manum tuam super os eius, et nares ipsius.	Then make a grasp with your thumb on its bone, and grasp its nostrils.
Si ergo egreditur per hoc, bonum est.	If it comes out through this, it is good
Si non: tunc accipe ollam, et perfora in coopertorio foramen: et pone in ea herbas aperientes os matricis, sicut calamentum, rutam, et anetum, et camomillam, et sseham, et cassiam ligneam, et centauream: accipe omnes istas herbas, aut quasdam earum, et submerge eas cum aqua, et pone eas super ignem.	If not: then grasp the head and perforate through the skull: and put in it herbs that will open the bone of the matrix, such as calamine, rue, and alum, chamomile, and saffron, and balsam, and cedar: grasp all of these herbs, or some of them, and immerse them with water, and put them over fire.
Deinde pone embulam arundinis super foramen coopertorii ollae, et extremitatem aliam in os matricis: et teneat eam donec perueniat uapor ad concauitatem matricis.	Then put a bundle of reeds over the hole of the skull, and the other extremity in the bone of the matrix: and hold it until the vapor has reached the cavity of the matrix
Deinde fac eam sternutare, sicut diximus.	Then make the incision as we have said.
Secundina enim egredietur cum facilitate.	The incision shall proceed easily from that point forward.
Si autem remaneat post hanc curationem, et non egrediatur: tunc praecipe Obstetrici, ut submergat manum suam in oleo sisamino, aut mucillagine alteae.	If, however, after this treatment, it still fails to proceed: then command the Obstetrician to immerse his hand in the navel-fat or in the thick mucus of the belly
Deinde intromittat in uuluam, et quaerat cum ea Secundinam.	Then insert the instrument into the wound and explore with it alongside the second incision
Cum ergo inuenerit eam, tunc accipiat eam, et extendat ipsam paulatim.	When you have found it, then grasp it and gradually expand it
Si autem fuerit annexa in profundo matricis, tunc intromittat manum, secundum quod narrauimus, donec quando inuenerit Secundinam, et extrahat eam paulatim secundum rectitudinem, ut non cadat matrix apud attractionem uehementem: imo oportet, ut permutetur cum facilitate ad latera dextra et sinistra: deinde addatur in quantitatem attractionis.	If, however, it is an appendix that lies deep in the belly: then insert the hand once more, as we have said, until you have reached the second incision. Then slowly withdraw the hand, following the natural direction, so as not to tear the matrix at the point of traction. It is better, however, to move the appendix to the right and left sides: then add some traction as well
Ipsa enim obedit tunc, et seruatur, et euadit ab adhaerentia.	The wound itself will now obey and be cured, and will depart from its adherence.
Quod si os matricis est coartatum, sicut nos iam narrauimus: cura eam cum sternutatione, et ex medicatione ollae cum herbis.	If the matrix is closed, as we have said: care for the wound with closure, and from an ointment jar with herbs.
Si autem non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc caue ne fatigeris super eam in iteratione extractionis.	If it still does not depart after all that we have said: then beware lest you tire yourself out in the process of its extraction
Verum oportet, ut quod egreditur ad os matricis ex ea, liges ad coxam mulieris.	It is true that it must come out at the os of the matrix to the woman's hip
Deinde clisteriza eam cum unguento tetrapharmacon.	Then bandage the wound with unguent tetrapharmacon
Ipsum enim putrefaciet eam post dies, et dissoluetur, et egredietur.	The wound itself will become rotten after a few days, and will then dissolve and depart
Verumtamen quando putrefit, eleuatur ex ea odor malus ad stomachum et caput, et laedit illud infirmam.	Indeed when it has become rotten, it will emit a bad odor from the stomach and head, and this will cause sickness.
Oportet ergo ut administrentur suffumigationes conuenientes ad illud.	It is necessary therefore that suitable fumigations be administered for that.
Quidam autem antiquorum iam experti sunt suffumigationem nasturtii, et ficuum siccarum.	Some of the ancients are experts in fumigation with naphtha and powdered alum.</start_of_turn>
Forma instrumenti quo suffumigatur mulier apud retentionem Secundinae et menstruorum.	The mode of the instrument with which a woman is fumigated for the retention of the second [menstrual] flow.</start_of_turn>
Fiat ex uitro simile alcama, aut ex zere: et ponatur extremitas ampla super ignem: et suffumigatio sit posita super prunas: teneat eam, donec consumatur illa suffumigatio: et itera aliam.	Let it be like an outpouring of milk, or from a horn: and the outer end shall be spread over the fire: and the fumigation shall be placed over the berries: let it remain there until the said fumigation has been consumed; and do it again.</start_of_turn
¶ De curatione Ani non perforati.	Concerning the care of an unpierced animal.</start_of_turn
Caput LXXIX.	Chapter LXXIX.</start_of_turn>
Nascuntur multi puerorum, et Ani eorum sunt non perforati, quos iam opilauit sifac subtile.	Many boys are born with their navels unpierced, whom I have seen to be nourished by fine oil.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo, ut obstetrix perforet illud sifac digito suo: et si non, perforet ipsum cum Spatumili acuto: et caueat lacertum, ne tangat eum.	It is necessary therefore that the midwife pierce that [navel] with her finger: and if not, pierce it with a fine needle: and beware of tears, lest it touch him.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam infusam in uino et oleo.	Then place upon it wool soaked in wine and oil.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum cum ungentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with nails until it is healed.</start_of_turn
Si autem times quod opiletur, tunc pone in foramine cannulam de plumbo diebus multis, et auferatur quando puer uult egerere.	If indeed it is to be done, then put in the hole a lead cannula for many days, and remove it when the boy wishes to go.</start_of_turn
Et iam accidit opilatio Ani etiam ex consolidatione uulneris, aut apostematis.	And it sometimes happens that the navel of an animal is pierced from the consolidation of the wound, or from the afterbirth.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut secetur illa consolidatio, deinde curetur cum eo quod diximus ex curatione et plumbo.	It is necessary therefore that you dry that consolidation, and then care for it as we said before concerning care and lead.</start_of_turn
¶ De curatione Fistularum quae accidunt in inferiori parte.	Concerning the treatment of fistulas that occur in the lower part.
Caput LXXX.	Concerning the treatment of fistulas that occur in the lower part.
Fistulae quae accidunt in inferiori, sunt Nodatio, et Grossitudo quae accidunt prope anum deforis: aut in spacio unius partium: et est Fistula una, aut plures.	Fistulas that occur in the lower part are of two kinds: Nodulation and Swelling which occur close to any bone, or in the space of one part: and are one fistula, or more.
Cum ergo antiquatur illa Nodatio, aperitur, et currit ex ea humiditas aquosa alba, aut pus subtile.	When the nodule has been thus removed, it is opened, and white watery moisture or subtle pus runs out from it
Et quandoque sunt ex istis Fistulis penetrantes.	And sometimes these fistulas are penetrating
Ergo penetrantes cognoscuntur per illud quod egreditur ex egestione, et uentositate, quando utitur infirmus egestione: et fortasse egreditur ex eis uermis.	Therefore they are recognized as penetrating by that which comes out with the evacuation, and by swelling, when the patient evacuates: and perhaps comes out through a worm.
Et sunt ex eis Fistulae quando sunt in spacio penetrantes usque ad uesicam, et usque ad meatum uirgae.	And there are fistulas when they are penetrating from the space until the bone, and until the marrow of the bone.
Et sunt ex eis penetrantes usque ad iuncturam coxae, et usque ad nodum caudae.	And they are penetrating from the space until the hip joint, and until the node of the buttocks
Ex eo autem quo cognoscitur Fistula penetrans usque ad anum, etiam a non penetrante, est, ut intromittas digitum tuum indicem in anum: et intromittas tentam subtilem in Fistulam ex aere, aut ferro: quando non est tortuositas.	From this, however, it is known that a penetrating fistula until a bone, even if not penetrating, is, as it were, that you insert your finger into the bone: and you insert a needle subtile into the fistula from the air, or from iron: when there is no curvature (of the bone).
Quod si in ea est tortuositas, tunc intromitte in eam tentam ex plumbo subtilem, aut pilum ex pilis equarum, donec sentias tentam, aut pilum in digito tuo.	When there is curvature in it, then insert into the bone a fine lead needle, or a hair from a horse's tail, until you feel the needle, or the hair in your finger
Quod si non sentis ipsam penitus, neque procedit ex foramine aliquid ex egestione, neque uentositas, neque uermis sicut dixi: tunc scias, quia est non penetrans: propera ergo ad curationem.	When you do not feel it penetrate, neither from a wound, nor from evacuation, nor swelling, nor a worm as I have said: then you know that it is not penetrating: do therefore the treatment correctly
Et quando Fistula est penetrans usque ad uesicam, aut ad meatum urinae: tunc significatio eius est exitus urinae ex ea, et prohibitio eius ab hoc ut consolidetur locus cum medicinis.	And when the fistula is penetrating until the marrow, or until the bladder: then the significance of it is the discharge of urine from it, and the prohibition of this from happening again until it has healed with the physicians.
Si uero est penetrans usque ad iuncturam coxae, aut ad os coxae: tunc signum eius est, quod perueniat tenta usque illuc, si non est in ea tortuositas usque ad os: et inuentio doloris in circumitu partis, et quod egreditur pus ex ea semper: et quod non ualeat in ea medicatio, neque consolidatur cum unguento.	If it has penetrated as far as the hip joint, or even to the bones of the hip: then its sign is that it proceeds until there, if there is no twist of the organ until the bones: and there is pain surrounding the part, and pus always comes out from it; and no medicine is useful for it, neither is it consolidated with ointment.
Et in istis Fistulis omnibus penetrantibus non est curatio omnino: et curatio earum est labor et uanitas ei, ex stultis medicis, super quem formatur.	In all these penetrating wounds there is no complete cure: the cure for them is toil and perseverance, from the fools of doctors, on whom they are formed.</start_of_turn>
In illa autem quae non est penetrans, et non antiqua, speratur sanatio cum serro: secundum quod ego narro tibi, et ego iam probaui: et est, ut iaceat infirmus inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et eleua crura eius usque supra coxas ipsius, et coxae eius sint inclinatae ad uentrem ipsius.	But in those which are neither penetrating nor old, hope of healing is expected with support: as I have said before, and as I have proved: that is, let the patient lie between your hands on his back: and lift his legs up to above his hips, and let his hips be inclined towards his belly.</start_of_turn>
Deinde intromittetentam plumbi, aut aeris, si est in Fistula tortuositas, donec scias ubi peruenit tenta.	Then introduce lead or air, if there is a twist in the fistula, until you know where the tentacle ends.</start_of_turn>
Si autem sentit eam infirmus circa anum, tunc oportet ut intromittas digitum tuum indicem in anum.	If, however, the patient feels around the limb something, then it is necessary to introduce your finger as a sign into the limb.</start_of_turn
Si ergo sentis in digito tuo tentam iam penetrasse per seipsam detectam, praeter quod sentias inter digitum tuum, et inter ipsum sifac, aut carnem: tunc ergo scias certe, quia est penetrans: non ergo labores in ea, quoniam non est eius sanatio, sicut diximus.	If you feel in your finger the tentacle which you have detected is penetrating, besides that which you feel between your finger and the flesh, or between the flesh and bone: then you know certainly that it is penetrating: no labour is to be done in it, because its cure is not that.</start_of_turn>
Dixerunt tamen, quia sanatur in quibusdam hominibus caro, et ex medicatione qua ei speratur iuuamentum, est, ut ignias cauterium subtile secundum amplitudinem Fistulae, sicut praecessit, et intromittas ipsum ignitum in Fistulam, donec perueniat circa anum.	They say that in some men the cure is in the flesh itself, and in the medicine which is expected to be of benefit, that is, to make a slight cautery according to the size of the fistula, as has been said before, and to introduce the flame into the fistula until it reaches around the limb.</start_of_turn
Deinde itera illud bis, aut ter, donec scias, quia iam adustae sunt omnes illae carnes additae filtratae, quae sunt similes cannulae pennae auis.	Then do it again twice or thrice until you know that all the added flesh, which is like the pennae of birds, has become soft.
Deinde cura illud cum liciniis inuolutis in butyro, donec egrediantur illae carnes, quae adustae sunt: deinde cura illud cum unguentis generantibus carnem et consolidantibus.	Then keep it bound with butter until the flesh has gone; then do it with unguents which generate flesh and consolidate it.
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est.	If it is healed, that is good.
Et si non, tunc non sanatur cum alia curatione unquam.	If not, it will not be healed by any other treatment.
Et si egreditur tenta, et non peruenerit usque ad digitum tuum, qui est in ano, et est inter ipsum et tentam uelamen spissum ex carne, aut sifac: et uides Fistulam in eo quod sequitur superficiem cutis, tunc seca cutem ab initio Fistulae, et tu uadis secando cum tenta quod est in fistula, donec perueniat secatio ubi peruenit tentae extremitas, et liberatur tenta et cadit.	If it comes out, and does not mend until it reaches your thumb which is in the year, and is between the thumb and the great toe, and there is a thick layer of flesh between them, and blood: then make an opening in that which follows the surface of the skin, then dry the skin from the beginning of the opening, and you dry with the thumb which is in the fistula until it comes away from the cutting edge, and the thumb is freed and falls off
Deinde mundifica illas carnes filtratas, quae assimilantur cannulae pennae auis, ut non remaneat ex eis aliquid.	Then soften those soft flesh which have become like the pennae of birds, so that nothing remains of them.
Si autem uincit te sanguis, et soluit inter te et inter operationem tuam ut seces illas carnes: tunc melius quod fit, et uelocioris iuuamenti, cauterizare eam cum igne, aut cum medicina acuta.	If however blood boils between you and the operation, and dissolves between you and the operation as you cut: then it is better to cauterize with fire or with sharp medicine.
Quoniam cauterium cum igne aggregat habitudines bonas, adustionem illarum carnium additarum, et abscisionem sanguinis, et exiccationem humiditatum.	For the cauterizing with fire brings together the good qualities, brings about the softening of the added flesh and the cutting off of blood, and dries out humours.
Deinde cura illud cum liciniis inuolutis in butyro, aut caulibus tritis, donec locus emittat pus, et egrediantur illae carnes adustae in pus.	Then keep it bound with butter or poultices until pus comes out, and the soft flesh becomes pus
Deinde cura tunc uulnus cum unguentis consolidatiuis, generantibus carnem duram: et sunt medicinae in quibus sunt stipticitas et exiccatio.	Then do it with strong unguents which consolidate and generate flesh: and these are medicines which have stypticity and drying power
Nam quando restaurantur, tunc iam sanatur: et non times iterationem.	When restoration is complete, then healing has occurred: and not through repeated attempts.
Si autem Fistula iam peruenit usque ad profundum ani, et elongatur a superfluitate corporis: tunc intromitte digitum tuum in anum, et inquire cum eo.	When, however, the fistula persists to the depth of the rectum, and is prolonged by the excess of the body: then insert your finger into the rectum and inquire about it.
Si ergo sentis tentam, et inter te, et inter eam est uelamen ex sifac, aut carne, et est propinqua penetrationi: tunc non est operatio in illo, nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	If, however, you feel resistance, and between you and the rectum there is either fat or flesh, and it is close to penetration: then there is no operation in that place, except according to the measure of trust and hope
Quod est, quia administratur in eo unus trium modorum: aut ut cauterizes ipsam, sicut diximus: aut seces eam, donec consequaris concauitatem eius, ut sit possibile tibi intromittere licinia, et curationem ex proximo.	For in that case one must employ three measures: either one cauterizes the same [fistula], as we have said: or one severs the vein, until you have obtained a flattening of it, so that it is possible for you to insert instruments, and to heal from the next time
Et non procedas multum cum sectione, ut non incidas lacertum continentem anum, et accidat super infirmum exitus egestionis absque uoluntate.	And do not proceed too much with the section, lest you cut through the mucous membrane of the rectum, and thereby cause an excessive discharge of blood without your consent.
Deinde cura illud cum eo quod diximus.	Then care for it as we have said
Fortasse enim sanabitur: aut elonges ipsum uelamen, et mundes ipsum postquam secas ipsum usque prope anum, sicut diximus, aut cum tenta, aut cum instrumento alio acutae extremitatis.	Perhaps it will heal by itself: or you will lengthen the vein, and dry it up after you have softened it, as we have said, or with the finger, or with an acute instrument.
Deinde mundifica illas carnes filtratas quae sunt in sectione, usque ubi potes cum perscrutatione.	Then soften the surrounding flesh which is in the section, until it becomes soft as with the mark of a scratch
Deinde conare restaurationem uulneris totius cum sectione, et orificio superiore ubi consolidatur: et remanet Fistula aperta in interiore parte anus, et erit leuius super infirmum.	Then try to restore the whole wound with the section, and the upper orifice where consolidation has taken place: and the fistula will remain open in the inner part of the rectum, and will be easier over the infirmity.
Et quandoque suitur Fistula secundum hunc modum: et est, quando intromittis tentam in Fistulam: et est in latere ani circa superficiem corporis cum cute et margine ani: tunc accipe tentam perforatae extremitatis, quae est sicut acus aleskef, id est, praeparantium coria, secundum hanc formam.
