Et postposita est curatio eius, donec fistulatum est crus, et facta sunt in eo orificia multa: quae omnia emittebant pus, et humiditates corporis.	And after the treatment was finished, when his knee was bound up, many holes were made in it: from which pus and moisture of the body came out
Curauit ergo ipsum multitudo medicorum circiter duos annos, et non fuit in eo sapiens in arte manus, donec uocatus sum, et uidi crus eius, et materias quae currebant ex illis orificiis cursu magno: etiam omne uiri corpus iam tabuerat, et color eius citrinus erat.	The doctors treated him for two years, but in this art there was no skill, until I came and saw his leg and the things which were coming out of his holes: for his whole body was pale, and his complexion was yellow
Intromisi ergo tentam in uno locorum orificiorum, et peruenit tenta ad os.	They tried to reach it in one place through a hole, and the attempt reached the bone
Deinde perscrutatus sum orificia omnia: et inueni ea peruenire ad se inuicem ex omnibus partibus cruris.	Then I examined all the holes: and I found that they went into each other from all parts of the leg.
Properaui ergo, et secui super unum illorum orificiorum, donec detexi partem ossis: et inueni ipsum corruptum: quod iam corrosum erat, et denigratum, et putruerat, et perforatum erat, donec penetrauerat usque ad medullam.	I treated him properly, and I sealed over one of those holes, until I found a piece of bone: and I found it corrupted: for it was rotten, and wrinkled, and had decayed, and had pierced through, until it had reached the marrow
Serraui ergo quod detectum est mihi, et praeparatum ex osse corrupto.	I saw that which was detected by me was prepared from the corrupted bone.
Et deputaui, quod non esset in osse nisi illa corruptio, quam abscidi, et serraui.	And I deemed that there was no benefit in the bone except for that corruption, which I cut off and sealed
Et ego iam eradicaueram eam.	And I will have eradicated it.
Deinde posui restaurationem uulneris cum medicinis consolidatiuis spacio longo.	Then I shall order the restoration of the wound with the help of solid physicians over a long space of time.
Et non est consolidatum.	It is not complete
Deinde tentaui, et detexi super os secundo supra detectionem primam: et inueni corruptionem continuam cum osse: et serraui quod apparuit mihi etiam ex illa corruptione.	Then I tried, and found on the second examination above the first: and I found continuous corruption with the bone: and I saw that even from that corruption there appeared to me something.
Deinde conatus sum restaurationem eius.	I will attempt to restore it
Et non est restauratum.	It is not restored
Detexi ergo super ipsum iterum, et non cessaui incidere os particulatim, et conari restaurationem eius: et non est restauratum, donec incidi ex osse circiter palmum unum, et extraxi illud cum medulla sua.	I found therefore above it again, and I did not cease to cut the bone piecemeal, and to try to restore it: and it is not restored, until I cut from the bone round about the palm of one hand, and I extracted that with the marrow itself
Deinde restauraui ipsum cum medicinis, et consolidatum est uelociter, et sanatum: et non fuit necessaria haec iteratio in operatione eius, et sectione ipsius, nisi propter dispositionem debilitatis infirmi, et paucitatem tolerantiae eius, et timorem meum super ipsum de morte: quoniam accidebat ei in omnibus horis ex superfluitate euacuationis syncopis mala.	Then I restored it with the physicians, and it was consolidated quickly, and healed: and there was no need for this repetition of the operation, and the section of it, except because of the weakness of the patient, and his little tolerance, and my fear of death for him, because it happened to him at every hour from the excessive evacuation of bad air.
Sanatus est ergo sanatione integra: et nata est in loco ossis caro dura, et bona facta est dispositio in corpore suo, et rediit uirtus eius: et conuersatus est in dispositionibus suis: et non fecit ei contrarietatem in ambulatione nocumentum omnino.	He is healed therefore with perfect healing: and was made in the place of the hard bone, and a good disposition was made in his body, and his strength returned: and he recovered his strength in his dispositions: and did not make him contradict in walking or writing at all
Si autem os eminens in loco corporis iam fractum est: tunc oportet ut serres ipsum, secundum hunc modum: et est: ut accipias ligamentum, et stringe ipsum in extremitate ossis eminentis: et praecipe alicui, qui extendat ipsum ad sursum: et pone ligamentum aliud ex lana grossius ligamento primo.	If however the prominent bone in the body is fractured: then it is necessary to bind it up according to this method: and that is: that you take hold of the ligament and bind the bone at the extremity of the prominent bone: and command someone to extend it upwards: and put another ligament of thicker thread than the first ligament.</start_of_turn>
Deinde liga ipsum super carne, quae est suh osse: et extende extremitatem eius, ut trahas carnem ad inferiora: et tu detegis carnem super locum quem uis serrare, ut non laedat Serra carnem.	Then bind the ligature above the flesh, which is on the bone: and extend its extremity, so that you may draw the flesh downwards: and you will see the flesh above the place where you wish to cut, so that it does not damage the flesh.
Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	Place a stick or board under the lower bone centrally: because when you make that, it does not prevent the cutting of the corrupted flesh.
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.	And it is necessary that the suture be above the corrupted place somewhat, so that there is not a depression of the corruption of the bone: and that it does not appear to the sense, and that it compels towards the suture of itself or something else
Quod si os est corruptum, et non est eminens, imo continuatur pars eius cum parte: et corruptio est in medio eius, aut in parte ipsius: tunc detege carnem ab omnibus partibus totam.	If the bone is corrupted and is not prominent, and the part is continued with the part: and the corruption is in the middle of it, or in the part itself: then remove the flesh from all the parts whole
Deinde pone lignum inferius.	Then place a stick below.
Postea serra illud ex parte prima, ubi est corruptio, donec continuetur Serratura ex parte altera: et sit Serratura secundum longitudinem a corruptione parumper, secundum quod diximus.	Then cut that from the first part where the corruption is, until the suture continues from the other part: and let the suture be according to the length of the corruption somewhat, as we said
Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	If the corruption is at the juncture, cut the corrupted juncture itself, and cut the bone where the other part continues
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	If indeed the corruption is in the continuation of two junctions, then it is not in it without abrasion
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	If the corruption is in the palm of the hand, or in the palm of the foot: then things are difficult there.
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	But it is necessary to inquire about the nature of the corruption as it appears to you.
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	And scrape it off, and cleanse it as much as you are able, and with whatever skill you can manage: when it does not make you contradict a vein or a nerve.
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	You know that incisions and sutures are many for this bone, according to the position of the bone, its preparation, its size, its smoothness, its magnitude, its fineness, and its hardness.
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Therefore it is necessary to prepare an instrument appropriate for each type of operation for that operation.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	You know that these operations are significant to you above the kind of instrument that you do not know when you have long studied it.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And the knowledge of the methods of this art is a proof of the knowledge of the methods of treatment: for then you will find for yourself what is suitable for every sickness from the instruments.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	And I am firm in the last of this chapter concerning the number of instruments that you place as examples for those that you cut, and the trial which you will experience on others.
Forma Serrae.	The shape of the sutures.
Forma alterius Serrae.	The shape of the other sutures
Forma Serrae alterius.	The shape of the other sutures once more.
Forma Serrae alterius.	The shape of the other sutures yet once more
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This shape of suture is made in the middle
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Let its arc be towards the upper part, its point from the iron: and its handle from the horn, and make it pyramid-shaped in the middle
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	The shape of the connected sutures.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	Let the head of this suture be according to the shape of the head of the star: and its points according to the shape of the needles of the embroidery
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it does not fit, unless it is that they are rough against each other when they are broken, or the bone is wide and large.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	Greater form of Rasassa.
Forma medii Rasorii.	Greater form of Rasassa.
Forma Rasorii lati.	Greater form of Rasassa
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	Greater form of Rasassa in which there is a concavity.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	Greater form of the other Rasassa is subtle
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	Greater form of the other Rasassa is blunt at the extremities
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	Greater form of the little, subtle Rasassa
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	Greater form of Rasassa like that in which bones are cut
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	Greater form of the great Rasassa too
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This is like Radio, and the extremity is like a saw: it is shown in many places because of the reason for the bones
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	Greater form of Rasassa which agrees with the reason for its perforation by bones
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	Its extremity is triangular, and the extremity is acute
Fit ex Indi.	Like that of the Indians
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And it should be like that, as for all that we have said of Rasassa, Incision, and Saw
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	As for the incision of the extremities, and the suture of bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	Chapter 89.</start_of_turn>
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	Extremities putrefy, either from an external cause, or an internal one.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	When therefore you have treated the cause of the corruption with medical treatment, and it does not heal: and if you do not cut off the corruption in the limb, without which nothing helps: then you must cut off that limb until the corruption has ceased, so that the patient may be saved from death, or from the greater defect of the limb.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign which indicates that this has happened is that the limb is blackened, until it is consumed by fire or putrefies after blackness: until that putrescence occurs up to and including that which follows the limb, and spreads throughout the body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	And thus with its incision, and similarly if the cause of the corruption is a blow from some venomous creatures: as the scorpion of the sea, and the viper, and the spider, and those of a similar kind.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If therefore the corruption or the blow is at the extremity of the finger, then cut off the finger, and do not leave any space for the corruption, but drive it right up to the remainder of the hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And similarly if it happens in the hand, then cut off the hand from the root of the bone, and do not leave any space for the corruption, until it has seized in the bone of the forearm.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it reaches the arm, then cut off the arm at the elbow in its joint
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	But if the corruption has passed beyond this, and you see it surrounding the elbow: then in that is the death of the patient.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And to manage besides this from the cure is the quantity of medicine.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And thus do the same with the foot, when the corruption reaches the toe, then cut it off at one of the joints: and if it has reached the heel, then cut off the whole foot
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	If however it reaches the knee, then cut off the leg at the knee joint
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	And if the corruption has passed above the knee, then it is not in that there is any remedy, except dismissal, and leaving the patient to die.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the way to cut off a limb, or to save it, is as follows: tighten the ligaments in the lower part which you wish to cut: and tighten the ligament above in the place of that which you have cut
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And extend the minister of one ligament to the lower parts: and extend the minister of another ligament to the upper parts.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And thou shalt separate the flesh which is between two ligaments, with a broad spatula, until the whole flesh be detached
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then it is cut, or it is returned back
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	And it is necessary that thou put on all parts of the linen cloth, and that thou avoid the place of health: and thou must add to the infirm wound, and the swelling must be cooled.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	If indeed there should flow forth blood within the work, then thou must cauterize the place quickly: or put upon it some powder which will absorb the blood
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to thy medication until it be complete.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind up the wounded limb with a ligament which is suitable for it, and care for it until it be healed.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I say unto thee that this happened to me in my foot, thus did this happen to me
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	That is, because it happened to me in my foot in the night, with a wound which assimilates the heat of fire: and the corruption of that first happened in my finger, until the whole foot was affected
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	I did therefore extract the man from his suffering, after I had cut away the corruption of the limb with its disease, which appeared from pain and inflammation: and I cut it at the junction, and it was healed
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after a long time had passed, it happened to him again in the finger of his hand at the index finger.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	He came to me, and I attempted to cure her with the things which I placed upon her hand after the cleansing of her body: and the superfluity did not cease, but began to proceed into another finger: until the corruption reached the hand itself
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	He called me to do it: to make an incision in his hand. I did not wish to do it, hoping that from me would come the return of his superfluous [tissue]: and I was also afraid of death itself at the hand of the incision in his hand.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	Because the patient was very sick.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	When he had despaired of me, he returned to the earth: and he came to me again, because he was in urgent need, and he made an incision in his whole hand: and he was healed.</start_of_turn>
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	I do not assent to this narrative, except as an aid to this ailment of this kind: and as a meaning to be understood, and according to how it is done.</start_of_turn>
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	On the treatment of bones, and the quality of blistering with physicians.</start_of_turn>
Caput XC.	Chapter 90.</start_of_turn>
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When a swelling occurs in some limb by a wound, and the swelling persists until collection of pus has taken place: then the swelling is broken, or pierced, and the pus which is in it is ejected, and that which is left is like a wound: and the skin which is over it is like a thin membrane: and it does not reach its utmost corruption, neither does it affect bone, nor nerve, nor ligament: it is called a sinus and not a fistula, unless its space is prolonged, until corruption affects some part of the limb, then it is called a fistula or swelling.</start_of_turn
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	Its care is that you cut through the whole skin as it is turned back: and especially when it is thinned out, and made like a membrane: and trust that it will not adhere to the place, because of its corruption.</start_of_turn
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	If, however, you hope that the skin will adhere, and that this is not the final consequence of the corruption: and if there is hardness in the skin from the flesh: then treat it with blistering: and consider it as a sinus.</start_of_turn
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	If it is great, and the pus which issues from it is foetid of odor: then clench it with Egyptian medicine, which is vinegar, oil, and alum, equal parts, gathered in a vessel: and boil them over fire until the medicine turns red. Then comes in the thickness of honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take from it what is necessary: and dissolve it with water and honey, and clench it with vinegar: and string its orifice, and discharge the medicine into it in the quantity of two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then draw it out with pressure: do this for several days, until the sinus is healed, and the odor is gone.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And when it is clenchied with vinegar and water of ashes, when it is not present this medicine: then take ashes of wood chips, or ashes of the ilex tree: and sprinkle them on water.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then boil the water, and clench it with these things, until you are confident that the sinus is healed.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	If the patient does not tolerate vinegar, or water of ashes, then clench it with water and honey, to which something of ground alum has been added
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or clench it with honey and wine mixed together, because of the property of honey to heal, and to cleanse: and the wine makes the sinus adhere, especially when there is an excess of astringency and dryness in it.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	When you have done this often, and are confident that the corruption of the sinus has passed away: then clench it with something which makes flesh grow in it
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And it is good to take from aloe of Spain: and dissolve it with rose oil and wine: or clench it with some medicine, and anoint with others, of whose properties are written in the treatise on unguents.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	If the orifice of the sinus is strict, so that a cannula will not pass through it, then enlarge it with a small iron [instrument]: or place within it a piece of lint soaked in Egyptian unguent, or in basilicon unguent, until it is enlarged.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And similarly if the orifice is also wide, then close its lips with sutures: and discharge from it the amount that enters the bladder without adding anything.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And similarly if pus comes from that orifice, it is elevated upwards: then dry it in the hollow place which is in it, so that it comes out from there downwards: for pus when coarsened in the depth of the sinus, hinders the generation of flesh in that place.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	And if it is not possible to dry the sinus round about downwards as you wish: then attempt to prepare the limb with the preparation which brings out pus easily as you prepare it.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Attempt to discharge all the pus from it entirely: and take solidified medicines which are placed above the sign, suitable for that which you wish
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And extend these things over the edge of the wound.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And let the size of the wound be such as to permit communication of the whole sinus.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then cut with scissors directly at the orifice of the sinus with a larger opening of the sinus at the same time.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then extend from the soft parts above the wound, according to the size of the hole: and place it over that in a long position from the orifice of the sinus, so as to relieve the discharge of pus from that place: and do not make the wound large, except after a few days when one wishes to do so.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	He who is above the orifice of the sinus must move in every hour, so that it may go out what is gathered in it from the pus: and that you may know whether that which comes out of it is much or little: or digested or undigested
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And thus again consider the place of the sinus itself, whether in it does the master himself feel pain, or is there no pain in it, and whether there is swelling in it, or is there no swelling in it.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	When you have proceeded thus with your treatment in this way, and you have washed the material which issues from the orifice of the sinus, then you will know whether the sinus is adhered, or is approaching adherence: then indeed you must resolve it in the mane, or on the third day. And when you have resolved the ulcer, then exchange the dressing and renew the unguentum.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	If, however, it issues from the sinus after a long space of time with a slight discharge, then you must not despair of its adherence, for its healing approaches, because there are men who are slow to generate flesh in their ulcers, and there are those who act contrariwise to this.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	If, however, it issues from the sinus after many days with undigested pus, then you know that the sinus is not adhered.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	If, therefore, the adherence of the sinus is delayed and its condition is prolonged: then add to the medication drying agents, truly making the doctors do so, that there may be moisture in their body and dryness in their sweat: like alum, when added to fat, it makes fat dry.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from the last thing which is to be done, that you take alum and dissolve it with rosewater, and apply it over the old wound equal in amount to the body of the wound.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then cover it with that, and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And thus it is done like this, when there is no alum available, honey, when you dissolve it, until it is absorbed, and with it the other things that are in it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Take myrrh, aloes, and olibanum: mix them all together, and sprinkle that over honey while it is over the fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then smear upon the vessel itself, and bind it upon the Sinus: and smear with the honey which you have boiled, until it is thick: and sprinkle upon it the aforesaid things, and place upon the vessel itself, and bind it.</start_of_turn>
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And when it is administered in that vessel, long are the aristolochia and the roots of lilies of heaven, and is lily: and barley of herbs, and centaurea.</start_of_turn>
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use either simple or compound things, mix them together: sprinkle that over honey as I have said, and use that.</start_of_turn>
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	If, however, the condition of the Sinus is prolonged and does not heal by this treatment: then you know that there is corruption in its depth: or that it makes an imprint in the bones, or in the other hard parts, or ligaments: then care for the fistula according to what has been said before.</start_of_turn
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	Of the care of panaritius and nails drawn out, and incision of the finger added, and section.</start_of_turn
Caput XCI.	Chapter 101.</start_of_turn>
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	Panaritius is a swelling which arises under the nail of the thumb of the hand, or foot: and perhaps arises in the other fingers.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	When, however, its duration is prolonged, and it is neglected in its treatment, and a swelling arises from the swelling, or it is corrupted, and pus is emitted, until it corrupts the root of the nail: and perhaps it corrupts the whole thing, and perhaps the corruption extends to the bone, until there is a foul odor: and the extremity of the finger becomes wide, and its color becomes dark.</start_of_turn
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When you are treating yourself, as we have said before, and the cure does not take effect: then it is necessary that you cut off with the sword the entire superfluous part which remains from the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the nail afterwards.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	The cautery is useful for nails which are inflamed.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	If indeed the bone is sound, and the nail is also sound, and the swelling of the nail has become excessive, and it bites itself, and causes pain: then it is necessary to place radium beneath the nail at an angle where it bites the flesh, and push it upwards: and cut away the flesh easily, and place upon it what remains of the flesh from the burning and corrosive medicines until it has disappeared entirely
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with unguents until it is healed
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	If however corruption has set in the bone, then it is necessary to cut away that bone and extract it: for it will never heal as long as it remains corrupted in that bone
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	If you see the corrosion and corruption advancing in the finger: then cut it off at one of its joints, as has been mentioned previously concerning its reminder.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it is healed.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	If however there occurs to the nail attrition or percussion: and it brings about pain which is unbearable: then it is necessary to perform a bloodletting in the first instance.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then dry the nail with sharp Spatumil from above downwards to the end.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And be careful, lest the cutting should reach the flesh which is under the nail, for you will thereby cause the addition of further pain to the already existing pain, and will be the cause of the corruption of the flesh in that place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then care for the place with that which sits down the pain.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	Then care for the place with that which sits down the pain.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	Then care for the place with that which sits down the pain.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	Then care for the place with that which sits down the pain
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	Then care for the place with that which sits down the pain, that is, as you would an Incision with a Spatulum.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	Then care for the place with that which sits down the pain, that is, as you would an Incision with a Spatulum. The care of that which is born in the root of the junction is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Then care for the place with that which sits down the pain. Abstain from its Incision.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	Then care for the place with that which sits down the pain. In that which is born at the end of the fingers, then it is necessary to Incline in the first meat of it by a circular Incision until you reach the bone.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then care for the place with that which sits down the pain. Then saw the bone with one saw compatible with this.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for the place with that which sits down the pain. Then care for the thing itself until it is healed.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	Then care for the place with that which sits down the pain. Consolidation which happens to the fingers because of the wound or by the nature of man himself, that is, because it is born with it, or from the consolidation of the wound, or from burning fire, and similar things.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	Then care for the place with that which sits down the pain. It is necessary to dissect that consolidation, until the fingers return to their natural form
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then care for the place with that which sits down the pain. Then put between them pins, or soak with infused lead in rose water: so that they do not solidify too quickly, and separate between them: or put between them a thin sheet of lead, until the place is consolidated as it should be
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And similarly, if consolidation has occurred in some fingers with the palm, then dry that consolidation, according to what is prepared and agrees with the figure of the limb.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	Of incisions for wounds.
Caput XCII.	Chapter XCII
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	There are veins which are involved, large and full of melancholic superfluities that happen in various parts of the body: and most frequently in the legs, especially in those of travelers and laborers, and those who bear burdens.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	It is necessary therefore that you manage the exclusion of the body from black bile somewhat forcefully with an expulsion.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then let a bloodletting be made from the patient with ease by means of a balsam.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	The treatment of these with iron is in two ways
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	One is that it be cut through, and the black blood be extracted
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	The other is that the vein be elevated and the whole of it extracted
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	The cutting of it is done in this way
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	Embalm the ankle at first with warm water much, until the thick blood is resolved
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then bind the ankle of the sick from the upper part of the thigh down to the lower part of the knee with a strap
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then dry the vein in one place, or two, or three wide sections
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then elevate, that is, extract the blood from the lower part of the leg up to the upper part, and from the upper part let the patient bleed in the first place
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then dry the limb until the quantity of blood that has bled out is equal to what is needed for the treatment, and as much as the patient can tolerate
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	After the ligature is made: and command him to abstain from foods that generate black bile: and repeat the enema and phlebotomy when the veins are full, for this will be harmful to the patient.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	The elevation of the limb is done in this way.</start_of_turn>
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	If there are many hairs on the limb of the patient, shave them off.</start_of_turn>
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then immerse the limb in a bath: or embroider it in the limb with warm water, until it turns red, and swell the veins: or perform a strong exercise, if there is no bath available, until the limb is warmed.</start_of_turn>
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then dry the skin along the course of the vein: or at its end near the knee, or at its end near the heel.</start_of_turn
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with hooks, and scrape the vein from all sides, until sensation is restored: and it is known when sensation returns, that the bile has been evacuated from the vein.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When the blood has gone out of the skin, the surgeon should wipe off the blood as if it were a cord.</start_of_turn
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then place under it radium, until it rises up and comes out of the skin: suspend the blood with a piece of gauze, soft.</start_of_turn
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then dry the other side near that three fingers away.</start_of_turn
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then scrape the skin from the upper part of the vein, until sensation appears.</start_of_turn
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then raise the limb with the radium as before, and suspend the blood with another piece of gauze, as you did at the beginning.</start_of_turn
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then dry the other side, or several other sides, if necessary.</start_of_turn>
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then elevate it, and pierce the last part near the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then extract the bone to the part which is above the sole of the foot.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	Do this until you have extracted the bone from the higher sections, until all bones have gone out: then pierce the bone
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	If, however, it does not obey you for extracting and elevating: then insert a sharp needle with a strong thread, and bind the bone, and extract it: or insert under it radium: and move your hand over every part, until it comes out
Et caue, ne incidatur.	Take heed, lest you pierce it
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if you pierce it, it becomes difficult to elevate the bone again, and it enters through that wound.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	When you have extracted the whole bone: then place over the wound a soaked wool bandage in wine and rose oil, or oil: and care for it, until it is healed
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	If the vein is contracted, having a twist which has to do with parts, and is not like what we said according to the straight line: then you must find over the bone to every part of the twist of it, and the place of the twist itself
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then suspend the bone with needles, until you have elevated the whole bone: and take heed at your incision on the bone so that you do not pierce the vein, or wound it: for it is difficult to elevate or extract the bone again
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Be prudent in this matter.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	Make the incision in such a way that the vein heals.
Forma Vncini caeci.	Leave the surrounding area clean
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It has no acute extremity like the rest of the incisions, and is not of a fine character, so as not to wound the vein: and it has a large flexibility, gentle: for if it were fine, it would wound the vein by its slightness: and if it were of a large size, like this, it would be useless
De extractione Venae cruris.	On the extraction of the vein of the thigh.
Caput XCIII.	On the extraction of the vein of the thigh.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is generated in the thighs in warm lands, like Alizegi and Arabia, and in dry and warm lands, few in number, for in them no herb or tree grows.</start_of_turn>
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	It is also perhaps generated in other parts of the body besides the thighs.</start_of_turn
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	And its generation is from the putrefaction which happens under the skin, like that which happens within the bodies of serpents and worms, and worms generated between the skin and the flesh.</start_of_turn
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of the commencement of this vein is inflammation in the thigh which is painful.</start_of_turn
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then the place is to be dried.</start_of_turn
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein is to be extracted from the place of its drying, like the root of a plant, or an animal.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	When it appears from this extremity, then it is necessary to cover over the lead with leaden weights whose weight is from a drachma to two drachmas and a node: and let go of the lead weight from the thigh.</start_of_turn
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	Whenever it comes out from that to the exterior, cover it in lead and tie it down.</start_of_turn
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	If it persists for a long time, then cut off a part of it, and cover the rest.</start_of_turn
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not cut through the root before it has come out whole.</start_of_turn
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you cut through it, it contracts and enters the flesh: and causes inflammation, and gangrene in the place, and a bad ulcer.</start_of_turn
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Wherever it is necessary, it should be gently evacuated, and drawn out gradually, until nothing remains within, and that nothing remains in the body: and from this vein, in some men, there comes out that which is equal in length to five palms and ten fingers.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And thus it is with me, because the urine has gone out of twenty palms.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	But if it happens to you in the hour of your medication: then insert radium into its cavity, and perforate the cavity with a needle as long as the body, until all that is in it is evacuated: and administer the putrefaction of the place with the physicians for a few days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then care for the aftercare of the wound.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And this vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears at the junction of the foot, or in the foot itself: and it has many outlets, and comes out of every outlet branch.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Care for it in this way, as we said in the previous discourse, and as we have said before
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	Of the cutting above the worms generated under the skin, and it is called the bovine disease.
Caput XCIIII.	Chapter XCIV.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This disease is called in this land among us the bovine disease: because it often happens to bulls, and is a small worm which is born between the skin and the flesh
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And it goes throughout the body, ascending and descending: and it is seen by the sense when it walks from limb to limb, until it bursts in the place where it bursts through the skin at the location, and comes out
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its generation is from the decay of some humors.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	As worms and serpents do, so too do lumbrici and ascarides within.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	They are mischievous like serpents and worms.</start_of_turn>
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	For when it itself enters the body, and rises to the head, and proceeds to a place: then it may well burst open there and go out, and destroy the eye: and such an event happens often.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	When it is thus to be treated and removed, it is not to be omitted from its walking and its sensation.</start_of_turn>
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	It is necessary therefore to bind that which is above it and that which is below it with a strong ligature.</start_of_turn>
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry over it and remove it.</start_of_turn
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	If it has gone deep into the flesh and you do not find it: then place above the place a burn with fire until it dies.</start_of_turn
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And greater than this is the corruption of its matter, which corrupts the eye, as we have said.</start_of_turn>
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	If however you find it to have gone up to the head near the eye: then bind under it over the eyebrow a good strong ligature.</start_of_turn
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry over it and remove it.</start_of_turn
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And it is necessary that the sick man should take care of the purification of his body, with doctors who will dissolve harmful humors.</start_of_turn
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And let him beware of foods that generate putrefaction.</start_of_turn
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	About the section above the navel, Nakir.</start_of_turn
Caput XCV.	Chapter XCV.</start_of_turn>
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This ailment is known in our land as Nakir: and it is a pain which happens in some members: and then changes from member to member.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	I myself have seen this, as I have told you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was called to a woman who was sick in some village
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And I found her arm swollen, and I saw a swelling in the groin of her arm
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after an hour had passed, I saw that the swelling had increased in size like a worm, ascending towards her shoulder more quickly than is possible: like silver that is running from one place to another
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	The pain thus withdrew from that place and settled in the shoulder
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	And an hour later it had spread throughout the rest of the body, until it reached the other arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	And she told me that it had disappeared throughout her whole body, as I saw
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	I was amazed at the speed of its change from member to member
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And I had never seen such an ailment before in my life in the same way as this
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	However, I have heard of many people who suffer from a pain that changes from member to member: but I have never seen anything like this before.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	I do not believe this is possible, except perhaps because of the woman's position in the village: hence it appears that the pain has been transmitted from the lower parts of the body to the upper parts.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	It is necessary that this does not appear in delicate people and those with moist bodies, in whom the hidden veins are more easily affected.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	When therefore the physician has finished his treatment and the patient still feels pain, if it be apparent to the physician's eye, as we have said, then he should bind above and below the painful part with greater force: and he should dry above the painful part until the swelling has subsided; and he should cauterize the spot.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	If, however, he does not see it with his eyes: then he must treat it with an outward dressing, and with that which drives out the swelling, and he must rub it with unguents of foetid herbs and of serapion, and like things.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	(The provided text does not include the continuation of the sentence regarding the extraction of arrows, so I cannot provide a translation for it.)
Caput XCVI.	Chapter XCVI.</start_of_turn>
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows are varied according to their kind and according to the place from which they are drawn from the body.</start_of_turn>
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	And their variety is such: because some have large spines and some have small; and some are concave and some are convex.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And some have three angles.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And some have tongues.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And some have stars.</start_of_turn
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	As for those which are according to the limbs in which they are found, there are two ways.</start_of_turn
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	Or the limbs are from those which are concave in their main parts, such as the brain, and the heart, and the spleen, and the lung, and the kidneys, and the intestines, and the bladder, and things like these.</start_of_turn
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	When therefore it falls into any of these limbs, and it appears to you that there is a sign of death, as I shall tell you afterwards, then it is necessary to draw out that arrow from the limb, for death follows its wound in many arrangements.</start_of_turn
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	When the signs of illness are not apparent, and the arrow is not hidden in the depth of the limb, then extract it and care for the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	When the signs are absent and the arrow has penetrated the bone, and comes out upon the brain, it is: because from that there arise vomiting, spasms, swelling, redness of the eyes, diarrhea, redness of the tongue, spasm, and mixture of the intellect, and vomiting of bile.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood will issue from the nostrils or ears
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps speech will be severed, and the voice will be destroyed
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And there will issue from the wound a white moisture resembling pus
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And there will come out from it like the discharge from a wound
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If, however, these signs appear, then abstain from treatment, and extract the arrow if it does not come out.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of an arrow that has fallen into the cord are: that it is itself near the left breast: and that it feels as though it is fixed in something hard, not in something soft.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the arrow is in motion like the pulse: and blood flows from the wound black.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And follows this coldness of the extremities, and cold sweat, and fainting.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	You know therefore that death approaches with doubt.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	The sign of an arrow that has pierced the lung is the discharge of bloody foam from the wound: and the after-effects which follow the collarbone become swollen and change color of the patient.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And the great and high spirit departs: and it seeks the attraction of cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	If an arrow falls into the chest, that is near the flanks: then it is close to the back parts: and it makes a great sigh with pain and aspiration, with a gasp: and it moves all the limbs of the arms.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if an arrow falls into the stomach: then perhaps it will come out through the wound from some undigested food
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if an arrow falls into the belly, and it lies there: something of stool, or bile, or intestine which has been broken will come out through the wound
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	There is no hope in the cure of it, neither in the extraction of the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	If an arrow falls into the bladder, and urine comes out: and something comes out from it to the outside, and the pain is stronger over the sick person: then you know that it is deadly
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	The rest of the limbs, such as the face, and the neck, and the gut, and the palate, and the attendants, and the scapulae, and the ribs, and the shoulder, and the thigh, and the ankle, and the heel, and similar members: when it does not find the arrow an artery or a nerve: and there is no venomous arrow.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I tell you that I have heard that there are many such arrows, that you may know about the cure for it
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	That is, because I take care that the arrow may fall into the tear of his eye, or in the root of his nose
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	I extracted it for him from the other side, under the fat of his ear: and he was healed, and no wound remained in his eye
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I extracted another arrow from a Jew, which had fallen into the fat of his eye under his lower eyelid: and the arrow was hidden, and I did not find its tip from it, since it was stuck in its wood: and it was a great arrow of the Turks, with lead, in which there were no ears.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	The healed man is indeed a Jew, and no evil thing has befallen his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I have drawn out another arrow from the belly of a Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	It was an Arab arrow, and this is the one which has ears.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	Behind it [the arrow] on the same side between two ribs: and it was submerged in his belly
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	I have been careful with her [the arrow] until I have extracted it: and the Christian is healed
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I have drawn out another arrow which had fallen into his belly: and we thought that it would surely kill him
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	When thirty days had passed by and nothing had changed in his condition from before concerning his disposition, behind the arrow: we considered concerning the arrow, and I drew it out: and he was healed, and no evil thing befell him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw a man whose arrow had fallen in his back, and his wound was closed over the arrow
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	When seven years had passed by, the arrow was extracted from the root of his hip bone.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And I saw a woman whose arrow had fallen into her belly, and her wound was closed over the arrow, and the arrow remained inside her: and no change occurred in her condition from her natural operations.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And I saw another man whose arrow had fallen on his face: and his wound was closed over, and the arrow remained, without causing him much pain: and similar things happened often
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I drew out an arrow from the king's head, which had fallen in the middle of his nose, and it had inclined towards the right side: and the arrow was completely hidden
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	I am called therefore to care for him until three days after the case of the arrow.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	I find the wound of the arrow strict and swollen upwards
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	I questioned him concerning the pain with a subtle touch, and he did not feel it: and even I found that he had a puncture wound and pain on his right side
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I hope that it is the wound of the arrow which is the cause of the puncture
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	I plastered the place with a plaster which had an attractive and digestible powder, confident that the wound would dry up, and that I would see a sign of the arrow, that is to say that the tip of the arrow would remain on the surface: and it did not happen in the place of the accident that the arrow had followed the wound to the place.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	I remained with the plaster for many days: and it did not happen that there was an accident, and the wound became consolidated in the meantime: and he remained unable to extract the arrow until he felt the arrow enter his nose on a certain day.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me that.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	I placed above it an acute medicine which was corrosive for many days: and when I finally touched it, and felt the tip of the arrow which was adhering to the wood
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then I added to the opening of the wound by that acute medicine until we saw the tip of the arrow clearly: and it passed from us after that for about four months
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then when the wound had healed, and it was possible for me to introduce forceps into the wound, and to move it, and it did not obey my order to go out: then I did not cease to touch it, and I devised various methods for it on the surface of the wound, until on a certain day I put on the wound with forceps that were well-made, following their form at the end of the chapter, until I extracted the arrow.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I restored the limb.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And the physicians say that the cartilage of the nose is not restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	I restored it therefore, and the limb was consolidated, and the illness was healed whole: nothing further was required of it.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I tell you the manner in which I extracted some arrows: in order that you may know the rule and the signification of this which I have not said
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	For the parts of this art and their distinctions are not comprehended by narration: neither does this book comprehend them, and a prudent craftsman compares them with little to much: and with that which is present, with that which is absent: and he finds a new operation and a new instrument among the descent of things extraneous to this art when these occur
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say therefore, that arrows do not depart from the limbs in which they are fixed, except according to two ways.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or by drawing out from the place from which they entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or by counter-drawing out a part of the other
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And whatever comes out from where it entered, whether it is an arrow proceeding in a fleshy place: it is drawn out and comes out.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	If it does not obey the coming out from the hour in which it fell: then it is necessary that you wait a few days, until the carrion which is around it has become putrid: and you will alleviate the drawing out of it, and its going out
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And in like manner if it is fixed in bone, and does not obey you concerning coming out: then you must also wait a few days: and repeat the drawing out and the motion every day, until it comes out
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	If it does not obey you concerning coming out after days: then it is necessary that you perforate all around the arrow in the very bone with a fine thread, until the arrow is amplified
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then draw the loop, and draw it out.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	If, however, the arrow is fixed in the bone of the head, and has gone forward into one of the ventricles of the brain, and if any of the accidents which I mentioned appear on the diseased side: then abstain from drawing the arrow, and withdraw the loop, until it is equal to the former state.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow continues until the ear, then the life is not prolonged thereby
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.
