If the arrow is not fixed in the body of a bone only, but does not penetrate as far as the ear: and if the patient remains sick for some days without any of the accidents having happened to him: then proceed with the drawing of the arrow and its extraction
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	If, however, it is fixed firmly and does not obey your drawing: then apply pressure around the arrow as I have told you before: then care for the place, until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	If, however, the arrow has gone completely away from the body, and is hidden and covered from the sense: then inquire about the loop with a hook.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If you feel the loop, then draw the loop with some instruments that are suitable for its drawing.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	If, however, you are unable to do so because of the constriction of the wound, and because of the length of the arrow in the depth: and there is no bone, no nerve, or blood vessel there: then find over the loop until the wound is enlarged, and it is possible to extract the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	If there are ears which hold the flesh fixed in the bone from all sides, all by means which you can think of, and if you can think of nothing which can liberate them except the fracture of the ears and their torsion: then leave them alone
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	When you perform the extraction of the arrow in any place, then use the twisting of your hand, with forceps to all parts, until you have made the loop leave: and take away the last little bit slowly, so that the arrow is not broken, and that its drawing and extraction are not difficult.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	If it is not possible to complete the procedure within an hour, then defer it for a few days until the surrounding tissues have decayed.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then repeat the procedure: if it is causing excessive bleeding, stop the procedure until the bleeding has ceased. Then perform what we have said in the chapter on wound management. Guard your virtue from the incision of a vein, nerve, or cord.</start_of_turn>
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	Perform the procedure in every way that you can to facilitate healing of the arrow: do so with ease, tranquility, or slowly and steadily, as I have said.</start_of_turn>
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And it is necessary that you draw out the arrow so that the patient remains in the same position as before the arrow was placed, as it is with the case of the arrow itself.</start_of_turn
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	For it is more harmful to leave the arrow in than to draw it out.</start_of_turn>
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	If it is not possible to draw out the arrow, then perform what you can from the figure.</start_of_turn
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	The arrow which comes out from the opposite side of the body, or which proceeds from that to the exterior: or it makes a swelling at the extremity of the arrow in the sense from the upper part of the skin close to it, and raises up the surrounding: dry therefore above the wound, and make an incision according to the amount that can be grasped with the forceps.</start_of_turn
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then draw out the arrow: it will come out easily by itself.</start_of_turn
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	If it is retained in the bone, then turn your hand according to the circumference, until you press the arrow into the bone, and expand it: then draw it out.</start_of_turn
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: defer the procedure for a few days: then repeat the procedure until it comes out.</start_of_turn
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	If the bowwood is in it, then push it out with the same.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	If the bowwood has broken, and you wish to give it an impulse: then introduce into the instrument a concave instrument, so that its concavity may fill the cavity of the bowwood: then push out the bowwood with the same.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	If the bow is concave, then push out the bow with the instrument that enters it.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	The bow will straighten itself by that.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	If the bow is poisonous, then it is necessary to cut off the whole flesh in which the poison is: if this is possible
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then take care of the bow with the thing that agrees with it.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	If the bow has fallen in the chest, or in the belly, or in the groin, or on the side: and it is close to the thing which you touch with your finger, and it is possible to cut above the wound: then cut, and burn from the incision of the vein, or nerve, and take out the bow.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then drain the wound, if there is blood, and take care of it until it is healed.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	This is the form of forceps by which the bow is extracted
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	The extremities are similar to the beak of a bird, which are made like iron: when they grasp the bow, they do not diminish the bow
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And there are many kinds of forceps, great and small, medium and large, according to the quantity of the magnitude of the bow, and the thinness or thickness of the wound, and the constriction of it
Forma Impellentis concaui.	The shape of the concave impulse.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	The shape of the blunt impulse
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is the extremity of the forearm as in the radius, that its entrance into the sagittal bow may be alleviated by it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	The proximal part of the forearm resembles the wing of a bird: its entrance into the sagittal bow is alleviated by its concavity
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	(Continuation of the previous translation
Caput XCVII.	(End of translation
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	The veins suitable for phlebotomy, which are found throughout the body, are thirty in number.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	Of these, six are in the head: two pulse- veins, which are behind the ears, two Herbae veins, two Arteriae which appear in two temporal regions, two lachrymal veins of the two eyes, which are called Aspicientes, a vein prepared in the middle of the forehead, and a vein at the tip of the nose
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two Guidegi veins, which are in the neck
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins which are in the upper lip of the mouth
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins which are in the lower lip
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	These are the Algecherich veins.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins which are under the tongue
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	As for the veins of the arms, there are five in each arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is the Cephalica vein, which is from the lateral side of the shoulder: and it is called the armpit vein.
Et Fusca.	And the Brachialis.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And the Median vein, which is composed of the branches of the basilica and the cephalic veins: and it is called the body vein
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	Both Basilica and Titillicaris are situated in the domestic side.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	The people call it Titillicaris within the house.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	The brachial vein is situated above the elbow: it is in that part from which blood is drawn, and that appears above the thumb when the hand is clenched
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	The little finger: that is the one between the ring finger and the smallest one, and it has two branches.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	There are three veins in the leg and foot
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is under the thumb nail, near the little toe
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	The second is the saphenous vein: its place is at the ankle on the domestic side
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The third is the great saphenous vein: its place is at the ankle on the outside of the foot
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And in the other leg there are three veins like these
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	As for the drawing of blood from two veins after the Golden Age
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	Bloodletting from these two veins behind the Golden Age is useful for ancient cataracts, migraine, haemorrhoids, head ulcers and other such ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	The quality of the bloodletting is according to what is narrated.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	It is to be done by causing the patient to raise his head; and to tear the hair of the head in the place of the two veins with a rough towel
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then the patient should tighten his neck with his hands until two veins appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And their place is behind the Golden Age in two depressed parts of the head
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	Wherefore doth thou question concerning the ease of thy finger, and where thou feel the pulse thereof under thy finger, there shalt thou find signs like a cautery.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take hold of the needle with the thumb and index finger, and that which is called Incidens is there.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then insert it under the nail into the flesh, until the needle reach the bone.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then lift up your hand with the nail and flesh to the upper part, and cut the nail with the incision made previously.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And let the length of the incision be as much as two fingers joined together, or thereabouts: and let blood flow out as much as you will
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then bind up the wound with threads, and let go of the needle, until it is healed
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And thus it is necessary at the beginning of this book to treat the incisions of the ears, and their cauterization.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	In the meantime of these two arteries in the temporal region.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	Two arteries being in both temples, from which phlebotomy is done, is for an old headache: and for swelling of the jaw, and for retention of urine: and for running of the blood from the acute angles towards the eyes
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And as for the quality of the phlebotomy of the hand, it is easy as I have told you
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	Bind up the patient's neck greatly, until two nails appear to be sensible to the touch: and let the pulse of the ears be shown under your finger
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then signs like a cautery will be shown
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then lift up the skin above the nail with your index finger, and insert the phlebotomy under the nail, and lift up the nail to the upper part
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And incise the vein, as you did in two other veins: and make it run from the blood in accordance with the quantity of your need.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then solve the clotting of the patient, and place your finger over the vein for an hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then place over the foot and the toes, and tie up from above the constriction strongly: and let it go when it is healed
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And now remember the reminder of these things, and their incision, and their extraction in the beginning of the book
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	About the incision of the front vein after the cephalic phlebotomy.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	The cause of the pain of phlebotomy of the front vein is after the cephalic phlebotomy: for the old diseases of the face: and for the headache, and redness: and the ulcer wound.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is, according to what I have said to you
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	Bind the patient's neck with a cloth, until the vein appears
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then take the instrument which is called Fossorium.
Cuius haec est forma.	What is its shape like this
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Place the protruding point which is on the head of the Fossorium over the vein, and pierce through it with a needle or with something like this: and let the blood run according to the quantity you want
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then solve the perforation of the patient, and tie up the vein, until it is healed
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And when it is opened with the wide phlebotomy.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	Indeed it does not befit that it should be of acute extremity, like the rest of the phlebotomies, but rather of the wide extremity
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	And a bloodletting is sometimes done according to the passing of time: because the bone is near: and perhaps in that it is fractured when the bloodletter is slight.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	And a bloodletting is sometimes done concerning the two tear ducts.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	The bleeding of the two veins which are in the two tear ducts of the two eyes, is for the eye from itching and redness: and for the swelling in the eye, and the pains of the face.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of the bloodletting of these is, as it tightens the sick man's neck with the wit
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then the bloodletting is easy: and you are standing over his head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And let the bloodletting be done according to the passing of time to a little length, with a small bloodletter, wide a little, for in that place there is no flesh
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	If the bloodletter is slight at the end, perhaps it is fractured.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then let him run from the blood as much as is necessary for him
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And put on the patient's side the foot of the blanket, and bind up the vein one night, and heal the vein.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	Concerning the bleeding of the veins of the nose
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	The veins of the nose are bled concerning fever, and sneezing, and pains of the face, such as a headache, and redness which happens in the face, especially when it is old.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of the bloodletting of these is, as it tightens the sick man's neck with the wit
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then take his nose with your left hand, and make the bloodletting under the tip of the nose, long: and fix it in the middle of the face between that which distinguishes the nose according to its straightness.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	Since the vulva does not appear to the sense there, and because the blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	It is necessary to make an incision with the scalpel immediately and let the blood flow out as required.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then tie off the vessel at night once.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	It will restore itself quickly by itself.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	Of the phlebotomy of the veins of the Guidegi.
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	The phlebotomy of the veins of the Guidegi is useful for constriction of the breath, and the inception of leprosy, and melancholy, and various ailments, and wounds and ulcers, and corrosiveness, that is, herpes of the abdomen
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	The quality of the phlebotomy of these veins is that it tightens the patient under both armpits with a ligature: and the artist stands over the head of the patient, and the patient sits on his seat.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then make the phlebotomy of the vein to the width of the phlebotomy.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then draw out from the blood the quantity that is appropriate, or according to what you need for this purpose
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do the same with the other vein
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Then tie off the ligature and tighten the two veins with the middle suture: so as not to cause the patient pain
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And keep him until morning
Sanatur enim uulnus.	He will recover quickly.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	Of the phlebotomy of the veins of Algeberich
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	The veins of Algeberich are useful for phlebotomy because they cause swelling in the mouth, corruption of the gums: and bad ulcers, and fissures of the lips, and bad ulcers, also those that are in the nose, and in the circumference of the eye
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And what is the quality of the bloodletting for this, that you make the patient sit before you: and bind his neck with a cloth.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then turn his lip outwards, and look at two veins: one is on the right side of the lip, and the other on the left side: and their mark is by the blackening of both.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And this is true: because around their circumference are small veins, black.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	Therefore make an incision on both of them at the place where it touches
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	If, however, there is doubt for you, and you do not know which of them is which: then you must resort to the incision of the greater of the two, and their manifestation.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And do the same with the two veins which are in the upper lip: and most frequently runs along with this: and make an incision of the two veins which are in the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	As for the phlebotomy of the vein under the tongue after the cephalic phlebotomy.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	Then indeed are the veins which are under the tongue phlebotomized: that is, the cephalic phlebotomy is for the affections which are in the gullet, and the swelling of the tongue, and the pains of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the quality of the mandibular phlebotomy is this, that you make the patient sit between your hands towards the sun: and lift his tongue, and look under the tongue at the side of his tongue one vein, and at the side of his tongue the other: and the colour of both runs down to black
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	Therefore make an incision on both of them: and hold, do not touch your last hand in making the phlebotomy
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For under those are arteries, and perhaps there will be a flow of blood from those arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	Of three veins in the cubit.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	There are three veins in the cubit that are commonly bled.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	They are bled in two ways.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Either by means of a broad lancet or by means of an olive oil compress or by cutting with a knife, as is practiced by Alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	This is his method.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus Alnesil is right, as regards the section.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And from these two kinds there are broad and subtle kinds according to the amplitude of the veins and the tension of their form. The form of phlebotomy with the lancet is broad like water
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it is suitable for opening wide veins that are swollen, distended, apparent, large, and containing thick blood.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this phlebotomy is of smaller breadth and greater fineness of touch
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	And it is suitable for bleeding small veins which contain thin yellow blood
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	Of the phlebotomy of the basilica.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	The basilica is one of these three veins which is used for phlebotomy.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because it takes blood from the swellings which are under the jaw and the collarbone, from that which follows to the chest, and the abdomen: and it is suitable for the phlebotomist because of the risk of causing damage to the artery from which blood is not taken
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If therefore he is careless and adds to the puncture of the phlebotomy, he will break that artery and the blood flow will cease.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Wherever it is necessary, do not perform a phlebotomy with a phlebotome that is still sharp: rather, make it blunt like Alnesil.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	If the condition does not clearly manifest itself, then it is necessary to examine other parts of the body, or to ask about other symptoms: or to perform a phlebotomy in the place of the Funem brachii vein.</start_of_turn>
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	For indeed it is evident, and must be made blunt like the phlebotome of Anesil, as we have said.</start_of_turn>
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	If you wish to perform a phlebotomy on the limb itself, then before you tighten the tourniquet on the limb, touch the area to ascertain the location of the pulse.</start_of_turn>
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then place the sign over the area with the burn, afterwards the arm, and make the vein section concave with the phlebotome like Alnesil, as we have said.</start_of_turn>
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	Take care that the incision does not reach the artery.</start_of_turn
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	When you have finished, when you tighten the ligature, the swelling in the place that you marked with the burn, then that swelling is the swelling of the artery: you must therefore stop it.</start_of_turn
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	If blood spurts out at the phlebotomy, like the urine of a child, and is thin and red: then you know that it is from the artery.</start_of_turn
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Then you must be quick, and place your finger on the area that you are working on, and then remove your finger.</start_of_turn
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If blood continues to spurt (since it is likely to have spurted a great deal), then tighten the limb and let go: and beware lest the patient move: and stay calm about the patient's fear.</start_of_turn
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	Neither does it move for a few days until it is healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	If blood does not clot and the swelling increases: and it is not present to you in this moment of your medicine, then cut the artery if necessary.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For its extremities contract and blood clots.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Take off the outer skin of the flesh, and find the bone: take hold of one middle and bind it above the joint with a ligature and strings until another day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if blood clots, that is good
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not: then take care of it as is remembered from the place of the powdered blood which flows out: and the cutting of blood in these things is not difficult because of the smallness of the wound and the possibility of the ligature from the arm
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	Of the phlebotomy of the elbow
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	The veins of the elbow for phlebotomy are considered to be those that draw blood from the upper part of the head and the lower part of the body: because they are composed of the branch of the basilica and the branch of the cephalic, as we have said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	It is necessary for the phlebotomist to be aware of the position of the vein in relation to the phlebotomy, for under it is a nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	If therefore the puncture of the phlebotomy adds to the injury of the nerve, and it finds the nerve, it will result in that stupor, and the healing of it will be difficult, and it may not heal at all
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve is perceived by many sensations
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	If however it is hidden in some people, and is faint, and is not visible: then you must take care that you make the phlebotomy as low as possible, sectioning with Alnesil, and cutting the nerve with your skill
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	If there is a bone between two nerves, then find the bone in length.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	If there is a bone between two nerves, then find the bone along its length.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	Phlebotomies of the cephalic bone are useful because they draw blood from the head and supply it to the eyes.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	It is necessary to perform incisions on the proper bone only, if necessary, as when performing phlebotomy with olive oil, or with myrtle: for it is safer for all veins than for arteries or nerves.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	It is appropriate to join together with the phlebotomy, that is to say, to make an opening only as large as necessary, and to seek a softer place: and it does not harm if it is not found at the first blow, as it will return with subsequent phlebotomies
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	Indeed, sometimes a swelling appears in some people when no phlebotomy is performed at the first blow, but it does not harm them in any way
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	Of the usefulness of phlebotomy, and precautions to be observed in its practice.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The quality of phlebotomy, and the accidents which arise from it, in whose rectification you must think carefully
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	Firstly, you must know that phlebotomy is not administered except in the conservation of health, and for the maintenance of well-being, and for the prevention of ailments.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And for the three veins which are in the cubit, namely the cephalic, the cubital, and the basilica.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And for phlebotomy in the beginning of spring over fasting, in summer, and autumn, and in winter after the harvest, when there are signs of repletion
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And let the phlebotomy be done on the first or third day after three hours have passed.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	Phlebotomy is done in ailments whenever convenience and need dictate, whether at night or day, at any hour, in any time.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	It is not to be done on children until they are fourteen years of age.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	Neither should it be done to a pregnant woman except from the fourth month until the seventh month.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	Nor to old people who have passed their sixty-fifth year
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	When anyone wishes to undergo phlebotomy for whatever reason: it is necessary beforehand to cleanse the intestines with mild laxatives, if there is much retained stool in the intestines: in order that they do not draw out harmful pus from the intestines to the principal parts during the phlebotomy
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	Neither should it be done to a patient suffering from acute vomiting, nor to a drunkard or someone suffering from excessive drunkenness until these conditions have subsided from the body
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Nor to a patient with dropsy
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And care should be taken that phlebotomy is not repeated too soon after a bout of colics, vomiting, flux of the bowels, multiplication of sexual intercourse, laborious work, exercise, joy, fasting, or any other thing that dissolves strength from the body or animal
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Then consider in the subtlity of humors before this, if the blood is thick with food and drink, and the physicians: if possible do this for him
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Then let a bath be taken, if it does not forbid this: or some exercise be performed, in order to lighten the blood.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And make an incision in the belly, about the third of the day, as we have said: and strive that he may evacuate his belly from all the harmful accidents of animals, such as constriction, and wrath, and fear: and from all the accidental misfortunes of the body, such as toil, and pain, and luxury, and like those.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And let its juices be present with things which customarily accompany human use of aromatic substances, and fragrance, and delight, and like those in quantity as is possible.</start_of_turn>
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Then sit the phlebotomist above the elbow, which is higher than the elbow of the phlebotomist: then extract his arm, and rub it with his hand twice, or thrice.</start_of_turn>
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then tighten the ligament with forceps, and bind it twice.</start_of_turn
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And let the tightening be moderate, for when the tightening is unequal, or through excess in the tightening, it hinders the course of the blood: or in softening, and even then it hinders the course of the blood.</start_of_turn
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after the tightening, it is necessary to rub the phlebotomized hand with the palm of the hand towards the inside, until the veins are engorged, and the sensation returns.</start_of_turn>
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then the phlebotomist will withdraw the phlebotome with a little oil, as before.</start_of_turn
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then he places his index finger of his left hand over the vein at the place where he wishes to make the incision, slightly: so that it does not escape the vein, and to prevent bruising.</start_of_turn
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	For from the veins is as from a flying chord at the phlebotomy: and from these is what is filled with wind: and when you put the phlebotome on it, it contracts under the phlebotomy, and the phlebotomist is thrown down, and the phlebotomy is not opened by the vein: and if it is opened, it is tight: because of this it is necessary to strengthen the phlebotomist, and to take care of him in all these things.</start_of_turn>
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then the phlebotomist lays it down.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If ever an opening appears from the belly of the belly, then that is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then repeat that vein again under that place slightly, or above it with a constriction: if the place does not yield
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	For if it yields, or the patient grows faint, then let him go on the first or second day: and do not tighten the ligament.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	Perhaps then the clot will be drawn out by the drawing-out.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	Neither should a poultice be introduced
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then repeat the phlebotomy if necessary.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	For if the opening is small, or blood runs slowly: and take care that it does not go outside the blood quantity that you wish: then repeat the phlebotomy in the same place according to the rule, and add a little to the operation.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	And do that with constriction, before the place yields, for the clot is often in many people in the surrounding area at the time of the operation itself
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If therefore you see that the clot has already gone, then do not repeat over it altogether, for that will not excuse you before God
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And put over it something from the fat of oil: because it will soothe the running of the blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	And it is better in this place than pure oil, and than the rest of the oils.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And do the same with the fat of oil in all your phlebotomies, which you do against the running of the blood: and make that it be like tyriaca alfarach and sage, when it is put on one of them over the place
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	Blood thickens and resolves when it is gross.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	When blood is thick, it thickens and resolves itself
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And it is necessary that you do this after the blood has gone out of the vein itself, with its complement, or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	If anything black or yellow remains in the place after a few days, it does not harm: and if it does, place upon it some aloe, or balm of resolvers, or something of the juice of mint, that is, camomile or something like that.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	And many times indeed are there apostemata and swellings at the phlebotomy of the basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	Put your hand upon it therefore, then if you find softness in the compression of your hand over it, then that swelling is bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Therefore put upon it something of what we have said
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps the blood will flow from that artery.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make a plaster of it with that which has astringency, so that the place may be bound up.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with the rest of the treatment, until it is healed
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is necessary that you draw out of every man his blood according to the quantity of his virtue.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And what appears from the color of the stain on the blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For blood is black when it is going out, then let it go out until it turns red: and in the same way if you see it thick, let it go out until it thickens: and in the same way if it is sharp, let it go out until the sharpness is gone
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	He who is full, strong, and in need of bloodletting should take one, so that the phlebotomy may be ample: and he who is bilious should be on the opposite side.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	He should draw it out in veins, and the opening should be tight: and it is better that it should be administered in the phlebotomy of the vein, than by puncture
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	This method of phlebotomy is safe from the flow of blood, and from the nerves: and it is more praiseworthy and safer than phlebotomy by width and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And he who has suffered from syncope during phlebotomy should before phlebotomy give the patient some bread soaked in pomegranate juice: or vinegar, if he is hot: and let him draw from the blood in three or four veins.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	And if the complexion is pale, then he should take before phlebotomy bread soaked in honey syrup, or in scented honey syrup with spices, or in scented syrup with a strong odor
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	If there should be syncope during phlebotomy, and the cause of this is too much blood drawn: then he should take in the drink water with meat, and fragrant syrup under the tongue: and he should mix aromatic things with algae, and fill his chest with these: and he should do the rest of what we said in the chapter on syncope from evacuation
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	Whoever wants to make his arm well, and to dissolve his blood in the second degree: he must take the one who has phlebotomy because of a great evacuation, and who is bilious, so that he may gradually dissolve the blood according to the quantity of bile in continuous days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	Whoever wants to make his arm well, and to dissolve his blood in the second degree, and who is strong in his body: then let him do this after seven hours, or nine from his first phlebotomy
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of that from which it declines: it is necessary for him to do so on the second or third day.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of that from which it declines: it is necessary for him to do so on the second or third day.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of that from which it declines: it is necessary for him to do so on the second or third day.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of that from which it declines: it is necessary for him to do so on the second or third day
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of that from which it declines: it is necessary for him to do so on the second or third day
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of that from which it declines: it is necessary for him to do so on the second or third day
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of that from which it declines: it is necessary for him to do so on the second or third day.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of that from which it declines: it is necessary for him to do so on the second or third day
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of that from which it declines: it is necessary for him to do so on the second or third day
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of that from which it declines: it is necessary for him to do so on the second or third day
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is that it allows the sickly hand to immerse itself in warm water until the flesh reddens, and then the vein reappears manifest.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	And then it is bound over itself with a slight median constriction
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	And the phlebotomy is performed according to a cross-section gradually, not latitudinally, neither in length: and let the opening be wide, and let your phlebotomy be such that it is as little as possible over the joint of the hand
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	If it is forbidden for blood to issue, then immerse the hand once more in the warm water, and allow the blood to flow in the water until you reach your need
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	But if you are in the summer days, then you are excused from the immersion of the hand in the warm water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And mostly blood flow in warm water is set in the wintertime.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And the phlebotomy of this vein is safer than all other veins, because there is no pulsating vein under it, neither nerve.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	Phlebotomy of the right hand of Salvatella is beneficial for the ailments of the liver.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is that you bind the hand with the ligature or your hand after you have immersed your hand in the warm water until the vein swells and appears to the touch.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	And the phlebotomy is performed by a cross-section
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you cut the vein completely, it will not cause any damage to it in any way
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And be careful not to lose your hand with the phlebotomy.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	Under these nerves are exposed the nerves of the fingers denuded of flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then again, move the hand to the warm water, and let the blood flow out into it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	If you do not move the hand into the warm water, the blood will coagulate in the opening of the vein, and will be prohibited from running.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	When you have drawn out the quantity of blood necessary, then put on the vein oil and salt: that it may not solidify too quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And in like manner it is necessary to make with every limb strict.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The dressing of a phlebotomy of the left hand is: because it is connected with the spleen: and in like manner do it in a phlebotomy of the right hand, as you did in the second equal to the first.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	As for the veins of the phlebotomy, the dressing is for the ailments which are in the lower part of the body, such as the ailments of the belly, and retention of the monthly blood, and weakness of the kidneys, and ulcers of the buttocks and of the ancient thighs, and similar ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is that it lets the sick foot enter the warm water: and makes on it friction above, until the veins become swollen: and ties above the joining of the foot with a bandage
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	And the veins are located at the heel, appearing under the thumb: and are pulled out from it on the face of the foot of many fingers.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	The phlebotomy is therefore better in a wider limb, or at the heel in its gathering: because it is better and safer
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	If you do the phlebotomy on the face of the foot, then take care from the nerves which are under it over the face of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And put your phlebotomy as it comes out from across, like the one you wish to make: and be the phlebotomist Nestles
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	If blood flow is prohibited, then repeat the foot in hot water: and allow the blood to cease its flow in the limb until it is evacuated.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	If the vein has slipped from the first position, then repeat the procedure with phlebotomy above the lower part, for the place is safe and not liable to cause harm, as we have said
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	Similarly with the other foot's saphenous vein equally.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The veins of the sciatic nerve are located at the heel on the outside of the ankle
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	Its support in phlebotomy is for the pain of the ankle when it is caused by warm blood
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	Its quality is that it should include a diseased bath and must hurry: and tighten the limb from the ankle up to four fingers above the heel, with a fine thread that does not show except by this.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When it appears, then phlebotomy must be performed as well as possible, or by displacement: and it is better either to cut the vein with a knife, or to ligate it by section
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	For the place is safer, and it is hidden in many people.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	If you do not find it and do not perceive it at all: then phlebotomy should be performed on some branch of it, for it is that which appears in the back of the foot and below the heel: and cause the blood to flow out in the quantity you wish
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then loosen the tightening, and place over the place of phlebotomy the skin, and tighten the place.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	It heals quickly.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	(The text continues with further instructions on wound care and treatment of various ailments.)
Caput XCVIII.	Chapter 105.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	The sources of wounds are from bones, air, and blood vessels.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	The aetiology of wounds is in two ways
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	By incision and extraction of blood, or by contamination without incision
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	This contamination which is without incision is in two ways
Aut enim est cum igne.	Or with fire
Aut est absque igne.	Or without fire
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And the wounds which are made with incision and extraction of blood are in fourteen parts of the body
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	These are the wounds which are made with incision and extraction of blood: Alnocrati is the most posterior wound of the head; Alkehel is the middle wound of the neck; Alhagdahim are two wounds of the neck from two parts at once; menti is under the mandible in the lower part of the mouth; the two wounds of the lips; Alachosos is over the end of the tail of the scapula; the two wounds of the elbows are in the middle of the two arms; the two wounds of the knees are in the middle of the two thighs; and the two wounds of the ankles are below the two calves
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	Wounds do not draw out blood from small scattered veins in the flesh, and for this reason does not cause the loss of blood like phlebotomy.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	Neither is it necessary to administer wounds with fire, or without fire in any bodily illness which originates from congestion, until the whole body is evacuated.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	When necessity compels us to perform a wound for the purpose of treatment, or by custom, we must administer it at the beginning, middle, and end of the month, and at any other time as needed
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	When blood multiplies within a human being, until it requires extraction through incisions, it accumulates in the head, causing swelling and pain.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	It also results in swelling and redness of the face, head, and neck
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	It also causes itching of the face, forehead, eyebrows, and darkness under the eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And from this blood there results the place of incision for its extraction
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	From this blood laughter multiplies
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	From this blood there results a taste of blood in the mouth: either the tongue swells and expels blood.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	From this blood sleep multiplies
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	From this blood there results vomiting of blood, redness, and frothing, and similar things occur
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When we see this in the third part of the month, we order an incision to be made immediately, after two or three days have passed.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	The ointment of the night is: because it itself contributes to swelling in the head, and what drips to the eyes
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	Therefore it is necessary that after the evacuation of the whole body
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	These are the wounds of cephalic phlebotomy.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	It is not permitted to perform this operation on those who are pale in complexion or in whom there is catarrh
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it brings great danger
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	Neither should it be performed on the elderly, in whom the head is cold and brittle
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	Whoever is very diligent beyond his limit will generate against himself an aversion.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	He must therefore take precautions, like the winds of the south, to throw his hand down with the lower part towards the ground, fearing the generation of aversion.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	The winds of the south or the Galen, is the place of the puncture of the veins of the Fusca, and the veins of the Basilica, and by this means he brings on asthma, constriction of the chest, swelling of the instruments, spitting, and distension.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	He must therefore take precautions like the winds of the Galen, which must be thrown down towards the lower parts, because if it is put below, it generates weakness in the chest and the stomach
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	The winds of the Galen cause pain in the head, vomiting, headache, perforation, and pain in the roots of the teeth: and this is the place of the puncture of the veins of the Basilica.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	He must therefore take precautions like the winds of the south, do not bring your hand forward with the scarification: so that you do not cut the artery and cause the flow of blood to increase
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	The winds of the south under the chin cause swelling of the saliva in the mouth, corruption of the gums, and similar evils which are in the mouth: and this is the place of the puncture of the veins of the jaw, which are in two layers
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	The winds of the south cause spitting, which brings on vomiting, which is caused by reflection and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	The winds of the south cause the attraction of the inner parts of the two cavities towards the three veins, Basilica, Fusca, and Cephalic: because these veins attract blood from all these small veins that are in the flesh: and they attract these small veins from other large veins until the attraction reaches the three veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	It is necessary, therefore, that the surgeon take heed, not to perform too great a scarification: for in this place the flesh is stripped bare, and beneath it are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	The winds which are blown upon the ulcers above the thighs cause hemorrhoids of the Ani and ulcers below.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	It is necessary, therefore, that the surgeon take heed, so that the winds may be great and open to the air: for in this place the skin requires strong suction, and the subtle winds may perhaps be broken by the scarification; and a great scarification is required
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	The winds of the thighs diminish somewhat in their manifestation: for they draw blood from the whole body, and cause ancient pains in the buttocks, thighs, and belly: they cause menstruation, and bring swelling, and stiffness: and they are in the place of two saphenous veins and the groin bone.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	Indeed, they weaken the body much, and cause syncope in many people.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	The winds of the groin are close to the winds of the two thighs.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	The position of the winds is such that you should place the greatest suction at the first wound, and temper the suction: do not prolong the position of the wound, but place the hand quickly and remove it quickly, so that the humors may reach their place in an even manner: and do not cease doing this until the place is red and swollen, and the blood appears red: then indeed you may scarify, and perform the suction gradually
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	Consider also the disposition of the body.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	For one who has a thin body, little hair, should make the incision once, not more: so as not to damage the place
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	And command the Wind-worker to increase the sharpness of the incision, and make it slight: and temper the suction to facilitate, and speed, and the movement of the blood.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	If there is any thickness in the blood, it is necessary to make the incision twice.</start_of_turn>
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	In the first incision, a narrow opening is made under the thickness of the blood, and its moisture is taken away: and in the second incision, the fine extraction of the thick blood is made.</start_of_turn>
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	If the blood is dark or purulent, then a third incision is made: to achieve the most effective result.</start_of_turn
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	Finally, when we wish to extract the blood slowly or in small amounts, a single incision suffices.</start_of_turn
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	When we wish to extract a large amount of blood, we make multiple incisions.</start_of_turn>
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	And if we measure that the blood is thick: then it is necessary to make a deep incision: and the equal end of the incision is the depth of the skin.</start_of_turn
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	What is to be done with the oils at the position of the Wind-workers, and what is their purpose?
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	In such a case where the skin is thick, hard, rough, and has close pores, it is necessary to anoint the area of the Wind-workers with opened, softened, and resolving oils: such as almond oil, or olive oil, or sweet almond oil, or pumpkin seed oil.</start_of_turn
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	And if it is in winter, then narcissus oil, or lily oil, or camomile oil, or mastic: and such like.</start_of_turn
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	If the superfluousness is great, cold: then let olive oil be amaranth, or balsam oil or white oil, or anatine oil: and like these.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.
