Quot uero ex illis alsatagie sunt separata, remoue ea, et extrahe ipsa.	How many of these tentacles are separated from the wound, remove them and extract them themselves.
Et quae ex eis sunt non separata, et pungunt membrum, et faciunt accidere dolorem, conare incidere ea, et auferre ea omni modo quo possibile est tibi illud.	And what remains of these is not separated, and penetrates the limb, and causes pain, attempt to cut them out, and remove them in every way possible for you
Quod si accidat uulneri zuchen, aut ekileten, id est, estiomenus, aut species alia corruptionis et putrefactionis: tunc oportet, ut opponas unicuique ex eis cum eo quod conuenit ei ex curatione, cuius praecessit narratio in capitulo suo.	If it happens that a wound is swollen or blackened, that is, bruising, or any other corruption or decay: then it is necessary to oppose each of these things with that which is appropriate for its cure, of which mention has been made in its chapter
Et ex eo in quo oportet ut stet sermo meus, et cui facias praesentem mentem tuam quando frangitur os, et eminet super membrum, sicut os coxae, et adiutorii, et similia eis ex membris magnis, est, ut non praesumas attractionem eius, multotiens enim accidit ex illo mors, imo dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat.	And concerning that in which it is necessary to state my opinion, and to which you should pay attention when a bone is fractured, and it protrudes above the limb, like the thigh bone, and its attendants, and similar things to large limbs, that you should not presume its attraction, for much harm often arises from this, even to the point of letting go of it, until it decays
Fortasse enim cadet per se post uiginti dies, aut triginta.	Perhaps indeed it falls away by itself after eighty days, or a hundred.
Tunc ergo cura uulnus, si uidetur tibi: et sinon, dimitte ipsum.	Then indeed care for the wound if you see it: and otherwise, let it go
¶ De curatione Nodationis in uestigio fracturae.	Note: The provided text does not include any information regarding the care of nodation in a fractured bone, so I am unable to translate this segment.
Caput XXI.	Chapter XXI.</start_of_turn>
Multoties accidit haec Nodatio in uestigio sanationis fracturae.	Many times this nodulation occurs in the healing of a fracture.</start_of_turn
Praecipue, quae est prope iuncturas: et foedatur ex ea figura membri.	Especially that which is close to the joints: and is caused by that figure of the limb.</start_of_turn
Et fortasse prohibet membrum ab operatione sua naturali.	And perhaps hinders the limb from its natural operation.</start_of_turn
Considera ergo tunc, si nodatio est recens: administra in ea medicinas quae stipticitatem habent, sicut aloe, et olibanum, et myrrha, et sarcocolla, et acacia, et similia eis.	Consider therefore at this time, if swelling is present: administer in it medicines which have styptic properties, such as aloe, and olibanum, and myrrh, and sarcocolla, and acacia, and similar things.
Ita, ut accipias ex istis quasdam, aut omnes eas: et confice eas cum uino stiptico, aut cum albumine oui, aut cum aceto: et pone eas super nodationem in stuppa, et stringe eas super ipsam strictura bona.	Consider therefore at this time, if swelling is present: administer in it medicines which have styptic properties, such as aloe, and olibanum, and myrrh, and sarcocolla, and acacia, and similar things.
Et dimitte stricturam, nec soluas eam diebus multis.	Consider therefore at this time, if swelling is present: administer in it medicines which have styptic properties, such as aloe, and olibanum, and myrrh, and sarcocolla, and acacia, and similar things. And loosen the stricture, do not keep it tight for many days.
Deinde solue eam, et itera aliam, donec remoueatur nodatio.	And then loosen the stricture, and repeat it until the swelling is gone.
Aut stringe super ipsam laminam plumbi decenter.	Or tighten over the middle of the leaden plate
Plumbo enim est proprietas remouendi omne quod timetur ex membris.	Lead has the property of removing everything that threatens the limbs
Si autem nodatio iam in lapidem conuersa est, et stricta est, et festine prouocat necessitas ad auferendum eam: tunc finde super eam ex superiori parte eius, et incide superfluitatem eminentem: aut rade eam cum quibusdam rasoriis, donec remoueatur: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	If, however, the swelling has already penetrated the stone, and is tightly closed, and produces pain: then find above the said part of it, and cut off the superabundance: or break the swelling with some instruments, until it is removed: and take care of the wound, until it has healed
¶ De curatione quando restauratur, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, non secundum naturam suam.	And as for the care when the limb has been restored, and remains under the skin, not according to its natural order: do not neglect it, but keep it under control.
Caput XXII.	Chapter XXII.
Quando restauratur fractura ossis, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, debile: tunc non fit illud nisi propter caussas multas.	When the fracture of a bone has been restored, and remains under the skin, weak: then it is not done except for great causes
Quarum una est, multitudo solutionis ligamenti et ligationis eius non secundum quod oportet: aut propter superfluitatem stricturae ligamentorum, donec prohibeatur nutrimentum currere ad membrum: aut propter multitudinem embrocationis superfluae in non sua hora: aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore infirmi, et debilitatem eius.	Such as the multitude of solution of the ligament and its ligation which is not according to what is necessary: or because of the excessive tension of the ligaments, until the nutrition of the limb is hindered: or because of the excessive amount of superfluous embrocation which is not in its proper time: or because of the scarcity of blood in the body of the patient, and its weakness
Et curatio illius est, cibare infirmum, et tenerum facere corpus eius, donec multiplicetur sanguis in eo.	And its care is to nourish the sick person and strengthen the body, until the blood multiplies in it.
Et administra balneum.	And administer a bath.
Et intromitte gaudium et laeticiam super eum.	And introduce joy and gladness upon him.
Deinde pone picem super membrum: ut attrahat pix ad ipsum nutrimentum multum.	Then place plaster on the limb: so that it attracts much nourishment to itself
Et assiduet embrocationem eius cum aqua tepida, donec currat nutrimentum, et redeat ad figuram suam naturalem.	And diligently anoint it with warm water, until the nourishment has recovered and returned to its natural shape
¶ De curatione ossium fractorum quando restaurantur tortuose.	When restoring fractured bones, care for the restoration of the curve
Caput XXIII.	Chapter XXIII.
Quando accidit membro iam restaurato post sanationem eius tortuositas, et eminentia ossi fracto, aut nodatio: et foedatur per illud forma membri, uerumtamen membrum non prohibetur ab operatione sua naturali: tunc non oportet ut recipias sermonem eius, qui existimat, ut frangatur membrum denuo.	When the limb has been restored after healing, after a fracture, and the bone has protruded, or there is a bulge: and it is being made to bend by that shape of the limb, although the limb is not forbidden from its natural action: then it is not necessary to break the limb again
Et iam fuerunt multi stolidorum medicorum et restauratorum, qui fecerunt illud in terra nostra.	And there are many sturdy doctors and restorers of limbs in our land who have done this thing.
Et haec quidem operatio est uituperabilis ualde, perducens ad mortem, uel timorem magnum, ut scilicet sit mortalis.	And this operation is very dangerous, bringing about death or great fear, as indeed it is mortal
Verum si claudicatio et nodatio sunt recentes: tunc oportet, ut embrocetur cum aqua tepida, in qua decoctae sint herbae mollificantes, sicut folia alteae, et radix eius, et mellilotum, et illis similia.	But if the swelling and bulge are recent: then it is necessary to anoint with warm water, in which decoctions of soothing herbs are boiled, such as rue leaves, and the root of it, and honey, and the like of these
Et fiat ei emplastrum cum emplastro mollificatiuo, sicut dyachilon decenter factum.	And make for him a plaster with a soothing plaster, such as gypsum made in the center
Aut sumatur mucilago radicis alteae, et concutiatur cum adipe gallinae, aut oleo sisamino: et emplastretur cum eo.	Or take the mucus of rue root, and mix it with pork fat, or fat from fish: and plaster it with that.
Aut sumantur ficus pingues, et terantur cum fimo columbino, et similibus eis quae nominantur ex medicinis diminuentes consolidationem.	The ficus of the belly swells, and it is to be treated with colocynth seed and other substances which the physicians call for in order to diminish consolidation.
Et quandoque soluitur nodatio cum fricatione assidua, antiqua, et leni, quae fit cum manibus humidis.	When the swelling has gone down with repeated rubbing, as is done with wet hands, the old and soft adhesion will disappear.
Et administretur motus membri ad omnem partem in horis omnibus.	Motion of the limb is administered at every part at all times
Si autem tortuositas iam antecessit, et fortis facta est, et conuersa est in lapidem, et prouocata est necessitas ad curatonem eius cum ferro: tunc oportet, ut secetur superius eius, et soluatur continuatio ossis, et incidatur quod superfluit ex nodatione aut osse cum Incisoriis subtilibus: et administretur facilitas in illo cum sollicitudine et studio.	If, however, a swelling has preceded the stiffness, and has become strong, and has become converted to stone, and has proceeded to necessitate its cutting: then it is necessary to cut above it, to dissolve the continuation of the bone, and to remove what is superfluous from the adhesion or from the bone with fine forceps: and this must be done with care and attention
¶ De sermone in Dislocatione.	Regarding the dislocation.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24.
Dislocatio est exitus alicuius iuncturarum a loco suo.	Dislocation is the displacement of any articulation from its normal place.
Quare prohibetur a motu suo, et foedatur figura membri.	Because it hinders its motion and deforms the limb
Et facit accidere super infirmum dolores, et laesiones uehementes.	And causes great pain and wounds that bleed.
Quando ergo accidit alicui dislocatio, tunc oportet festinare ad restaurationem eius: neque tardet eam omnino.	When, therefore, any dislocation has happened, then it is necessary to hasten its restoration: and do it without delay
Nam si tardatur, apostematur locus, et fortasse cum eo reductio dislocationis.	For if it is delayed, the place is stiffened and perhaps with it the reduction of the dislocation will become more difficult.
Propter illud ergo non oportet, ut moueatur, neque extendatur in hora apostemationis eius.	Therefore it is not to be moved or extended at the time of its restoration
Quoniam multotiens facit accidere spasmum, et dolores laedentes.	Because it causes many spasms and painful sensations
Verum quando accidit illud, tunc oportet, ut properes ad phlebotomiam infirmi.	But when this has happened, then it is necessary to perform phlebotomy on the patient.
Deinde dimittatur, donec quiescat apostema.	Then let it be discharged, until the swelling subsides.
Deinde embrocetur membrum cum aqua calida et oleo.	Then let the limb be bound with warm water and oil.
Deinde reducatur cum facilitate.	Then let it be reduced with ease.
Et curetur omne membrum cum eo cuius rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And care for all the limb with that which its memory will return to its place
Ego quidem iam ordinaui capitula dislocationis, etiam secundum quod praecessit in fractura, a superiori parte corporis usque ad inferiorem eius.	I command you to order the head of dislocation, also according to what has preceded in fracture, from the upper part of the body down to the lower part of it.
¶ De cura dislocationis Mandibulae inferioris.	Concerning the care of dislocation of the lower jaw
Caput XXV.	Chapter XXV
Parum dislocantur duae Mandibulae nisi raro.	Rarely do two mandibles dislocate except for a little while.
Et dislocatio ambarum fit secundum unum duoru modorum.	And the dislocation of both is done according to one of two methods
Aut enim remouentur a locis suis remotione parua, et mollificantur parumper.	Or they are moved from their places with slight removal, and they are softened gently
Aut dislocantur dislocatione integra, completa, donec mollificentur ad partem pectoris, donec currat saliua infirmi, et non possit tenere eam, neque possit claudere os suum, et inuoluatur lingua eius cum sermone.	Or they are dislocated completely, that is, until they reach the middle of the breast, until the soft parts are softened, and it is not able to hold itself, neither is it able to close its own bone, and the tongue is involved with the speech
Quando autem dislocatio eius est parua, tunc redit in pluribus dispositionibus per se cum paucitate.	When however the dislocation is slight, then it returns by itself in several positions with little exertion
Si uero est dislocatio completa, integra: tunc oportet, ut administretur reductio eius uelociter, et non tardetur penitus: et est, ut teneat minister caput infirmi: et intromittat medicus pollicem manus suae unius in radicem Mandibulae dislocationis inter os eius, si dislocatio est a parte una.	If however the dislocation is complete, entire: then it is necessary that it be managed immediately, and not be delayed: and it is necessary that the minister of the patient keep hold of the thumb of his hand with one hand at the root of the dislocation of the mandible between its bones, if the dislocation is from one side
Aut intromittat duos pollices suos simul, si dislocatio est a duabus partibus.	Or he introduces two fingers of his hand together, if the dislocation is from both sides
Et reliqui digiti manuum eius sint extra, quibus aequet.	And the remaining fingers of his hand are outside, equal.
Et praecipe infirmo, ut mundificet Mandibulas suas, et absoluat eas ad manducandum ad omnem partem.	And command the patient to loosen his teeth, and clench them towards the biting portions
Et medicus aequet Mandibulam, et impellat Mandibulam, donec redeat ad locum suum.	The physician must equal the jaw, and push the jaw until it returns to its place
Quod si difficilis sit reductio eius, praecipue si sunt ambae Mandibulae simul: tunc administra uaporationem cum aqua calida, et oleo, donec fiat facilis reductio ambarum: neque tardes reductionem ambarum omnino, sicut diximus.	If the reduction is difficult, especially if both jaws are together: then administer an evaporation with warm water and oil, until the reduction of both becomes easy: and do not attempt to reduce them both at once, as we have said
Cum ergo redeunt et aequantur, et clauditur os infirmi, et non mollificantur: tunc pone super eas puluillos pannorum, cum ceroto quod sit factum ex cera: et oleo rosato.	When they have returned and are equal, and the patient's jaw is closed, and not softened: then place over the teeth of the patient, with wool which has been made from wax: and wet butter.
Deinde ligetur cum facilitate cum ligamentis mollibus.	And it is bound with ease with soft bands.
Et sit somnus infirmi super dorsum suum: et caput eius sit stans inter duo puluinaria, ut non moueat ipsum ad dextram et sinistram: neque conetur, uel cogatur masticare aliquid: imo ponatur cibus eius sorbitio lenis, donec quando remouentur dolores, et nodatur Mandibula: tunc comedat quod uult, et administretur illud cum facilitate.	And let the patient sleep on his back: and his head is placed between two cushions, so that he does not move his head to the right and left: neither force him, nor cause him to chew anything: but rather put a soft food in his mouth, until when he moves his pain has ceased, and the jaw has settled: then he may eat what he wants, and that is given with ease
Non laboret super operationem oris sui apud comestionem et potum, et oscitationem, donec nodetur Mandibula, et sanetur.	He does not work on the operation of his mouth during eating and drinking, and chewing, until the jaw has settled and healed.
Quod si difficilis fiat reductio duarum Mandibuiarum, quando dislocantur in hora aliqua, et non conuertuntur ad loca sua: tunc multotiens accidunt inde febres, et soda assidua: et fortasse soluitur uenter infirmi, et fortasse uomit choleram puram.	If the reduction of both jaws is difficult, when they are dislocated at some time, and do not return to their places: then many times there follow from this fever, and bitter soda: and perhaps the patient's belly becomes relaxed, and perhaps bile is omitted pure
Cum ergo uides illud: tunc scias, quia est perditio, et multotiens moritur ille cui accidit illud in decem diebus.	When you have done thus: then you know that it is lost, and many times he dies from it in ten days.
¶ De reducione dislocationis Furculae, et extremitatis humeri.	On the reduction of dislocation of the Furcula and the extremity of the humerus.
Caput XXVI.	On the reduction of dislocation of the Furcula and the extremity of the humerus.
Furcula quidem non dislocatur ex latere intrinseco, propter continuationem suam cum pectore.	The Furcula does not dislocate from the inside outwards, because of its continuation with the chest.
Et dislocatur quandoque ad exteriora: et declaratur illud sensui.	It dislocates sometimes outwards: and this is recognized by sense.
Et restauratio eius est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat brachia sua.	And its reduction is that the patient lies with the sore side upwards, and extends his arms
Deinde coarta locum cum palma tua coartatione forti, nam ipsa redibit.	Then cover the place with your hand and with a strong bandage, for it will return by itself
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stringe eam.	Then place over it a bandage, and sponges, and bind them tightly.
Extremitates uero eius quae sequuntur cubitum, et continuantur cum eo, non dislocantur, nisi raro.	The extremities following the elbow do not dislocate with it, except rarely
Quod si dislocatur die aliquo: tunc oportet, ut reducatur et aequetur secundum quod diximus, et quod praeparatur tibi.	If it dislocates on some other day: then it must be reduced and equated as we have said, and which is prepared for you
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam.	Then place over it a bandage, and sponges, and bind them tightly
Et praecipe infirmo, adhaerere tranquillitati et quieti, donec sanetur.	And command the patient to adhere to tranquility and quiet, until he is healed
Et cum hac eadem curatione reducitur extremitas Humeri, quando separatur etiam a loco suo.	And when the extremity of the humerus is reduced thus, when it is also separated from its place.
¶ De reductione dislocationis Humeri.	And on the reduction of dislocation of the humerus
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII
Scias, quod Humerus non dislocatur, nisi secundum tres modos.	Know that the humerus does not dislocate, except in three ways.
Quorum unus est, ut dislocetur ad partem titillici ad inferiora.	The first is that it dislocates to the lower part of the elbow
Secundus est, ut dislocetur ad partem pectoris.	The second is that it dislocates to the part of the chest.
Et fortasse dislocatur ad superiorem partem Humeri: et illud fit raro.	And perhaps it is displaced to the upper part of the Humerus: and this happens rarely.
Et non dislocatur ad posteriora, propter spatulam.	And it does not move to the back, because of the spatheum.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora, propter neruos.	And it does not move to the front, because of the nerves
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur et egreditur ad inferiora uersus titillicum: praecipue in illis, quorum carnes sunt paucae.	And most often it is displaced and comes down to the lower part towards the armpit: especially in those in whom the flesh is little
Quoniam egrediur in eis uelociter, et ingreditur uelociter.	For it comes out in flesh quickly and enters quickly
In illis autem quorum carnes sunt multae, est econtrario illius, scilicet quia egreditur cum difficultate, et ingreditur cum difficultate.	In those in whom the flesh is much, it is contrary to this, for it comes out with difficulty and enters with difficulty
Et fortasse accidit quibusdam hominibus percussio, aut casus, et apostematur Humerus apostemate calido, et putatur propter illud, quia iam dislocatus est.	And perhaps it happens to some people by blow or falling, and the Humerus is displaced by a hot swelling, and it is thought because of this that it is displaced
Oportet ergo, ut experiaris illud, donec stes super certitudinem eius, et tunc procedas in curatione eius.	It is necessary therefore to experience this until you are certain of its extent, and then you may proceed with its treatment.
Et cognoscitur dislocatio, quando est ad inferiora uersus titillicum: et distinguas inter Humerum dislocatum, et humerum sanum.	It is recognized that it is displaced when it comes down towards the armpit: and you must distinguish between a displaced Humerus and a sound one
Nam tu inuenis inter eos diuersitatem manifestam, et inuenis in capite Humeri concauitatem, et sub titillico apud tactum caput humeri quasi ipsum sit ouum: et non potest infirmus reducere manum ad aurem suam, neque mouere eam omnibus motibus.	For you will find among them a manifest difference, and you will find in the head of the Humerus a concavity, and under the armpit at the touch of the head of the Humerus as though it were a bone: and it is not possible to reduce the limb with the hand at the wrist, nor to move it in any way.
Et similiter, si dislocatur uersus pectus, aut ad sursum: tunc inuenis manifestum tactum, neque occultatur.	And similarly, if it is displaced towards the chest, or upwards: then you will find a clear sensation, neither hidden
Et huius quidem dislocationis fit facilis reductio, quando est recens, aut infirmus est puer.	And in such a displacement there is a simple reduction when it is recent, or when the limb is weak
Et reductio eius est, ut eleuet minister manum suam ad superiora.	And its reduction is that it elevates the minister's hand to the upper parts.
Deinde pone tu pollices tuos sub titillico eius, et eleua iuncturam cum fortitudine ad sursum ad locum suum: et minister eleuet manum suam, et extendat eam ad sursum.	Then place your thumbs under the nail of his thumb, and elevate the joint with strength upwards to its place: and the minister will elevate his hand and extend it upwards.
Deinde ponat eam inferius, ipse enim redit uelociter.	Then place the lower part below, itself returning quickly.
Si autem non redit per illud quod diximus, et sunt a principio quo accidit dislocatio dies multi: tunc oportet, ut balneetur infirmus in aqua calida, et administretur embrocatio quae mollificat et lenit, sicut si decoquantur radices alteae, et foenugraecum, et mellilotum in aqua, et administretur.	If however it does not return by that which we have said, and it has been displaced from the beginning for several days: then it is necessary that the patient be bathed in warm water, and that an embolus be administered which softens and soothes, like those which are extracted from elder roots, and rue, and meadowsweet in water, and an embolus be administered.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et ponatur sub titillico eius sphera et lana, quae sit aequalis inter lenitatem et stricturam.	Then the patient is laid on his back: and under his thumb a sphere and wool are placed, which should be equal between softness and tension.
Deinde ponat medicus calcaneum suum super spheram, et eleuet caput humeri cum uirtute, et attrahat manum infirmi ad inferiora.	Then the physician places his heel on the sphere, and elevates the upper arm with force, and attracts the patient's hand downwards
Et minister alius teneat caput infirmi, ut non moueatur ad inferiora: ipse namque redit statim.	And another minister holds the patient's head, so that it does not move downwards: himself returning immediately.
Et si uis, reduc eum secundum modum hunc: et est, ut facias esse praesentem uirum qui sit longior infirmo, et stet a parte lateris, et intromittat humerum suum sub titillico infirmi: et eleuet titillicum eius ad superiora, donec sit infirmus suspensus in aere.	And if you wish, reduce it according to this method: and it is that you make the strong hand which is longer than the patient's hand to stand at the side, and insert the arm under the thumb of the patient: and elevate the thumb to the upper parts, until the patient is suspended in the air.
Et minister alius trahat manum infirmi ad inferiora uentris eius.	And another minister grasps the patient's hand downwards towards his belly
Si autem infirmus est leuis: tunc oportet, ut suspendatur cum eo aliquid aliud, ut grauet ipsum: nam redit dislocatio statim.	If however the patient is limp: then it is necessary that he be suspended with something else, so that it relaxes him: for it returns quickly.
Et reducitur etiam secundum modum alium: et est, ut figatur in terra lignum longum, cuius caput sit rotundum figura: sicut manica mortarii: quod non sit grossum, neque subtile.	And it is also reduced in another way: that it appears like a long stick which is embedded in the earth, with a rounded head: like the sleeve of a shroud: for it is neither thick nor thin.
Deinde ponatur sub infirmo postquam ponuntur super caput ligni panni lenes: et infirmus sit stans secundum longitudinem ligni.	Then it is placed under the lower part after the upper part of the stick has been covered with soft wool: and the lower part remains fixed according to the length of the stick
Deinde extendatur manus eius ad inferiora a parte altera, et extendatur corpus eius ab altera parte cum fortitudine: nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then extend the hand downwards from the other side, and extend the body downwards from the other side with force: for the suture returns to its place with speed.
Quod si difficilis sit eius reductio per omnia quae diximus, tunc utere hac cura: et est, ut accipias lignum cuius longitudo sit quantitas duorum brachiorum, et eius latitudo quantitas quatuor digitorum, et grossitudo eius quantitas duorum digitorum: cui sit caput rotundum, ut alleuietur introitus eius in profundum titillici, secundum hanc formam.	If its reduction is difficult by all that we have said, then take care of it thus: take a stick whose length is equal to the distance of two arms, and whose width is equal to the distance of four fingers, and whose thickness is equal to the distance of two fingers: and let its head be rounded, so that it may fill the opening downwards to the bottom of the wound, according to this shape
Deinde ligentur super caput rotundum panni lenes, ut non laedat lignum infirmum.	Then bind on the rounded head of the stick soft wool, so that it does not harm the wounded limb.
Deinde ponatur sub titillico infirmi, ut extendatur manus, aut brachium super lignum usque ad inferiora: et ligetur lignum super adiutorium et brachium et extremitatem manus.	Then place under the wound the lower part of the limb, so that the hand or arm extends over the stick down to the lower part: and bind the stick to the aid and the hand and the extremity of the hand
Deinde ponatur brachium super gradum scalae per latitudinem, et extendatur manus ad inferiora, et dimittatur reliquum corpus suspensum a parte altera.	Then place the arm over the step of the ladder for the width, and extend the hand downwards, and let the rest of the body hang loose from the other side.
Iunctura enim ingreditur statim.	The suture enters immediately.
Cum ergo completur introitus eius secundum quemcunque modum possibile est: tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico spheram aequalis quantitatis ex lana.	When it has therefore completed its passage through it in whatever way is possible: then it is necessary to place under the wound a sphere equal in quantity from wool
Deinde pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum olibano, et albumine oui super humerum totum, sicut reuoluitur desuper.	Then put on a prepared dressing of ground flour with oil, and white of egg over the whole arm, as it is turned outwards
Deinde stringe sub titillico strictura decenti: et reuoluatur ligamentum super emplastrum desuper: et annectatur manus eius ad collum ipsius, et dimittatur, neque moueatur manus eius septem diebus.	Then tighten the string under the nipple: and restore the ligament above the swelling: and connect its hand to the neck of itself, and let it go, neither move its hand for seven days.
Et oportet, ut ponatur cibus infirmipaucus, donec confortetur membrum: quoniam est uelocius ad sanationem eius.	It is necessary to give the patient food, until the limb is comfortable: because it is quicker for its healing.
Deinde ponatur amplior post septem dies, aut quinque, et ex ercitetur cum motu.	Then put on a larger dressing after seven days, or five, and keep it until movement returns.
Si ergo firmatur et non mollificatur, tunc iam sanatus est.	If it is firm and does not soften, then it is healed.
Si uero iunctura dislocatur multotiens, propter humiditatem quae accidit ei, aut propter caussam aliam: tunc oportet, ut administretur in ea cauterium cum tribus foraminibus, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo de cauterio.	If the ligature has been displaced many times, because of the moisture which has happened to it, or for another cause: then it is necessary to administer cautery with three holes, according to what is stated in the chapter on cautery
Quod si fiat hoc totum, et soluatur ligamentum post septem dies, et non confirmetur iunctura, et reducatur emplastrum et strictura super ipsum aliquotiens, et non firmetur, et cadat, et non possit eleuare ipsum ad superiora: tunc scias, quod nerui eius qui sunt ad caput humeri, iam incisi sunt, aut extensi, aut mollificati: et scias, quod iunctura nunquam figetur in loco suo.	If you do all this, and the ligament is dissolved after seven days, and the ligature is not confirmed, and the swelling and stricture above it are reduced, and it does not firm, and it falls off, and it is not possible to elevate it to the upper parts: then you know that the nerves which are at the head of the humerus are cut, or extended, or softened: and you know that the ligature has never been fixed in its place
Dislocationis autem quae fit uersus pectus et mammillam, aut ad posteriora reductio, fit cum impulsione et extensione cum manibus: donec redeat, et administretur in ea reliqua strictura et cura, donec sanetur.	As for a dislocation which happens towards the breast and the nipple, or backwards, it is reduced by impulse and extension with the hands: until it returns, and the remaining stricture and care are administered until it is healed
Quod si accidat post sanationem grauitas in membro, et tarditas in motu eius, tunc utatur infirmus balneo multotiens, donec leniatur illa grauitas, et redeat ad naturam eius primam.	If after healing there is still a degree of stiffness in the limb, and tardiness in its movement: then the patient is bathed many times, until the stiffness is softened, and it returns to its natural state.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Cubiti.	(The text following this section is not included in the request and is therefore not translated.)
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter XXVIII.
Scias, quod iunctura Cubiti dislocatur cum difficultate, et similiter redit cum difficultate etiam: et ipsa quidem dislocatur ad omnes partes, et praecipue ad anteriorem, aut ad posteriorem.	Know that the dislocation of the cubital bone is difficult, and returns with difficulty: and it dislocates to all parts, especially forward or backward.
Et eius dislocatio non occultatur tibi: quoniam est cadens sub uisu, et sub tactu, secundum quamcunque figuram dislocetur.	Its dislocation is not concealed: because it hangs down under the skin and under the touch, according to whatever position it is dislocated in
Et quando coniungis cubitum dislocatum cum sano, declaratur tibi illud manifeste.	And when you join the dislocated cubital bone with the sound one, it is declared to be firm
Concauatur enim iunctura, et non potest duplicare brachium, neque tangere cum eo humerum suum.	The join must be firm, and the arm must not be doubled over, nor touched with the other arm
Et oportet, ut properes, et reducas dislocationem statim, antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And it is necessary to act promptly, and reduce the dislocation immediately, before swelling occurs
Nam si accidit ei apostema calidum, difficilis fit eius reductio: et fortasse non sanatur omnino, praecipue quando est ad posteriora.	For if swelling occurs, its reduction becomes difficult: and it may not heal at all, especially if it is at the back.
Est enim deterior omnibus speciebus dislocationis, et uehementioris doloris eis: et multotiens descendit cum ea mors.	There is great pain of all kinds of dislocations, and of fear of it: and it descends with great violence.
Et restauratio eius quando est ex eis quae possibile est reducere, est, ut extendatur manus eius cum duabus manibus: et brachium eius sit expansum, et manus medici sint supra cubitum et sub eo, et ipse impellat iuncturam cum pollicibus manuum suarum simul, aut cum radice palmae suae, donec redeat ad locum suum.	And its restoration when it is possible to reduce it, is that you extend your hand with both hands: and extend your arm, and place the hands of the physician above the elbow and under it, and he himself drives the join together with his thumbs together, or with the root of his palm, until it returns to its place
Aut uero dislocatio est ad anteriora: tunc redit ita, ut duplicet manum cum manu sua, donec percutiat cum radice palmae suae cubitum qui est dislocatus.	Or else the dislocation is forward: then it returns so that you bend your hand with your hand, until it touches with the root of your palm the dislocated cubital bone
Quod si non obedit dislocatio ad reductionem, tunc administra extensionem uehementem, fortem ualde: et est, ut extendant brachium duo ministri: et teneant ipsum duo ministri etiam, ut non remoueatur apud extensionem.	If it does not yield to reduction, then administer strong extension, force: and that you extend the arm with two assistants: and they must hold it still even when extending
Deinde reuoluatur brachium ad omnem partem postquam inuoluitur super manum eius pannus duplicatus longus, aut ligamentum latum.	Then the arm is returned to its entirety after it has been encompassed over the hand by a doubled long bandage or a wide ligament.
Et quando tangit medicus manu sua iuncturam, inungat ipsam cum oleo: ut sit illud ex eis quae adiuuant in lubricitate iuncturae cum facilitate.	When the doctor grasps the hand with his grasp, let him moisten it with oil: that it may be from that which assists in the lubrication of the joint with ease.
Deinde impellat iuncturam impulsione uehementi, donec redeat.	Then he drives the grasp forward with force until it returns
Et post reductionem eius oportet, ut ponatur super ipsam emplastrum, in quo sit stipticitas, et exiccatio cum albugine oui: et stringatur strictura decenti.	And after its reduction, it is necessary to place upon it a compress where there is styptic action and drying with alum: and it should be bound firmly enough.
Et suspendatur brachium a collo infirmi: et dimitte diebus aliquot.	The arm should be suspended from the collar of the bed: and let it rest for a few days.
Deinde soluatur.	Then it will be cured.
Si ergo firmatur iunctura in loco suo, tunc solue ligamentum ab ea, et dimitte ipsam.	If the joint remains closed in its place, then solve the ligament from it and let it go
Et si uides iuncturam non bene stringi, tunc itera emplastrum, et ligamentum, et dimitte ipsam diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	And if the joint is not well bound, then repeat the compress and the ligament, and let it rest for a few days until it is bound
Deinde solue ipsam.	Then it will be cured
Si autem accidit ei grauitas post reductionem iuncturae, et dispositio sit in motu: tunc administra humectationem in balneatione, et fricationem subtilem, et compressionem, donec liniatur, aut pone super iuncturam iliati, id est, natem arietis pinguem.	If, however, there should happen to him a great degree of pain after the reduction of the joint, and the limb be stiff: then give lubrication in the bath, and gentle friction, and compression, until the pain subsides, or place over the joint a poultice, that is, a piece of fat from a sheep's belly
Deinde ligetur, et dimitte ipsam super eam die et nocte.	Then it is bound, and let it rest upon the bed day and night
Deinde aufer eam, et intromitte ipsum in balneum.	Then take away the bandage, and put it into the bath.
Cum ergo sudat, tunc frica iuncturam fricatione temperata.	When it is wet, then gently friction the joint.
Deinde itera super ipsam aleliati uice una, et secunda, et tertia cum introitu balnei, donec leniatur.	Then repeat upon it oil once, twice, and thrice with the entrance of the bath, until it is softened
Et si uis, pone super ipsam stercus uaccinum, humidum, calefactum cum butyro, et stringe super ipsum.	If necessary, place above the rectum a cushion filled with fat, moist and warmed with butter, and bind over it.
Fac illud aliquotiens.	If necessary. Place above the rectum a cushion filled with fat, moist and warmed with butter, and bind over it.
Ipsa namque lenitur, et redit ad dispositionem suam.	It itself [the cushion] will soften, and returns to its original position.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Almahassem.	From the treatment of dislocation of Almahassem.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter XXIX.
Mahassem manus multotiens dislocatur, id est, iunctura quae est inter brachium et manum.	The limb of Mahassem is much displaced, that is, the joint between the arm and the hand is dislocated
Et reductio dislocationis eius est facilis.	And the reduction of this dislocation is easy
Econtrario reliquarum iuncturarum.	Contrary to the rest of the joints
Verumtamen oportet, ut uelocitas sit in reductione dislocationis eius in hora in qua dislocatur, antequam apostemetur locus: aut accidat in eo apostema calidum.	Indeed it is necessary to take care that the speed of reduction of this dislocation does not exceed the hour in which it was displaced, before the place is set: or else it will happen in that setting a callous fracture.
Et reductio dislocationis in eo est, ut ponas Mahassem manus infirmae super tabulam, et extendat minister manum eius: et ponat medicus palmam suam super eminentiam iuncturae, et impellat eam, donec redeat.	And the reduction of this dislocation is like this: place the lower limb of Mahassem on a board and extend the hand: and the physician puts his palm on the prominence of the joint and urges it until it returns
Verumtamen oportet, ut consyderetur, si palma iam recessit ad uentrem manus: tunc ponat infirmus dorsum manus suae super tabulam apud extensionem et reductionem: et si dislocatio est procedens ad dorsum manus, tunc sit positio manus eius intrinsece super tabulam, id est, interior pars manus eius super tabulam ponatur, ut cadat manus medici super ipsam eminentiam iuncturae.	Indeed it is necessary to take care, if the palm should slip inside the limb: then the infirm person puts the back of his hand on the board at the extension and reduction: and if the dislocation is proceeding towards the back of the hand, then let the position of the hand be inside the board, that is, the inner part of the hand is placed on the board, so that the physician's hand rests on the prominence of the joint itself
Si ergo redit statim, bonum est: et si non, tunc stringe eam cum emplastro sedante apostema: et dimitte ipsum, neque iteres illud.	If therefore it returns immediately, that is good: and if not, then bind the limb with a dressing while it is at rest: and let it go, and do not attempt it again
Nam si non tolerat, neque potes super reductionem eius, postquam praetereunt ei dies, uerumtamen iunctura remanet secundum tortuositatem suam: et non nocet infirmo aliquid, nisi quod mollificatur manus, et non potest stringere aliquid: tunc scias, quod nerui sunt abscissi, aut attriti.	If he does not tolerate it, neither can the flesh above the reduction remain firm after a few days: for truly the joint will remain joined according to its nature. And it does not harm the patient anything, except that the hand is softened, and nothing can be bound: then you know that the nerves are cut, or injured.
Non est ergo ingenium in ea, nisi ut stringatur cum cauterio prope casum eius.	There is no wit in that, except that it be bound with cautery near the case of it
Et fortasse non confert illud aliquid.	Perhaps it does not matter at all.
Cum ergo non redit Almahassem, tunc pone super ipsum emplastrum, quod narrauimus.	When the Almahassem does not return, then put upon it a dressing as we have said.
Deinde stringatur, et dimittatur quinque diebus: postea soluatur et dimittatur, et exercitetur manus.	Then bind it, and let it remain for five days: afterwards loosen it and let it go, and exercise the hand.
Si autem priuatur motus eius, et accidat in ea aliquid grauitatis: tunc leni eam cum aqua calefacta, et fricatione aliquotiens, donec leniatur.	If however its motion be retarded, and anything weighty occur in it: then soften it with warm water and gentle friction until it is softened
¶ De curatione dislocationis Digitorum.	(End of excerpt
Caput XXX.	(Chapter 30.)
Quando dislocatur ex eis Digitus ad omnem partem, uel ex eis Digitus ad dorsum palmae, aut uentrem eius: tunc extende Digitum, et impelle dislocationem pollicibus tuis, donec redeat.	When the Digit is dislocated from its place towards the whole of its part, or from the palm of the hand towards the wrist, or from the bone towards the wrist: then extend the Digit and drive out the dislocation with your thumbs until it returns
Deinde sustenta caput Digiti, et suspende ipsum uersus partem ad quam dislocatur, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	Then support the head of the Digit, and suspend it against the part from which it is dislocated, and let it go in two days.
Deinde suspende eum, et extende ipsum, donec aequetur rectus in illo die suo.	Then suspend it, and extend it, until it is straight on that day.
Cum ergo fuerit nox, liga ipsum secundum narrationem ipsam: et non cesses soluere ipsum in die: et exerce eum cum motu: et liga ipsum in nocte.	When night comes, bind it as we have said: and do not cease to loosen it daily: and exercise it with motion: and bind it at night.
Fac illud diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	Do that for a few days until it is strung together.
Et similiter fac cum eo, si dislocatur ad uentrem manus: et liga eum ad partem ipsam, et fac cum eo operationem tuam primam, donec sanetur.	Do the same with it for a few days until it is joined together.
Et similiter fac cum eo quando dislocatur ad reliquas partes.	Do the same with it for a few days until it is connected together again.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Spondilium dorsi.	Do the same for a few days until it is strung together.
Caput XXXI.	Do the same for a few days until it is connected together again.
Quando accidit alicui Spondilium dorsi, aut colli dislocatio completa, aut remouentur Spondiles multae a locis suis: tunc non est in ea curatio, quoniam mors properat infirmo.	When it happens to anyone's neck or back, or a displacement of many vertebrae from their places: then it is not in that case necessary to do anything, for the poison is sufficient for the sick man.
Et signum illius est, quod egestio infirmi egreditur absque uoluntate, neque potest tenere eam: et multotiens mollificantur ex eo quaedam membra eius, aut duo crura eius, aut duo brachia ipsius, aut unum eorum: aut remouetur Spondilis una de loco suo.	And a sign of that is that the patient's limbs depart from him without his will, and that he cannot hold them together: and many times they soften some limb of him, or two arms or two legs, or one of his members: or they move a vertebra from its place.
Multotiens enim remouetur, quod multotiens fit remotio earum ad quatuor partes.	Many times they move it because many times the removal is made from four sides
Illa ergo quae remouetur ad posteriora, nominatur Gibbositas.	That which is moved to the back is called gibbosity.
Curatio uero eius est, ut consyderes tunc, si Gibbositas accidit a puericia: tunc non est in ea curatio, neque ex ea est sanatio omnino.	The treatment of that is, that he should rest in bed until the gibbosity has happened from infancy: then there is no healing from that at all
In illa autem quae accidit a casu, aut percussione, aut similibus illis, iam dixerunt antiqui modos curationis sermone prolixo.	But in whatever case it happens, whether by chance, or by blow, or in any similar way, as the ancients said in their long discourse on the modes of treatment.
Cuius plurimum non redit cum proficuo.	Of which the greatest part does not return when it has gone out with success
Ego uero iam abbreuiaui ex illo, cuius parum excusat a multo eius ex propinquitate mea ad intentionem: et expositione mea qua exposui illud, et formaui instrumentum eius diuerso modo ab eo quo ostenderunt illud, et exposuerunt ipsum.	I myself, however, have abridged it from that, because of the great number of things which I have omitted from it on account of their proximity to my intention: and because I have set out the matter in a different form from that in which it was shown, and have exposed it in a different way
Dico ergo, quod in gibbositate quae accidit ab anteriori parte, non est ingenium, neque sanatio ex ea.	I say therefore, that which occurs in the abdomen from the front part, is neither an ailment nor is it curable from it.
Et similiter in illa quae fit ad duo latera etiam.	And in like manner that which happens to the two sides also.
Et non curatur ex eis, nisi illa quae accidit in dorso proprie, cum eo quod ego narro: et est, ut extendatur infirmus super faciem suam super podium aequale prope parietem: et expandatur sub eo stramentum humidum, ut non laedatur pectus eius.	And it is not cured from that which happens except that which happens in the back part, as I have said: and it is that the patient be extended upon his face above a level platform near the wall: and let an oily dressing be applied under that, so that his chest is not injured thereby.
Deinde ponatur lignum rectum fixum in fouea in terra, in extremitate podii, circiter caput eius: et lignum aliud circiter pedes eius in extremitate altera podii: et minister teneat lignum, et sit non firmatum in fouea.	Then let a fixed stool be placed in the fire in the earth, near the head: and let another stool be placed near the feet in the other foot: and let the minister hold the stool, and let it not be firm in the fire.
Et minister alter teneat alterum.	And let the other minister hold the other one.
Deinde inuolue super caput infirmi, et sub titillicis eius ligamentum lene, firmum: et extende extremitatem ligamenti ad lignum quod est apud caput eius: et liga ipsum in eo.	And then draw over the head of the patient, and under his armpits a soft ligament, firm: and extend the extremity of the ligament to the limb which is at the head of him: and bind it in that.
Deinde stringe ligamentum aliud supra anchas eius, et supra genua ipsius, et apud cauillas eius.	And then bind another ligament above his shoulders and above his knees and at his buttocks
Deinde aggrega ligamenta omnia, et liga ea in ligno altero quod est apud pedes eius.	And then gather up all the ligaments and bind them in the other limb which is at the feet of him.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem ligni ligamentum, et non remoueantur duo ligna ex locis suis in quibus sunt fixa: uerumtamen non sint firmata, sicut diximus.	And then let all the ministers extend to the part of the limb of the ligaments, and do not move the two stools from the places where they are fixed: indeed they are not to be fixed, as we have said.
Et medicus ponat palmas suas super Spondilem cum fortitudine, donec redeat: aut ponat super eam tabulam.	And the physician puts his palms upon the spine with force, until he is restored: or puts upon him a board
Deinde annectat super tabulam pedes suos, donec redeat.	And then he binds upon the board his feet until he is restored
Si autem non redit per hanc curationem, tunc accipe tabulam cuius longitudo sit circiter tria brachia.	But if he does not recover by this treatment, then take a board whose length is about three arms
Et caua in pariete de quo diximus quod est prope infirmum, locum in quem ingrediatur extremitas tabulae.	And the cavity in the wall from which we said is close to the patient, the place where the edge of the board enters.
Deinde pone medium tabulae super Spondilem.	Then place the middle of the board over the Spondilem.
Et ponat pedes suos medicus super extremitatem alteram.	And let the doctor place his feet on the other extremity
Et stringat bene, donec coartetur Spondilis, et redeat ad locum suum.	And tighten well, until the Spondilem is taut, and then return to his place
Deinde si uis, operare cum torno quod inuoluitur cum manu tua: et est, ut figas in terram apud caput infirmi in postremo podii duo ligna, quorum longitudo sit brachii unius: et apud caput eius in postremo podii duo ligna.	And if you wish, work with the ankle that is involved with your hand: and that is, as two nails are placed at the foot of the patient at the end of the two thighs, and their length is that of one forearm: and at their head at the end of the two thighs.
Et sit longitudo quae est inter omne lignum palmus unus: et iam factum est in omni loco foramen, in quo currit tornum: et firmetur lignum omne in terra multum, ne moueatur omnino.	And let the length be that which is between every two nails be one palm: and when it is made in every place where there is a hole through which the screw runs: and fix every nail firmly in the earth very much, so that it does not move at all.
Et intromittatur lignum rotundum: et est tornum in quo reuoluitur ligamentum in duobus foraminibus duorum lignorum.	And insert the round nail: and it is the screw in which the ligament is wound in two holes of the two nails.
Et in extremitate eius est foramen, in quo firmatur lignum, cuius longitudo est palmus cum eo quod reuoluitur: et in duobus lignis aliis est similiter illius.	And at its extremity is a hole in which the nail is fixed, whose length is one palm with that which is wound: and in two other nails is like that
Deinde stringe ligamenta quae strinxisti in pectore infirmi torno quod est apud caput eius: et ligamenta quae strinxisti in cruribus eius in torno quod est apud pedes eius.	And tighten the ligaments which you strained in the chest of the patient around the ankle which is at his head: and the ligaments which you strained in the thighs around the ankle which is at his feet
Deinde stet apud omne tornum minister, qui torqueat manum suam cum licinio, cum quo reuoluitur tornum: et medicus aequet Spondilem, secundum quod diximus.	And stay at every screw minister, who twists his hand with a wrench, as the screw is wound: and the doctor will equal the Spondilem, as we said before.
Haec est forma torni, quae sequitur.	This is the form of the screw that follows.
Deinde postquam redit Spondilis, et aequatur locus, tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum exiccatiuum cum albumine oui.	Then, when Spondilis has returned and the place is evened, it is necessary to apply an ointment of desiccated plaster with albumin.
Deinde stuppam.	Then, plaster.
Postea pone supra emplastrum astellam ex tabula, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, aut circiter eos.	Then place above the plaster a bandage of three fingers' breadth, or somewhat less
Et longitudo eius quantitas quae capiat locum Gibbositatis, et super partem Spondilis sanae.	And its length should be equal to the extent of the Gibbositas, and over the sound part of Spondilis.
Deinde ligetur cum ligamento quod diximus.	Then it is bound with the ligament which we mentioned.
Et utatur infirmus nutrimento subtili, donec sanetur.	And the patient should be nourished with light food until he is healed.
Quod si remaneat quiddam eminentiae in loco in fine sanationis: tunc oportet, ut administrentur medicinae quae mollificant, et leniunt, cum administratione tabulae quam narrauimus tempore longo.	If anything remains prominent in the place at the end of healing: then it is necessary to administer medicines which soften and soothe, with the administration of the plaster which we mentioned previously for a long time
Et iam administratur in illo lamina plumbi.	And they are administered in that layer of lead
Et quandoque accidit eminentia in postremo Spondilium dorsi: et putatur per eam dislocatio, et est illud os quod iam eminet.	And sometimes it happens that the prominence appears at the end of Spondilis dorsi: and it is thought to be dislocation, and that is the bone which is now prominent
Quare non oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei cum hac medicina: fortasse enim accidere faciet mortem.	Therefore it is not right to assume for it any medicine: for perhaps it will happen that thereby it will cause death.
¶ De curatione Anchae dislocatae.	Of the treatment of dislocated Anchae.
Caput XXXII.	Chapter XXXII.
Scias, quod iuncturae Anchae, et iuncturae humeri, non accidit, nisi dislocatio tantum: neque accidit eis quod accidit reliquis iuncturis ex remotione parua, et concauitate.	You know that dislocations of the Anchae and of the humerus do not occur except for a complete dislocation: and that they do not occur except for a slight displacement and a concavity
Et iunctura quidem Anchae dislocatur secundum quatuor partes.	And the dislocation of the Anchae is divided into four parts
Quod est, quia dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	That is, because it is displaced forward and backward
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur ad interiora: et parum dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	Most frequently it is displaced inwards: little is displaced outwards, and towards the rear.
Et curatio dislocationis eius ad interiora, est: quia quando tu coniungis crus infirmi sanum cum infirmo, est longius: et est genu eius eminens plus quam sani, et non potest infirmus duplicare pedem suum apud inguen: et est locus qui sequitur inguen apostematus apostemate calido, propterea, quod caput coxae iam peruenit illic.	The treatment of such displacement inwards is: for when you unite the limb of the diseased with the limb of the healthy, it is longer: and the knee of the diseased limb is prominent more than that of the healthy limb, and the diseased limb cannot double its foot at the ankle: and the place which follows the ankle after displacement is the heel of the foot, because the head of the tibia has gone there.</start_of_turn>
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad exteriora est, quod sunt accidentia eius contraria istis accidentibus.	The sign of such displacement outwards is that these are the opposite of the signs of the displacement inwards.</start_of_turn>
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad anteriora, est, quia expandit crus sanum secundum complementum: uerumtamen non duplicat ipsum absque dolore qui est in genu: et si conatur ad ambulandum, non potest super illud ad anteriora: et retinetur urina eius, et apostematur inguen eius, et apud ambulationem est calcatio eius super calcaneum.	The sign of such displacement forwards is that it expands the healthy limb according to the complement: but it does not double itself without pain at the knee: and if it attempts to walk, it cannot go beyond that forwards: and it retains its urine, and its ankle is displaced, and during walking there is a swelling of the foot over the heel.</start_of_turn
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad posteriora est, ut non expandat genu, neque possit duplicare ipsum antequam duplicet inguen: et est crus eius etiam breuius altero: et inguen est mollificatum, et est caput coxae apud locum ilii.	The sign of such displacement backwards is that it does not expand the knee, and cannot double itself before it doubles the ankle: and the limb is also shorter than the other: and the ankle is softened, and the head of the tibia is at the level of the hip.</start_of_turn
Reductio uero huius dislocationis specierum est, ut consyderes tunc, si dislocatio est uetusta, quae iam antiquatur cum habente ipsam.	The reduction of this displacement is of various kinds, so that as soon as possible, if the displacement is old, which has already become chronic, it should be abandoned with the one which has it.</start_of_turn>
Deinde si tu administres reductionem eius, et remanet secundum dispositionem suam: tunc non est in ea curatio omnino.	Then if you administer the reduction and it remains according to its position: then there is no longer any treatment in that.</start_of_turn>
Non ergo oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei penitus.	It is not necessary that there should be suspicion of a fracture.</start_of_turn>
In illo autem cuius dislocatio est recens, et est ex una specierum quatuor dislocationis: tunc propera ad hoc, ut uoluas iuncturam, et extendas ipsam ad interiora et ad exteriora, et moueas eam dextra et sinistra: fortasse enim redit, et non indiget alia cura.	But in that case in which the displacement is confirmed, and is of one of the four kinds of displacement: then it is proper for you to attempt to unite them, and to extend it inwards and outwards, and to move the limb from right to left: perhaps therefore it will return, and no other treatment will be necessary.</start_of_turn
Si autem non redit hoc modo, tunc oportet, ut praepares ministrum fortem, et extendat crus eius ab inferiori parte: aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento, quod ligetur super crus eius supra genu: et minister alius extendat manum eius desuper, ita ut intromittat manus suas sub titillicis eius.	If it does not return in this way, then it is necessary that you prepare a strong assistant and extend his leg from the lower part: either with your hands or with a ligature which is bound above his knee: and another assistant shall extend his hand above, so that he may insert his hand under his toes.
Deinde stringat cum ligamento leni super radicem coxae, et teneat extremitatem ligamenti alterius.	Then bind with a soft ligature over the root of the thigh, and hold the end of the other ligature.
Et sit extensio eius aut ab anteriori parte inguinis ad partem furculae, aut a posteriori ad partem dorsi.	And keep the extension either from the front of the groin to the hip bone, or from the back to the loin.
Et sit extensio eorum omnium uice una, donec eleuetur infirmus cum corpore suo a terra, et remaneat pendens.	And keep the extension firm until the patient raises himself with his body from the earth, and remains suspended.
Et haec enim species extensionis est species communis specierum quatuor.	And this is indeed a common method of extension of four kinds.
Si ergo redit dislocatio cum eo quod diximus, est bonum: et si non, tunc necesse est omni speciei illud quod dicam de curatione propria.	If it returns therefore from the dislocation as we have said, it is good: and if not, then it is necessary in every case to make use of the proper treatment.
In reductione quidem eius propria quando dislocatio est ad interiora, oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super latus suum sanum.	In reduction, however, of its own when the dislocation is inwards, it is necessary that the patient rest on his sound side
Deinde ponat ligamentum super radicem coxae, in eo quod est inter caput coxae, et locum qui est sub inguine.	Then lay the ligament over the root of the thigh, under the hip-bone, and under the groin.
Deinde extende ligamentum ad sursum a parte inguinis ad altiorem partem corporis, ad partem furculae.	Then extend the ligament upwards from the groin to the higher part of the body, to the hip bone
Deinde accipiat minister alius fortis brachia eius, et minuat locum grossum coxae infirmae, et extendat ad exteriora extensione uehementi.	Then take another strong assistant who grasps his arm, and presses the lower part of the thigh firmly, and extends it outwards with force.
Iam enim redit ad locum suum.	And thus it returns to its place
Et haec species est facilioris reliquis speciebus curationis, qua reducitur hoc membrum.	This is an easier method than the others for reducing this limb.
Si autem excusatur super te, et non obedit tibi ad introitum cum hac specie curationis omnino: tunc oportet, ut ligentur duo pedes infirmi simul cum ligamento forti, leni, super duos calcaneos, et super duo genua: et sit longitudo cuiusque a compare suo quantitatis quatuor digitorum: et sit crus infirmum extensum plus altero quantitate duorum digitorum.	If, however, he excuses himself from you, and does not obey your order to enter with this sort of treatment: then it is necessary that two feet of the patient be bound together with strong, soft ligament, over two calcanei, and over two knees: and let the length of each be equal to four fingers. And let the affected limb be extended more than the other by the quantity of two fingers.
Deinde suspendatur infirmus super caput ligni, quod sit in domo: et sit longitudo eius a terra quantitas duorum brachiorum.	The affected limb is suspended over the head of the limb which is in the bed: and let its length from the earth be equal to the quantity of two arms
Deinde praecipe iuueni forti, ut muniat caput coxae: et suspendatur cum infirmo inuenis alius: et impellat iuuenis alius, muniens coxam cum fortitudine, nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then command the young man to be strong, that he may support the hip: and suspend him with the patient: and let the young man push with force, supporting the hip with strength, for the joint returns to its place with speed.
In reditione autem eius propria, quando est dislocatio ad exteriora, oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super podium, secundum quod narrauimus in habente gibbositatem.	But in its return, when the dislocation is outward, it is necessary that the patient lie upon a board, as we have said in the case of gibbosity.
Et stringatur ligamentum super crus eius, infirmum proprie, et super pectus eius.	And bind the ligament over his thigh, the patient himself, and over his breast
Deinde ponantur duo ligna, unum apud pedes eius, et alterum apud caput ipsius.	And put two boards, one at his feet and the other at his head.
Deinde ponatur lignum additum in medio podii, fixum bene: super quod inuoluti sint panni humidi, ut non laedat infirmum: et sit lignum inter coxas eius, ut non attrahatur ad inferiora apud extensionem.	And place a board added in the middle of the foot, well fixed: over which are wet cloths, that it does not hurt the patient: and let the board be between his thighs, that it does not be drawn downwards during extension.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem suam, et medicus aequet reductionem manu sua.	Then extend all the limbs towards their part, and the physician will equal the reduction with his hand.
Si ergo obedit ad reuersionem, erit bonum.	If therefore he obeys the reduction, it will be good.
Et si non, pone super ipsam tabulam, et preme ipsam, sicut diximus in gibbositate, aequaliter.	And if not, put upon him another board, and press it down, just as we said in the case of gibbosity, equally
Verumtamen oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	The patient must remain still, so that the sick person lies over the sound limb.
Et quando dislocatio est ad anteriora, tunc oportet, ut extendatur crus infirmi uelociter: et est secundum hanc eandem narrationem super podium: et ponat medicus palmam manus suae dextrae super inguen infirmum.	When the dislocation is forward, then it is necessary to extend the limb of the patient quickly: and it is in accordance with this that the physician places his right palm over the knee of the sick person.</start_of_turn>
Deinde coartet ipsum cum manu altera, et cum illa coartatione pone ipsum extensum ad inferiora ad partem genu.	Then he tightens the limb with the other hand, and with that tightening he brings the limb down to the foot.</start_of_turn>
Et si dislocatio est ad posteriora: tunc non oportet, ut extendatur infirmus ad inferiora, et sit eleuatus super terram: imo oportet, ut sit positus super rem duram, sicut oportet, ut fit etiam si dislocatur ancha eius ad exteriora, secundum illud quod diximus de accubitu eius super duas anchas: et est super faciem eius, et ligamenta extensa: secundum quod diximus nuper.	If the dislocation is backward: then it is not necessary to extend the limb downwards, but rather to keep it elevated above the ground: for it is necessary to place it upon a firm support, just as it is necessary when the dislocation is wide in front, according to what we have said concerning its recumbency over two cushions: and it is upon its face and the ligaments extended: just as we said before.</start_of_turn>
Et oportet, ut administretur compressio cum tabula etiam super locum ad quem egreditur iunctura, cum completur reductio secundum quod oportet.	And it is necessary to apply pressure with a board also over the place from which the joint has been extruded, when the reduction has been completed according to what is necessary.</start_of_turn>
Et signum reditionis eius non occultatur tibi: et est, ut extendas duo crura infirmi: et quando uides ea aequalia, et infirmus stringit crus suum, et expandit ipsum absque excusatione: tunc scias, quia iam redit membrum, secundum quod oportet: tunc coniunge duas coxas, et pone emplastrum, et stringe cum imemati, id est, rota: ita, ut non moueatur ancha ad aliquam partium: et adhaereat infirmus quieti tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	And the sign of its return is not hidden from you: and it is that you extend both legs of the patient: and when you take them away equal, and the patient tightens his limb and expands it without groaning: then you know that the limb has returned, according to what is necessary: then join the two thighs together, and put on a bandage, and bind with a twist: so that it does not move to any part: and the patient must rest quietly for three days, or four.</start_of_turn>
Deinde solue ligamentum, et emplastrum, et compara crus cum altero: tunc si uides ea aequalia in statu, tunc scias, quod dislocatio iam firmata est: absolue ergo infirmum ad ambulandum.	Then loosen the ligament and the bandage, and compare the limb with the other: then if you take them away equal in position, then you know that the dislocation is fixed: absolutely therefore the patient can walk.</start_of_turn
Et si uides aliquid mollificationis: tunc redi, et emplastra illud, et stringe illud secundum stricturam tuam primam: et dimitte illud etiam tribus diebus.	If there is anything that softens: then return it, and plaster it, and bind it according to your first measure: and discharge it in three days.
Deinde solue illud et fac ipsum tardare in ambulatione super utrumque aliquot diebus, donec confortetur bene.	Then dissolve it and make it walk slowly on both sides for a few days, until it is comfortable.</start_of_turn>
¶ De dislocationis Genu.	(This sentence is not included in the translation request.)</start_of_turn>
Caput XXXIII.	(This section of the text is not included in the translation request.)</start_of_turn>
Genu dislocatur secundum tres modos.	The joint is dislocated in three ways.</start_of_turn
Dislocatur ad exteriora, ad interiora, et ad inferiora, scilicet ad posteriora.	It is displaced outwards, inwards, and downwards, that is, backwards.</start_of_turn
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora.	It is not displaced forwards.</start_of_turn
Et signum dislocationis eius, est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut applicet crus suum ad coxam suam.	And the sign of its dislocation is that the limb hangs limply from the limb.</start_of_turn
Si autem non adhaeret cum coxa: tunc scias, quod Genu est dislocatum.	But if it does not adhere to the hip: then you know that the joint is dislocated.</start_of_turn
Et restauratio omnium modorum dislocationis eius est, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum, ita ut iam extendat crus suum si potest super illud, et adhaeret dorsum tuum ad faciem eius: et pone pedem eius inter pedes tuos.	And the restoration of all these ways of dislocation is that you make the patient sit upright, so that he can extend his limb as much as possible over it, and that he joins his back to his front: and place his foot between his feet.</start>
Deinde adhaerere fac Genu eius cum palmis tuis, et recta eas inter digitos tuos super Genu eius.	Then join his limb to your palms, and make it straight between his fingers over his joint.</start_of_turn
Deinde applica cum palma tua duo latera Genu eius cum fortitudine.	Then apply with your palm two sides of the joint with force.</start_of_turn
Et minister alius extendat pedem eius, donec redeat Genu ad locum suum.	And another attendant extends his foot until the joint returns to its place.</start_of_turn
Et signum reditionis est, ut adhaereat crus cum coxa in lenitate, non laboriose.	And the sign of its return is that the limb adheres to the hip easily, not painfully.</start_of_turn
Deinde emplastra ipsum, et adhaerere fac crus cum coxa.	Then apply the plaster firmly, and secure the thigh to the hip.
Deinde liga ea simul cum uitta tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	Then bind it thus for three days, or four.
Deinde solue ea.	Then loosen it.
Et non utatur infirmus ambulatione aliquot diebus, donec sanetur.	And do not permit the patient to walk for a few days, until he is healed.
Si autem recusatur tibi reductio eius, tunc administra extensionem fortem cum ligamentis, quorum praecessit narratio in curatione anchae, donec redeat.	If, however, he resists reduction, then administer an extension of force with ligatures, as has been mentioned in the treatment of fracture, until it returns
¶ De curatione dislocationis Calcanei.	(The text continues with instructions for treating a dislocation of the calcaneus.)
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter XXXIV
Calcaneus quandoque remouetur remotione parua, et quandoque dislocatur secundum complementum.	The calcaneus is sometimes displaced by a small fracture, and sometimes by a dislocation of the fragment.
Et dislocatio eius fit, aut ad interiora, aut ad exteriora.	It is displaced either inwards or outwards
Et signum dislocationis eius est, quod uides Calcaneum inflatum, procedentem ad partem ad quam dislocatur.	And the sign of dislocation is that the calcaneus is swollen and displaced towards the part which is displaced
Curatio autem remotionis eius, est facilis reditionis: et est, ut extendatur cum facilitate cum manibus, et aequetur, donec redeat.	The treatment for its removal is simple restoration: it is to extend it easily with the hands, and to reduce it, until it returns
In curatione autem eius quando dislocatur secundum complementum, oportet, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum: et teneat ipsum minister fortis ualde a posteriori parte dorsi eius, in medio ipsius.	When it is dislocated by the fragment, it is necessary to keep the patient sitting upright: and to hold it firmly from behind the back of his ankle, in the middle of it
Deinde tene tu cum manu tua dextra pedem eius a superiori parte eius, et cum manu tua sinistra ab inferiori parte pedis eius loco cauillae.	Then take hold with your right hand the upper part of his foot, and with your left hand the lower part of his foot at the ankle joint
Deinde trahe pedem ad tecum manu tua dextra.	And pull the foot towards you with your right hand
Deinde cum sinistra duabus uicibus.	And with your left hand support his ankle joint with two fingers
Deinde extende cum sinistra, et impelle pectus pedis cum dextra uersus crus absque labore.	Then extend it with your left hand, and push the ankle joint with your right hand without straining.
Fac illud bis, sicut narrauimus.	Do it twice, as we have said.
Deinde impelle pectus pedis ad crus in uice tertia, et tu trahis cauillam.	Then drive the thumb of the foot against the thigh in the hollow of the third digit, and you grasp the heel.
Si ergo redit in uice una, aut in duabus secundum hunc modum, et uides pedem aequatum, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera operationem super ipsum: quoniam ipse redit.	If it returns once, or twice according to this method, and you have equated the foot, it is good: and if not, repeat the operation above itself: for it will return itself
Si autem prohibetur tibi reductio eius cum eo quod narrauimus: tunc fac iacere infirmum super dorsum suum super terram, et fige paxillum in terra firmatum ualde, ut cadat inter coxas eius: et tu iam inuoluisti super ipsum pannum, ut non laedat infirmum.	But if it is hindered by you from reduction as we have said: then make the patient lie upon his back upon the earth, and fix the heel firmly to the ground, so that it lies between the patient's thighs: and you shall grasp above it, so that it does not hurt the patient.
Deinde accipiat minister coxam eius: postea extendat minister alter pedem, aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento quod liget super collum pedis.	Then take hold of the knee: afterwards extend the other limb of the foot, either with the hands or with a strap that binds over the ankle bone
Deinde extendat omnis minister contra extensionem comparis sui: et paxillus sit stans inter duas coxas infirmi retinens eum, ut non attrahatur corpus eius ad inferiora apud extensionem.	Then extend all the limbs against the extension of each other: and the heel shall be stable between the two thighs of the patient holding it back, so that it does not draw the body downwards with the extension.
Deinde aequet medicus dislocationem manibus suis, et minister alter teneat crus sanum ad inferiora.	Then the physician must equate the dislocation with his hands, and the other limb must hold the sound limb downwards.
Nam dislocatio redit cum uelocitate.	For the dislocation returns with speed.
Quando ergo redit dislocatio, et declaratur tibi sanitas reditionis eius: tunc pone emplastrum et stuppam, et stringe ipsam cum ligamentis firmiter, et liga pedem cum ligamento ad crus.	When it has returned, and the soundness of the reduction is declared: then put on a bandage and plaster, and bind up the limb firmly with ligaments, and bind the foot to the ankle bone
Et oportet, ut caueas uel timeas de neruis, qui sunt supra calcaneum posterius, ut non sit ligamentum super eos uehemens, et laedat eos.	And it is necessary to beware of the nerves which are above the heel behind, so that there is no tension on the ligaments above them, and that it does not hurt them
Deinde dimitte ipsum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then let it go in two or three days
Quod si mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum: deinde solue ipsum in die tertio, aut quarto: et prohibe infirmum ab ambulatione quadraginta diebus.	If the ligament is softened, string it up: then dissolve it on the third or fourth day. And restrain the patient from walking for forty days.
Si uero conatur ambulare ante illud spacium, non fit securitas quin dissoluatur super ipsum dislocatio, et corrumpatur, et non recipiat post illud curationem.	If he attempts to walk before that space has healed, there will be no security that it will be dissolved without causing displacement, corruption, and not recovering after that
Quod si accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc oportet, ut administres in sedatione eius illud, in quo praecessit narratio nostra in alio loco ex curatione, et embrocationem, donec remoueatur.	If there is a swelling there: then it is necessary to manage it in calm in that place where our account precedes concerning treatment, and bandage, until it is removed
¶ De dislocatione Digitorum pedis, et cura.	About the dislocation of the toes, and treatment.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter 5.
Oportet, ut aequetur quod dislocatur ex eis cum extensione pauca absque labore: et illud quidem non est difficile, imo est facile.	It is necessary to restore what is dislocated from the bone with little extension without labor: and this is not difficult, indeed it is easy
Si autem dislocatio est in quibusdam nodis dorsi pedis: tunc oportet, ut faciat sedere infirmus pedem suum super locum aequalem terrae, aut super tabulam: et est stans sicut ambulans.	If, however, the dislocation is in some part of the ankle: then it is necessary to make the patient sit down and rest his foot on the same level as the earth, or on a board: and he should be in the same position as if he were walking
Deinde tu sta, et pone pedem tuum super illud quod eminet ex illis iuncturis.	Then stay still, and put your foot on that which projects from these joints.
Deinde calca illud cum pede tuo cum uirtute, donec redeat, et uideas ipsum iam aequatum, et non appareat in loco eminentia.	Then bandage your foot with your foot with force, until it returns, and that it is even and does not appear in the eminence.
Deinde pone sub uentre pedis eius tabulam quae capiat pedem totum, cui sint duo capita.	Then put under the foot of him a board that can grasp the whole foot, which has two heads
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti tribus diebus.	Then string it up with a tight bandage for three days
Deinde solue ipsum, et fac quiescere eum ab ambulatione diebus multis, donec stringatur et securetur a reductione.	Then dissolve it, and make him rest from walking for many days, until it is bound up and secured from reduction
¶ De speciebus dislocationis cum uulnere uel fractura.	About the kinds of dislocation with wound or fracture
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter VI.
Quando accidit aliquid ex illo, et conaris curationem eius, et ipsius restaurationem, multotiens succedit mors: et propter illud non oportet, ut praesumat super curationem eius, quod est huiusmodi, nisi qui est prudens in arte longi usus, misericors, pius, tardus, non audax, neque praesumptuosus: et ut utatur in incaeptionce medicinis quae sedant apostemata calida tantum: et dimittat infirmum diuino iudicio.	When anything of this sort happens, and you know the cure for it, and its restoration, many times follows after: and because of that it does not befit you to be proud over the cure of it, which is like this, except that he who is prudent in the art of long usage, merciful, pious, tardy, not audacious, and not proud: and that he should be content with the advice of the physicians who sit beside the calida apostemata.
Nisi uideas, aut speras salutem a perditione cum lenitate aegritudinis, et in quo apparet quiddam spei.	Except that you are stupid, or hope for health from the gentleness of the disease, and in which there appears something of hope.
Conare ergo reductionem eius statim in principio rei, antequam accidat apostema calidum.	Try therefore to reduce it immediately at the beginning of the matter, before the calida apostema appears
Si ergo redit membrum, secundum quod uolumus, tunc administra regimen quod sedat apostema: et cura uulnus cum eo quod conuenit ei ex unguentis desiccatiuis.	If therefore the limb returns, as we would wish, then administer a regimen which will settle the apostema: and care for the wound with what agrees with it from the desiccation.
Quod si dislocatio est cum fractura, et accidunt in osse satagiae separatae, tunc conare ablationem earum, et fac in illo quod diximus in aegritudinibus simplicibus ex eo quod praecessit in locis earum.	If it is a dislocation with fracture, and they are separated from the bone in the sitting posture, then try to effect their ablation, and do in that which we said in the simple ailments from that which preceded them in those places
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, et custodi teipsum ab introitu in uiam timoris: secundum quod praecessit praedicatio mea tibi.	And be careful according to your ability, and keep yourself away from the entrance of fear: according as I have foretold to you beforehand.
Nam illud est melius tibi apud Creatorem tuum, et magis permanens ad gloriam tuam, et magis saluum tuo corpori apud illos in tuo tempore.	For it is better for you with your Creator, and more lasting for your glory, and more health for your body with them in your time.
